pros: This company has some great things to offer. good benefits, and extras like an onsite gym and cafe.  Very nice work envionment and they do a lot of fun things like have company sponsored trips or lunches.  You even get 3 weeks of paid vacation your first year, which is more than most other companies.  Some of the managers are helpful with career planning, and can be flexible with scheduleing if you are responsible about it and don't take advantage.
cons: Nothing is stable as far as business processes, procedures and systems.  Things change constantly and you better pay attention to the signs because they seem to layoff quite a bit or just move you to another position with little or no advance notice and no increase in pay, but more and more job duties.  They don't really keep you informed about changes that are going to be made. Some of the managers are micromanagers, and of course you typical office politics and people in positions that know absolutley Nothing!

review_title: Good place to work, but going thru lot of changes now in overall direction
pros:
Business Leadership led by CEO is far sighted and strong.  That shows in the company being the only monolith Card company surviving over the past 20 years and growing into a top 10 bank in US!  

Overall work culture is good, though things keep changing a lot and the employee morale can go up or down depending on the nature and timing of those changes.   For instance, Company is going thru changes and upheaval currently in effort to position from a Financial services company to a Technology Company.  

Good Benefits;  Fast paced work culture.
cons:
There is constant change of direction, managers etc in the Technology groups  and for someone who is looking for steady role, this can be difficult to adjust.   Like in many other corporate companies, layoffs occurs in cycles and can be sudden (though there is time and benefits given to support transition outside of the role).

Work-life balance of job can vary depending on the group/manager.

review_title: Formerly great company, going through some transformation challenges
pros:
There is incredible talent in the organization (although a lot has been run off in the past couple of years) that if we could better align it we could truly achieve great things.
With that said, even despite management mis-steps we continue to be successful.
Work Life balance and overall flexibility is awesome.  
Cultural values are great (when they are adhered to.)
cons:
Pursuit of being  a 'technology company' has been costly without the return expected; we now are paying huge amounts to 'buy' talent who have not delivered nearly to the level we are investing in them
Like many companies, as Capital One has grown it has become highly political;  Company is still run by ex Card Marketing people who have very little digital or technology acumen but they are the ones supposedly turning us into a 'technology' company.  And they continue to drive more layoffs yet interestingly none of them have been impacted.

review_title: Your senior management doesn't understand your job; get ready to pitch your ideas to make progress.
pros: Capital One provides great work/life balance. Everyone takes great pains to be polite and supportive. There are a number of courses provided by Capital one university to ensure that the employees know how to get along with one another. There is extreme fairness in year-end evaluations and promotions. It takes a good 40 hours every year-end to perform all of the evaluations and cross-calibrations to make sure everyone is assessed fairly in relation to their peers.
cons: Senior managers are typically not experts in their departments' core competencies. Therefore, SME employees in the department must "pitch" their ideas for projects to management, progressing slowly along a long learning curve for the manager. To make matters worse, it seems like just about the time your manager finally does "get it," he or she is whisked away to lead some other unrelated department. and the employees must train a new manager.

pros:
-Great work life balance
-Mclean and Richmond offices has good facilities - gym, showers, sauna, bike racks, access to personal trainers 2x/month
-Depending on which team you are on, work can be interesting
-People are passionate about their work
-Lateral moves within the company are easy to do after being in a role for 1 year
cons:
- Very frequent reorgs (every 2-3 years), as a result people get displaced, but company takes good care of them
- Promotion cycle is slow - even with stellar performance, the "who you know" matters for promotions - not a merit based culture
- Low employee morale due to recent cuts
- Options for international mobility are limited as the company is located in the US/UK.
- Raises are poor (1-3%), but bonus are good (remember there is a higher tax on bonuses)

job_title: Fraud Investigator in Saint Cloud, MN
pros: Great benefits. I started working there in sales in 2008. When it was still ING DIRECT. B/c of that I not only had a great 401k  (with no waiting for a year like most companies now) but I was also one of the last lucky ducks to get in on a pension.
cons: After 5 years there, I still wasn't where I wanted to be and should've been in my career there. And I was going to train for my AML test thru them but when it became Capital one 360 a lot of options for employees went bye bye.

review_title: Open culture, high volume of change
job_title: Senior Manager, Process Management in Richmond, VA
pros: Very flexible, open to different approaches of doing things.  Great work life balance.  Collaborative.  Lateral movement supported.  Leadership is constantly asking for feedback.  Great benefits.  (on-site medical center, free PT, on-site fitness center, on-site pharmacy, 15 days of backup childcare, FSA contribution matching, tons of discounts for healthy eating and living)
cons:
High level of change,  Not much continuity.  I have averaged around three manager changes each year.
Over focus on socialization and consensus building.  Very few things have clear, singular decision makers.  Default is to shop idea around and convince everyone.  While in some cases this would make sense, for more BAU work, this becomes very inefficient.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros:
In terms of balancing future career aspirations and enjoyment of your job, its hard to get better than the Business Analyst role at Capital One. There are a lot of growth opportunities, but at the same time I enjoy going to work everyday which is hard to say of my friend who have high growth potential jobs.

Additionally, the people are fantastic. Everyone is kind and intelligent which is the combination of people you want to work with. Also, just about all my co-workers really like their jobs, which is rare, and this helps foster a happy culture.

Also, it actually feels good to work for Capital One because the bank is really trying to help people, which is unusual for banks.
cons: Its a big company so things can take too long to accomplish. Additionally, there are lot of different types of Business Analyst roles, and there is the potential that you will end up in one that doesn't fit your skills or interests. That being said, Capital One is good about helping people rotate around the company

review_title: A company that goes above and beyond (Retail Direct Bank experience).
job_title: Senior Human Resources Consultant in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Great work/life balance
- Excellent maternity/paternity leave policy
- Generous PTO (and option to buy more)
- Great compensation
- Ability to make your own schedule as long as you get your work done
- Partnership with Bright Horizons near office
- Excellent managers (based on my experience)
- Great learning resources and willingness to finance external courses
- Kind colleagues and laid back work environment
- Leaders and company policies are compassionate
- Emphasis on Diversity & Inclusion
- Great office space in Seattle
cons:
- Slow moving ship at times
- Leaders lack transparency at times, are sometimes inaccessible which can be frustrating 
- We change direction quite a bit; if you're not proactively learning you get left behind (that's kind of a pro though)
- Hard to advance if you're not a manager/geographically subordinate from teams

review_title: Plenty of potential and good intentions.  Needs to mature as a corporation.
pros: Capital One does have one of the better overall compensation packages in the industry, tho' some aspects are being scaled back or eliminated (e.g., long term incentives below exec level).  Also, benefits are top notch.  There are often opportunities to work on visible and complex projects.  Casual work environment.  Working with many smart and productive colleagues.
cons: Mandatory performance management distributions make year end reviews a zero sum game, i.e., only one or two people on a team can receive the highest marks (and corresponding bonuses) even if the whole team had an outstanding year.  Downturns hit hourly and mid-level employees harder than execs.  The company still has a bit of a consultant mentality, which means people who are really good at executing projects and working hard will generally succeed.  The company is still trying to figure out how to reward people with ongoing run-the-engine jobs in a comparable manner.

review_title: Good company, but weird sense of collaboration
pros:
- Good benefits
- Fair advancement potential
- Great career-training and competency development opportunities
- Encouraging of diversity, to a large extent
cons:
- Team environments and/or project-team environments often felt very finger-pointed in nature, vs. a true sense of genuine collaboration I've seen since employed there. 
- Emphasis on perfecting weaknesses vs. fostering development of strengths.
- Certain satellite offices or sub-groups within organization don't get same bonus-perks as other teams (i.e. quarterly offsite team-building activities, etc.).

pros:
- Thorough 2 week program
- A business based on moral & excellence
- Exceptional Hiring Managers/recruiters
cons:
- Excessive thoroughness in training (almost exhausting - multiple online and in class courses that were almost pointless, redundant and so lengthy and even illegible to the point where I forgot 85% of it once I finished)
- Intake training lacks structure and capable management
- Poor technological advancement and funding in the workplace. Multiple money counters that were so old that you had to reinsert cash like 5 times to properly use. Never had this problem at Chase as they always had updated, state of the art equipment.
- Poor commandatory and interpersonal skills of management towards employees
- Online interview process was a bit excessive.

pros: If you are on a team you love, it can be great working here. The benefits are competitive, as is salary. Company likes to promote from within. There are a number of employees that have a true love for the company, and there is a heavy emphasis on the values in your day to day work.
cons:
Lots and lots of reorgs - there's a constant dread in the back of your mind about your job, especially in a support area like HR. 

The flip side to promoting from within is that nepotism exists and there isn't a true managerial training program, so a bad manager can severely derail your growth and your passion for your job.

D&I efforts seemed stagnant when I left - hoping they picked back up afterward. Lots of lip service around D&I but no true action on any initiative. I saw every person of color on the SLT leave the company or get org-ed out within my last year.

review_title: Bangalore office doesn't have a vision
pros: Decent work culture, Decent salary and benefits, free food, lot of fun activities. Good work life balance as there is no work
cons: A very poor engineering team. Senior management in engineering are not at all skilled technologists. Nobody has hands on experience and theoretical knowledge is even pathetic. Company doesnt hire skillful experience people at higher levels. As a result, all the products developed in the bangalore office looks like college projects. In contrast US managers are extremely skilled and hands on. Too much focus on presentations to impress the stakeholders who comes to visit. Almost all of the projects are dropped once the stakeholder visit is over. Also the culture and values Capital one US upholds is very different from what is seen in Bangalore office.

review_title: Smart , respectful people, respectful, but too busy & too many meetings
pros: Smart, motivated coworkers and lots of recognition/praise for a job well done. Intelligent and smart leadership, generally making good decisions. Great benefits (vacation, flex time, work from home - sometimes). Great facilities. Interesting work. Great training classes.
cons: Too much work - many at the Manager + level work 55-65 hours a week. They say they support working from home, but typically only on Fridays. Too many meetings where phone calls/emails/IM could suffice. Too many meetings mean not enough time for work. Performance management process intense and cumbersome; too complex. Expect that once you get in, you'll be at that level for 3-5 years - hard to get promoted. Not as many options for promotion/advancement as you think unless you are Sr Mgr+ and are willing to leave your line of business.

pros:
Great work life balance
Solid Benefits
Plenty of opportunity for front line associates
They care about what their associates think to a fault
cons: they feel they can pay less because they have family fall festivals or spring flings, when I say less we're talking 20% of what the market pays. I'd rather pay my bills or drive a newer car than go to some dumb outing. The DFW area is saturated with auto finance companies and COAF constantly loses talent to competition.

review_title: Great company to build a career with great benefits
job_title: AML Investigator II in New Orleans, LA
pros: Yearly bonus and pay raise available based on performance review. Great benefits with many options, a gym available on the same floor. Work from home 1-4 days a week depending on your level of progress and expertise. The senior directors are very open and honest about where the company is going and constantly touch base, provide uplifting and motivational books they've reviewed and speeches, motivate employees to speak up, dare employees to find ways to make the company better, more efficient, and effective. The company is always improving. Career advancement opportunities. Feels like a family. Did I mention work from home!?
cons: Salary is low. The new hire process is difficult (learning curve is very high and training takes 10+ weeks because everyone is so over tasked they have to give that much time to ensure the new employee can handle the work load when released into "the wild.")

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Benefits are great! They definitely feed you free food, Starting pay is ok
cons: New employees working hours are not so good. The bank shouldn't be open on sundays at least not until 10 o'clock that's a little much , management isn't that great. Some managers take management to their head. They will help the employees that they personally like. Managers aren't around to help when you need them because they are too busy socializing with eachother (probably talking about somebody). Some managers are extremely spiteful and want to get to know you on a personal level that is uncomfortable. BEWARE ! They will work together to try to get you fired if they don't like you. If you are a brown noser then this position is perfect for you. At least at this site!

review_title: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly...
pros: The benefits are great, the option to WFH is awesome too, the pay is pretty competitive and Cap 1 truly seems to care about their customers. If only they cared as much about what their employees feel as well.
cons: Not a lot of power to make the decisions we feel are appropriate. Also the time restrictions are ridiculous. We are not in elementary school anymore. I shouldn't feel like I can't go the bathroom when I NEED to, not when I'm told to. Also, when I feel I need to work on an issue for a customer, per their motto, "Do the right thing", I should have the power to do so.

review_title: Not a long term employment choice
pros: Great benefits and campus amenities.  Lots of great talent to work with on a daily basis.  Decent bonus and 401K matching up to 7.5%
cons: Salaries are not competitive with the local market.  Management plays favorites with promotions and withholds internal moves on a regular basis.  Massive re-orgs one to two times a year, plus layoffs due to closing Home Loans.  All software for internal use is developed in house and is poorly designed by people on work visas and not supported past launch - many are abandoned by the business within a year and we do internal business on spreadsheets.

review_title: Not a long term employment choice
pros: Great benefits and campus amenities.  Lots of great talent to work with on a daily basis.  Decent bonus and 401K matching up to 7.5%
cons: Salaries are not competitive with the local market.  Management plays favorites with promotions and withholds internal moves on a regular basis.  Massive re-orgs one to two times a year, plus layoffs due to closing Home Loans.  All software for internal use is developed in house and is poorly designed by people on work visas and not supported past launch - many are abandoned by the business within a year and we do internal business on spreadsheets.

review_title: Pay is good, very short term prospects
pros: The pay is good, with bonus you can exceed the "going rate."  As a tech company they are making real inroads into the cloud journey, there is something to learn there.  There is a lot said about issues of diverse hiring practices and I think those saying it mean it, no women in my department though and to the best of my knowledge never has been.
cons: Take a look at cnbc write up on Facebook dated 20190108, its description of cross calibration is excellent.  This system is used by capitalone.  So, everyone is fighting all the time.  Your job requires that others fail, indeed rewards you for causing others to fail.  The reward = cash.

review_title: Great Company -- Be wary of the expand and contract cycles
pros: The company takes excellent care of their full-time employees: good benefits, freedom to fail fast and experiment, open to new ideas, changes very fast (can also be a con depending on how you deal with change), proactive in training, opportunities to attend in-house conferences with industry leaders, great facilities and offices.
cons: Life at the company is very fast paced, almost hectic sometimes (granted, depending on role), and change happens so quickly that it can require some fancy footwork to keep up. The company also tends to function in cycles where they will hire many new employees and 6-12 months later let a large group go. It's a good place to be if you can keep on top of change and avoid the layoff cycles.

review_title: CapOne is pretending to be ‘a tech company that happens to be a bank’!!
job_title: Director, Data Engineering in Chicago, IL
pros:
- Competitive salary and benefits in particular 6% 401K matching
- Flexibility to work from home
- Flexibility in internal work mobility
cons:
- Frequent organizational changes and redeployments leading to employee frustration and lost of productivity
- Too many unproductive meetings with no time left for core work!
- Forced distribution performance management system creating infighting and ‘lick boots’ culture.

review_title: The best place to work in Nottingham
job_title: Senior Technical Programmer Manager in Nottingham, England
pros:
Great people, projects, technology, workplace, restaurant and work life balance.
Friendly, collaborative people. High aspirations. Exciting initiatives. Some departments promote staff rapidly e.g. Marketing, Software Engineering
The CEO, Rich Fairbank, is genuinely inspirational. He talks to the company every year, at length, about his vision and strategy, and while this can go on a bit it is ultimately worthwhile that we share in the knowledge of where we are going and why.
cons:
Capital One UK is only a very small part of Capital One Financial and can sometimes get left behind. There is a reticence to enter new markets e.g. loans, banking, etc. C1 UK is stuck as a mono-line credit card business.
Some departments can be very slow to promote internally, e.g. Operations, Tech Ops.
A lot of attrition in some departments e.g. Software Engineering.

pros: Great PTO, decent pay, and great benefits.
cons: Due to all the changes, there is no room for growth. There are only 3 positions now on retail side branch ambassador, multi branch ambassador, and multi branch manager. Branches are understaffed having to work with 3 associates majority of the time which causes overwhelming amount of work. Managers work at multiple branches now and will have you travel to the branches they manage to help out staffing without paying you for travel or as a multi-branch ambassador despite you working outside your home branch. Systems are down every other day. Your only solution to most customer problems have to be done through a submission of a work request what they refer to as TRIPS or by contacting an internal support line known as BASL. The retail side has dramatically went downhill within the past 3-5 months

pros: Industry leading benefits, good pay and educational opportunities
cons:
Performance management is based on all managers getting in a room and rating all employees into a forced distribution.  The bottom will probably get fired, the top get big bonuses and are more likely to get promoted.

As you climb the management ladder its foolish to promote others to your level who are more competenant than you, lest you drop in the distribution.  Promoting good people could literally cost you money.

There is a ridiculous amount of back biting and upstaging. Also... the layoffs! 1000s of people every year.  You can learn a lot hear, but dont stay long unless you want to become toxic.

pros: The people I work with are great. The main focus is customer service, which makes the job less stressful. Benefits are great. You will learn so much on the job. You have a chance to show your leadership skills and make your self stand out. Its really up to you in how well you do. Capital One loves engagement. Everyone is extremely helpful. You will learn something new everyday. If you like to research how to do things, this job is for you. Capital One helps you with your personal brand and provide you with many resources to help your career. I can say that the branch ambassador roll will prepare you for many roles and is a great stepping stone for almost any career in banking.
cons: Short staffing, you literally do everything in the branch from servicing atms, processing teller transactions, to opening accounts, which can be a bit much at times. No room for real growth in retail banking unless you work at the corporate offices in Mclean VA.

review_title: Good job, although not as fast changing as they claim.
pros:
Overall Capital One provides a good, stable work environment. Many of the projects are interesting and at times, challenging. Your colleagues are typically very talented and of the same mindset. It may take time, but problematic employees will be managed out.

Benefits, PTO and Work/Life balance are strong pluses for a corporate or professional role. I cannot comment for our call centers and front line roles.
cons:
Legacy Capital One is very  much stuck in the old days and it creates this weird divide between the new arrivals and old guard. This divide helps slow down the company as some groups resist change. Although, this seems to be continually improving.

Invest some more money in Downtown DC, local growth is Fairfax-centric and we are missing a large chunk of our local talent pool.

review_title: Great place to work but no place is perfect
job_title: Lead Software Engineer in Richmond, VA
pros: Capital One prides itself on having a great work life balance and I can confirm that they offer flexible work schedules, good leave packages, and have very understanding leadership in this space.  The people are generally smart, talented, and committed to doing the right thing.
cons: There is a middle management culture of consensus based decisioning that drives down certain teams and individuals potential.  This stifles innovation, reduces speed, and leads to a feeling of distrust and lack of autonomy within teams.  For a company that sells itself as "being agile" this is something that many people find difficult.

pros: Great coworker employees to work with and lots of learning opportunities.
cons:
Per several managers, 80% of Capital One employees are contractors.  When there is a layoff, full time employees (FTE) are laid off first followed by contractors.

Many new managers do not have mortgage or auto financing work experience or understanding and are hired just to increase productivity.  As we all know, each account may have conditions or issues that may take longer to resolve than others and sometimes each person will always have different numbers for the day.  If Quantity is the priority, Quality is diminished and maintaining a balance of each will always be difficult.

pros:
The Company truly lives their values. I have access to endless resources to better myself and my career. My leaders value my work, and spend extra time helping me develop my skills. As a result, I have been promoted every year.

I would argue that the re-orgs people are complaining about in other reviews create great opportunities if you are the proactive type. If you are comfortable coming in and piking it, the re-orgs will certainly upset your comfort level.

Top leadership is very forward thinking and has clear goals that get communicated to us by Rich himself, in person, once a year.
cons:
While the re-orgs can create opportunities, it does sometimes disrupt best practices in place, and as a large organization it can be difficult to correct in a timely manner.

Much like any large company, Some tasks can be overly cumbersome.

review_title: above all this is still a sales environment
pros: the corporate philosophy is to let one advance and achieve without hindrance.  Fast growing company.  Keep in mind this is still a sale organization.  sales are the key to success.
cons: help is not always available to solve problems,  the "figure it out" plan does not always work.  when someone falters they are then left on their own.  there are  5-6 different software programs that do not talk to each other and are not user friendly thus constant repeating same info.    learning curve on software is very quick  but it is the foundation of everything else.  Despite the "corporate line" of doing what's best for the customer, one is required to intensely question all customers to uncover new sales opportunities, even if they just want a simple transaction.  Customers hate this.  corporate environment is totally different than   sitting in a bank

pros: Incredible flexibility.  Talent is amazing and I love learning new things every day from my teams.  Lost of horizontal movement and chance to learn new parts of the business with the growth.
cons: With the constant change of a fast moving organization, it isn't uncommon to have 2, 3 or even 4 supervisors in a year making it nearly impossible to get promoted if you aren't an data analyst or a non-exempt employee because no one is around long enough to learn your name, much less advocate for you during performance management cycles because they are only there for one.

review_title: Good compensation and smart people, but no job security.
pros: Good compensation and smart people are the reason people come to Capital One and the reason people stay at Capital One.  The company recruits from top schools throughout the country (and the world), and invests heavily in professional development.  In general, the company does a lot of the right things for employees -- allows working from home, good benefits (which don't increase in cost by 10%+ every year), fair severance (historically), etc.
cons: Job security is virtually non-existent.  Growth is gone, which makes it difficult to advance as senior managers protect their kingdoms instead of take on risks.  Performance reviews and bonuses are driven more by tenure and politics than the company's managers would like to admit, and HR has a long track record of blunders when trying to address these problems.

review_title: Too much work, not enough pay
pros: Good people for the most part.  My group tries to have flexible work days and telecommuting but there just doesn't seem to be 100% buy-in by Sr. Mgmt.  Lots of responsibility if you want it.
cons: Culture can be difficult to get used to.  Pay is well below similar positions at other companies and benefits are more costly.  Lots of technical issues even though they claim to be tech savvy.  My area is very production oriented so there isn't much work/life balance.  Not enough time in the day to get all the work done.  Not enough vacation time for mid-career hires but it doesn't really matter when most managers and above end up working most of their vacations.

review_title: Great place to work, but check group turnover before accepting a position
pros: Challenging, team - oriented environment.  Great place to learn and develop critical skills, including effective communication and consensus - driven decision making.  Senior management team is exceptional and the reason I joined the company.
cons: Quality of life differs significantly from team to team.  Before accepting a position with Capital One, try to learn promotion timing and turnover data for your prospective team.  It was striking to me how in one department, associates on two teams had entirely different experiences.

review_title: Still a bank, not a technology company
job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Management is taking some steps in the right direction to become more technology forward. Capital One also has the funds to move in that direction, and has an overall good company vision. Overall work environment was also inviting, and balanced.
cons: Unfortunately, implementation of the technology bank vision is poor. The company is wasting money hiring way too many engineers at a low bar. These engineers are then managed by non-technical managers for projects that are then randomly killed with poor leadership synchronization.

pros: Great Employee Benefits, excellent retirement, 401K match level is the best
cons:
The company claims to do what's in the best interest of customers and moving towards more of a planning environment. In reality it's very high pressured sales environment and very transactional. Only the final number matters, not the customer. For this, they always threaten to fire employees. No job security.

There is no effort to promote women in the Financial Advisement position, it's a boy's club. So to women looking to work as a financial adviser at Capital One, be prepared for unequal opportunity.  
Compensation Sucks - In the 2 years I spent with the company, Compensation structure changed 3 times, to structures that tightened the ability to earn a higher income.

co-workers are very friendly, very a great team environment, but not when it matters so beware - everyone protect themselves - no one stands up for the other when they should.

review_title: Apply for part time teller position
job_title: Part-Time Teller (Hopefully! Still Waiting!) in New Orleans, LA
pros: Discount on my tuition offered through my University.  Capital One has tuition reimbursement benefits.  I can start at an entry level position and work my way up as I further my education.  Several branches nationwide allow me to relocate when I decide to.  Benefits for part-time positions as well as full-time.   Capital One was voted one of the best places to work.
cons: Hourly pay is not that great starting out, but the other benefits outweigh the cons.  A part-time position will be great while I finish school.

job_title: Senior Ops Coord- Reposession Department/Loss Mitigation/Recoveries in Plano, TX
pros: The pay is good at COAF. There are several great managers in the corporation and also really great oppurtunities to move up within the company.
cons: Like most companies immediate managers have a great deal of power over their associates or workers. Here there is too much power given to managers and also so many changes being made without the proper training being provided. They will hold you accountable even had they not provided the proper training to you. I have also seen people fired for personal reasons between a manager and employee. Not a great example of ethical responsibilityffrom a manager. The turn over is more consistant then it was 4 years ago with all the changes in the company and also the people that are being hired for entry positions are alot less professional then 4 years ago.

pros: In the Home loans business, the enviornment is a little different than the rest of the company, given the growing challenges and the market situation. There are udgetary and resourcing pressures, but the quality of the workforce is exceptional. most people live the values of the company and everyone is expected to be a complete owner of the task/process/project they are a part of. Feebacks are welcome and irrespective of your job level ideas are socialized and heard.
cons: Stress and resource bandwidth availability might be a challenege in lot of groups, mainly because there is a lot to do and the Home Loans business in its current place is losing a lot of money. Department politics and constant re-organizations can weigh in to the stress levels a lot of times. Also, due to all of these the longevity of any set oout strategy becomes questionable over a longer period of time.

review_title: Not as attractive as it's sold to be
job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros:
Strong organizational culture, which can be great, but not so great too
Strong belief in corporate values
Tries to be the bank that does what's right for it's customers 
Great organization for low level and mid-level professionals
cons:
Lack of job opportunities, growth and promotions
Performance Management process is horrible and very biased
non-competitive pay 
Insular organization full of home-grown talent. Org does not do well when top external talent is brought in 
Lacks creativity. Feels it's cutting edge, but is really behind large, global banks in terms of creativity, design and ideation.

pros:
Overall
    - Medical, 401k match and employee stock program
    - Learned how to work in a cut throat enviroment and keep my morals.

Plano, TX 
   - Great in office eats

SanFrancisco, CA 
    - Free Snacks
    - Nice office layout
cons:
CapitalOne is so political with people willing to stab anyone in the back to move up in the company. After my 6+ years of service I have seen almost everything.

- Forced distribution at year end performance reviews. 
- Every 3 - 6 months leadership changes.
- There is a massive layoff of people who are 40 years old and older. I heard that 3% attrition was "too low" for tech companies. So leadership wants 8% attrition. 
- People in San Francisco are very under paid.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mc Lean, VA
pros:
- It's a laid back environment as compared to other financial institutions.
-  Depending with the Manager, you have the opportunity to do teleworking as much as you can as long as you get the work done
- It's an environment that encourages innovation and engenuity
cons:
- Promotion is very subjective and political depending on where you work
- Some middle level managers do not seem to have any leadership experience or training at all.
- There is a certain population within the bank that lacks basic common courtesies: please, thank you, or excuse me. That was shocking and that was very disappointing to experience in the Corporate environment????

review_title: Fake tech company but decent place to work
pros:
- Good compensation (competitive salary + benefits)
- Positive and easygoing people
- Lots of social/fun activities
- Good work/life balance
cons:
- Pretends to be a top tier tech company but far from it. Also doesn't pay like one.
- Tech is mediocre at best. Code quality is low because often they just want to get it out of the door asap.
- Agile done all wrong. Lots of rituals/formalities but the spirit is not there.
- Collaboration between teams/departments is poor
- Canada tech team often bottlenecked by US teams/policies
- Senior management (director+) is nearly all white
- Too bureaucratic

pros: Great colleagues, competitive salary/bonus/benefits, downtown location
cons: Frequent and disruptive org changes and leadership changes, some roles (analysts) receive systemic preferential treatment while everyone else is second class, deeply flawed performance management process, only product is a credit card - no innovation or growth

review_title: Great job but strict attendance policies and bank rules
pros: Its a great environment everyone is friendly there. The cafeteria food is amazing and cheap. They have 5 by 8 shift schedules or 4 by 10 which is convenient. Job wasn't extremely hard. Also do incentives and they feed you ALOT and have a lot of extra activities and volunteer things. Amazing benefits, had a doctors office and a gym in building.
cons: Have to be careful what you say on the phone its easy to get a reg or a BI which can make you lose your bonus. Their 90 day probation is extremely strict miss 2 days or late past 3 minutes you're out. Then if you're fired for attendance youre not allowed to be rehired even if you had an excused absence.

job_title: Senior Business Manager in McLean, VA
pros: Capital One has an incredible dedication to your personal and career development. Senior leadership spends significant time coaching, mentoring, etc. They are very supportive of rotations to various parts of the company to continue to learn new areas and skills even at the expense of efficiency at times.
cons: The culture and type of work has shifted over time as the bank has grown. The company used to always be about growth/innovation and had retained part of its start up culture roots for a long time. More recently the focus has shifted to mostly regulatory/compliance and well managed work and the culture has gotten a bit stuffier. That being said its still an amazing place to work and to launch a career.

review_title: Good Company for the Right Fit
pros: Great company for recent grads that network well. This is a very promising opportunity for individuals with a strong Capital One centric network before joining the company.
cons: (Richmond Campus) Company creates an extremely cut throat environment that favors cookie cutter behavior.  Capital One definitely favors individuals in their 20’s that can be groomed to fit their corporate behavior. Unfortunately Capital One favors and promotes individuals based on relationships (i.e. family members, church members, close friends) with established Associates. Also there are frequent shifts in management (new Manager approximately every 6 months to a year). Capital One is a very different company since its early innovative years, but still successful.

review_title: Very poor management of service levels and a culture of shaming
pros: Its easy to get hired on at the COAF call center near Tulsa Oklahoma and the insurance is good.
cons:
The COAF management cant figure out how to manage service levels in the customer care call center. 
And there is a strange culture of shaming that they think drives performance. Every employees individual statistics are posted on boards around the Tulsa call center. The poor performers are humiliated and shamed because their metrics are highlighted in red. The young generally uneducated managers that COAF hires think this practice drives better performance but all it does is demoralize employees. Even the best employees have bad months and their hard work is rewarded with shaming. It is very sad that such a large organization has such a basic lack of understanding of how to motivate and drive better performance.

review_title: Generally great culture, rapid management changes
pros:
- Generally great culture, very open, fun events, free swag and food
- Investment in education
- Great pay when comparing to similar positions on the market
- Work from home option
- Employee stock plan has no vesting period
- Employer matched RRSP contributions are really good
- Generally really good hiring process that weeds out individuals without the appropriate technical skills
- They actually fire people who are not performing to keep up a high performance level
cons:
- Hiring process is long and slow with many steps
- Lots of change in upper management results in a very dynamic and not so enjoyable work environment
- Some departments not as good to work for as others.  Data analyst team is great; finance team is not so great
- Not a lot of room to move up within Canada, although there are lots of opportunities in the US and particularly Richmond, Virginia

job_title: Master Software Engineer in McLean, VA
pros: Good benefits, flexible work options, great severance package.
cons: Highly political environment and managers are like clan leaders. A very hierarchical environment. COF wants to portray as a cutting edge technology company, while the core business is financial services. Everyone is after the "coolness factor" and just hop on buzzwords like cloud, big data, devops etc. and there is too much talk and no much output.  Changes are too frequent, and layoffs at unexpected time, when you think the company is doing great. Recently, management thinks software programming is the only great job and wants all IT folks to do coding work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mc Lean, VA
pros: Company as a whole is very employee focused and takes care of there employee. They provide training when required and when it is in the best interest of the associate. Most managers take of their team ensure they have everything they need to be successful.
cons: Some managers within Capital One are the same as other companies. All projects need to get done ahead of schedule regardless of the complexity or lack of valid requirements. The thought is to just put something out there so it can be said it is done and hope it doesn't cause a SEV 1 incident and causing major rework to repair applications that do not work well.  These managers have a detrimental affect on employee work / life balance.

pros: no workload. great benefits. great training programs, nice work life balance. no sales goals. stress free job.
cons: hard to get promoted. system is crappy. call themselves a tech company but their systems are useless. crash all the time. and with those kinds of system they expect you to please customers and get good surveys. pay is not good. probably good compared to other banks but not really a good compensation.

job_title: Summer Financial Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: The company has an outstanding work-life balance with very generous benefits, and any time spent working unusually-long hours is often compensated for at a later date. Richmond campus is a spectacular environment that blows most offices out of the water. Summer internship program was engaging and very well-run; the full-time employees almost made us feel like family. The work was very stimulating given that it was an internship, and I was able to see how my work over the summer positively affected my team.
cons: HR is a bureaucratic black hole; I received my signing bonus 4 months after I was supposed to. Performance feedback could have been much better, and HR and team management had numerous miscommunications. In addition, the business as a whole is highly cyclical, so keep that in mind if job security is a primary factor in your decision.

job_title: Fraud Recovery Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Decent benefits, medical, dental  and vacation available from day one. Excellent 401k employer match program and of course five day work week in fraud recovery
cons: The cons, job specifics has changed a great deal from investigating fraud to simply providing customer service to repeat cardholders and/ or would be fraudsters. The pay isn't enough for those with various backgrounds in the financial industry. The year appraisal end process for associate is based strictly on personal opinion and favoritism to managers. Some associates are promoted to other roles of recovery while others are stuck and not provided with support and coaching needed to succeed.

pros: Capital One has a great employee benefits package and has multiple ways of keeping employees happy to work hard and to increase morale. If you have an idea that will increase productivity, unlike many employers Capital One will listen, and if the idea is feasible will quickly put it into place.  Quarterly fun days are paid days where your team leaves the work site for lunch and a fun event or team building exercises.  Lunches are often provided, holidays are paid time off or extra pay if worked and morale boosting events and rallys happen monthly. Medical, dental, optical and retirement benefits are offered as well as discounts to local events.
cons: There are many opportunities for promotion within Capital One, but there is also a lot of competition from coworkers to fill these positions.

pros: The benefits are some of the best in the industry even with the change of vendors.  401K is really awesome with up to a 7 and 1/2 percent match. There are cafes, cafeterias, gyms, onsite doctors and much more on each campus.  They focus on being well and depending on the position you hold, work/life balance can be a reality.
cons: Advancement opportunities, promotions and recognition are majority based on favoritism/popularity.  Leadership is moved around when they are not performing but lower levels are replaced.  People are told to get their name and face out there to be promoted, recognized and advanced but not given opportunities to do so.

review_title: A company filled with smart people who strive to bring humanity to the financial world
pros:
Vision: Capital One’s mission to Change Banking for Good really resonates with me. A company where the bottom line is not the only consideration in business decisions and where there’s a genuine commitment to bringing humanity to banking.

Culture: A respectful, passionate and collaborative environment that works towards a unifying vision to Change Banking for Good. 

Design Team: An aspiring leader who has built a fully-rounded team of passionate experts who champion the user and good design across the business. 

Facilities: Beautiful and spacious new offices at the White Collar Factory in London with an abundance of quirky places to work and collaborate with others, either face-2-face or remotely via the Surface Hubs that are located throughout the office and meeting rooms.  I’m especially excited by our purpose built, in-house Research Lab which we use to gather insights about our customers and evaluate products in development.
cons: Dogs: I miss taking my dog to work :(

review_title: Sounded like a good idea at the time.
job_title: Senior Process Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Work life balance. Flexibility to work from home. 401K match. Potential for significant salary increases at EOY based on Board of Directors.
cons: No transparency from changing leadership. Performance management is entirely contingent on your direct manager so if they are inexperienced or lack leadership skills, consider yourself screwed. Based on the rating system, associates are self interested and will withhold information from teammates in order to make themselves look good. The company claims they are diverse but they spend an insane amount of money sending leadership to classes and when they come back nothing has changed. Difficult to move departments because there are so many layoffs. No incentive to go above and beyond because there is no recognition unless you beg for it. Misogynistic attitude from the top down. The higher level associate, the greater chance of them acting like you don’t exist. If you are a head-down, get things done kind of a person, this is not the place for you.

review_title: A great two years out of college
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: This is a great place to start working out of college.  There are a lot of young people around to meet and network with, everyone I've worked with has been collegial and willing to help me learn.  New analysts get to work on real business problems right away and can get heard right away if they prove themselves.  There is also a real emphasis on work/life balance and senior management seems to really mean it.  Nice benefits package too.
cons: Capital One has hired a lot of very smart people, which sometimes means that things are way more complicated than they should be.  Recent acquisitions means that some parts of the company feel more disjointed than others.  There is constant turnover as people rotate around to different teams- good if you like change but it sometimes can be overwhelming plus you lose institutional knowledge.

review_title: Fantastic work-life balance, if you are willing to do the sales grind.
pros:
Work-life balance is phenominal, they want employees to be rested and have a life
Constantly training so you are not doing this alone
Great sense of district-wide comradory and competition
Management seems to only get on your case if you are failing to actually work
Capital One really strives to be a different kind of bank, it's fun to watch the company constantly evolve
cons:
Several different systems needed to perform daily functions will drive you crazy
Don't have down-time to catch up on the mountains of paperwork
Interdepartment collaboration is non existant, everybody uses a different system
Your "big money" success depends on your business and investment partners, if you have a good one they will help you, if you have lazy ones you will absolutely fail

review_title: Great Company overall, tough year end review
job_title: Testing Specialist, Senior in Tysons Corner, VA
pros: Working in IT -- all my colleagues & managers are very bright, nice, and a pleasure to work with. There are endless company sponsored trainings that management highly encourages us to take. We are provided with all the top end resources and technology for IT & software development.
cons: The number 1 complaint across the board by all employees is the year end employee review process. Most companies, you are graded based on your individual performance alone. Here, you are placed into a pool of people of your employee level (Associate, Senior Associate, Manager, etc.), and then senior management has meetings ranking all the people in the pool. People who do good work, sometimes end up low in a ranking which seems unfair and is why so many people complain. The higher your rank, the higher your bonus.

pros: The health benefits, salary and bonus structure are superior to most in the market. The working environment is casual and comfortable. Its conveniently located to the Tollway. There are some very intelligent hardworking people who make the company successful.
cons: The way the departments are set up, someone has to die before advancement can happen. Or, you must have a close relationshiop with the VP or senior management to advance. Many unqualified people were promoted based on friendships rather than ability to do the job well. The intelligent and hardworking people are the ones carrying the company, but usually with little chance to advance within one department. Associates have a better chance at advancement by leaving the department they currently work for and transferring to another. Some even leave the company to advance and then return at a higher level.

review_title: Good pay but culture is not for everyone
pros:
The pay is good and the people are nice if they don't know your level.
The culture is flexible to accommodate a healthy work life balance.
cons:
Horrible prejudicial culture when it comes to employee levels and heavy hierarchical structure. 

People will refuse to talk to you once they know you are a lower level coworker which hinders on work productivity. I once worked on something that had been terminated but was not informed due to my lower status, this wasted my time and effort. I would not recommend Capital One if you prefer a classless culture that promotes team work.

review_title: Great pitch not so great follow through
job_title: Call Center Agent in Richmond, VA
pros: Great place to work with many perks, Some really good managers and co-workers. Work can be fun and challenging which can make the day fly by.
cons:
If you are over 50 watch out they will find some way to get rid of you even if you are a high performer. Benefits are like golden handcuffs hard to think about leaving a dead end job when you have them. 
Management is a mixed bag you have to hope you get a good one. Many manager have been promoted due to time with company and have no people skills or if they do are forced to focus on the bottom line and not the people.
If you like long hours and little praise this is the company for you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Cloud, MN
pros: Great benefits package, great managers and coaches, competitive salaries, but since the acquisition of ING Direct things changed dramatically. I would still recommend people to work here, but I couldn't guarantee the length of time the position might last although  admitedly they do treat everyone very well upon departure.
cons: When it was ING Direct associates treated like individuals, upper management knew our names,  goals, and had personal conversations with us. Since the acquisition associates are treated as just an employee number, and the corporate greed for money is leading to cutting entire departments across the nation.  It doesn't matter if our entire team had a decade and more of experience per person, with top notch skills and work ethics, they were eliminated anyway.

pros: 401k, time off, remote work, travel
cons:
Performance management is just a fancy word for high school popularity contest. They dont promote the best but instead focus on those who are seen (as in sit in the office with the VP of the team). 

The pay is not competitive when compared to other banks and "other tech companies", they need get better comparison methods and stop being stingy. The only way to move up salary wise is via promotion, which is hard to attain no matter what level you are.

Meetings for meeting sake, they love that here.

Non value add middle level management. The company is filled with incompetent people throughout the manager to sr director level, hire outside consultants to get rid of the waste.

review_title: If you can eat, sleep and breath Capital One Auto Finance, you may be successful.
pros: The medical benefits are pretty good if you are someone that does not have a lot of medical problems. The yearly incentive for managers can be several thousand dollars. Most front line managers are starting to get laptops. You also get 401k matching, tuition reimbursement, discounted stock, and a decent amount of vacation time.
cons: Managers rarely get praise and recognition for their work. Promotions usually go to those who fit a particular mold or who are good friends with upper management. You have to live at work to get a decent yearly bonus. They are all about numbers and less about customer service and doing the right thing. They will skip on making on process right if they can tweak it for cheap.

review_title: If you can eat, sleep and breath Capital One Auto Finance, you may be successful.
pros: The medical benefits are pretty good if you are someone that does not have a lot of medical problems. The yearly incentive for managers can be several thousand dollars. Most front line managers are starting to get laptops. You also get 401k matching, tuition reimbursement, discounted stock, and a decent amount of vacation time.
cons: Managers rarely get praise and recognition for their work. Promotions usually go to those who fit a particular mold or who are good friends with upper management. You have to live at work to get a decent yearly bonus. They are all about numbers and less about customer service and doing the right thing. They will skip on making on process right if they can tweak it for cheap.

pros:
The company loves to explore new technology (Big Data...etc) and embrace new ideas. 
Great benefits and a family balance.  They love to recruit from colleges, and there is a sign on bonus.
cons: The annual calibration process is painful. You need to have a strong manager who will fight for you otherwise you will get the crumbs.  Annual merit increases are small (2% - 4%). Lots of politics... Lots of offshore resources - which may or may not be a bad thing. If you do come to work at Capital One - get as much money upfront, and make sure that the group you are slanted to work in will actually be there when you start (too many re-orgs and restructuring). .  Their

job_title: Relationship Manager in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Overall great company good benefits and as a whole great culture... I truly love what I do!
cons: Even though benefits are great, insurance is a bit expensive. Have worked here for several years and one of the lowest paid. We are only a number here and truly hold no value to the company. We were told they would rather hire new employees than to invest in current employees. A lot of favoritism, very obvious. If you are not a favorite no chance for advancement. Work life balance is not what they preach especially if you are on the lowered end of the pay scale, you have to work longer hours to even compare to your peers. New employees are hired paid at a minimum of 10k more with no experience what so ever and trained by those how are paid less?

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
+ A great salary, benefits package, and bonus.
+ A good learning opportunity. You'll be challenged to learn a lot, fast.
+ A distributed team ( most team members telecommuted 100% ).
+ Smart, professional co-workers with a sense of humor.
+ A not-so-messy Perl codebase with lots of tests.
+ A mature Agile process, which helps teams functional well.
+ Emphasis on documentation, so there are written procedures for doing some complex tasks.
+ New initiative to automate as much as possible ( example: minimal manual QA ).
+ Lunch-and-Learn sessions, in which a speaker gives a presentation during lunch.
cons: - Too many communication tools ( email, multiple flavors of IM, multiple ways of doing voice chat, video conferencing, screen shares, and pair programming, message boards, wiki, Slack, etc. ), which sometimes cause communication to go haywire.

pros: Good benefits, forward leaning technology-wise, intelligent and rational decision making on a larger scale
cons: Stack rankings means that your #1 priority at all times is to NOT be in the bottom 15% of your cohort.  This has little to do with your talent, it has (in order of importance) to do with 1) Your manager's political power 2) Your visibility to your manger's peers and skips 3) Your job performance.  Beware!  At review time, the knives come out, and if you haven't positioned yourself properly, you will NOT get the bonus the recruiter promised you, and you'll have a black mark next to your name.

pros: Technology was good. Worked with amazing colleagues & partners from other departments; many fired or pushed out.
cons: Job security!. Excessive amounts of people fired and/or placed on corrective action; reason given was for not being able to reach unattainable goals. Poor support from district managers: More interested in promoting themselves & protecting their jobs than supporting their teams. Toxic & negative environment.

review_title: Political but lots of learning opportunities
pros: There is big community of statisticians/data scientists, and lots of training opportunities including courses offered by internal guru or from outside like SAS.
cons: Very political. An individual manager was very mean to his direct reports while being very nice to people at higher ranks or his peers. The turnover rate is very high. In order to push ranking of the employees in his/her own team, managers or directors kept attacking employees in different group, even bringing it up to performance if an employee sent out an email earlier than set up, which did not cause any issue except sending it out earlier. Quote from a previous reviewers " It is a place of dog eating dog." Was not able to take any vacation in one year.

pros: The benefits of working her are great. There's a great Work/Life balance. Salary is average but it's topped up with a great package such as Life Insurance, Health Insurance (plus family!), Travel to Work schemes, Subsidised restaurant (Notts only),  free Tea and Coffee and a good amount of holidays. The pension is also unbeatable!
cons:
You may find it hard to progress if you don't 'Play the game'. The people who discuss your progress could have absolutely no interest or scope of your work, so you can get stuck at a position for years despite working above and beyond your role.

The benefit package is so good that you'll struggle to find a suitable paying job elsewhere.

pros: Excellent benefits including  100% mass transit subsidy,  7 1/2% 401k match and gym membership.   Good upward mobility provided you take the initiative to make your career goals known  and you of course remain in good standing in your current role.   For a financial firm, they readily embraced new technologies so your skills stayed relevant and things stayed interesting.
cons:
I have witnessed an associate's attempt to move between departments thwarted due to the existing manager's negative comments.  I understand the importance of a manager's feedback but in this case I felt the negativity was more personal then professional.  
I worked in the Seattle office which was a small division and it was easy to feel a bit alienated from the much larger campuses where the major decisions were made.

review_title: Toxic, backward-thinking, badly managed digital division in the Chicago area
pros: Solid benefits, some excellent Scrum Masters and Engineers who are not properly leveraged.
cons: Management creates a toxic workplace. The twice yearly review process discourages teamwork and kills morale by forcing managers to put 20% or more of their reports on a performance plan or terminiating them. This is no way to create a good work environment or culture. Promotions are subject to cronyism and engineers are encouraged to look out only for themselves. Valuable, high-performing engineers are not developed or promoted. With the recent Chicago lay-off announcements, morale is terrible. It seems like the Virginia offices are better places to work, but steer clear of the Chicago and Rolling Meadows locations if you are looking for a safe workplace. There is no opportunity there.

review_title: Great place when I started however has lost moral significantly
job_title: Senior Advocacy Coordinator in London, England
pros: Pay is great, bonus structure, co-workers are awesome, great benefits and vacation
cons: Trainers suck (my initial trainers were great, however after they left it went down hill) and can't answer any questions when asked, team manager is NEVER around to assist,  continue to push for OT but don't have any incentives for employees who do, Floor walkers treat you as if you are stupid when you ask a question, QAs are usually done within the last week and a half causing no roo. To improve scores in order to bonus higher, Manager never used team budget while other managers teams had team outings and food catered in almost monthly

job_title: Master Software Engineer in Manchester, England
pros: The resources of an Enterprise.  Why do people rob banks, right?  So the cash compensation—including signing bonus—is great.  Strongly run relative to other large entities that make money from usury (banks, credit cards)... just look at how C1 recovered from 2008 financial crisis vs Wells Fargo or Bank of America.  Stable and I think recession-proof job.
cons: For a software engineer, things are bogged down.  Use of AWS Cloud especially.  And just so much process, anonymous systems sending emails demanding compliance, etc.  They self insure, so can't get Kaiser in the Bay Area.

pros: Benefits are really great.  Capital One as a company encourages work/life balance and is rated high for working moms and working parents.  Working from home is popular and they have many great volunteer activities and events to make it a great place to work.
cons: Do your research and ask what the maximum salary is for the level below the one you are applying for or you may be underpaid.  Some managers are really bad and don't want to be there as they have been with the company for 15-20 years or since the company started.  If you get a bad manager it will be hard to transfer into new roles or get the support and development you need.  Although, the company as a whole supports work/life balance, there are some individual managers who do not which sucks.  There is also a lot of turnover.

pros:
- Great people to work with
- Most departments are very well organized
- Easy to advance and cross-train in other departments
- Decent pay and work-life balance
- Lots of training/learning opportunities
- Benefits are top-notch
- Many opportunities to bond with colleagues (social committees are well-run and organized)
- The company's LGBTQ+ outreach efforts are surprisingly good for a corporation, and I think other companies should take Capital One's lead in advocating for the LGBTQ+ community
cons: This is my opinion, and mine alone: the method used to review, promote, and award raises is outdated and not based on merit, but a "bell curve" approach. Basically, employees with the same title are compared to each other (whether or not the actual work they do is in any way similar), and there are only enough "slots" for a certain number of folks to get a particular rating level. It's an ineffective and absurd method of evaluating people.

review_title: For the first time I am able to say I love my job!
job_title: Lead User Experience Designer in London, England
pros:
Capital One has invested greatly in the working environment with the new offices in the White Collar Factory right on Old Street roundabout. This provides a fantastic working environment both inside and outside the office.

The culture is great and not like other banks. Flexible working is available and well utilised by the team.

The organisation is investing in design and the mission to change banking for good is evident and clearly present.

The work is challenging and innovative which makes coming to work exciting and highly rewarding.
cons:
The disconnect between the Nottingham and London office can be a little frustrating. However the way technology is adopted in the business its made less painful. 

The interview process was a bit daunting but its clear that it works to create a great overall team.

Salary, whilst competitive is on the low side but to be fair the other benefits and opportunity for progression are up for grabs.

review_title: Excellent company, takes care of employees, hires many talented engineers
pros:
- Very smart and talented people
- Management is open and promotes positive work-life balance
- Pays well and exceptional benefits. Incredible 401k match
- Leadership prioritizes innovation and learning new things
- Great company culture
cons: - Sometimes the projects don't have the most interesting business need, but that can be expected at times no matter where you work.

pros: Capital One has become one of the most successful banks in country because of the dedicated and smart associates and the innovation of its Founder and CEO. The company does not stand still, nor does anyone who works there. It is not a bank culture and never has been. Don't look to work here if you aren't ready to be a part of - or frankly, think of, the next innovative idea in how people think about money!!
cons: The culture is fast-paced, and you have to be willing to work hard, catch on to new trends quickly and think ahead of the curve. If not, you may be shown the door, or find it yourself! The company takes care of its people, though, even those it decides to let go.

review_title: Sr. Leaders Are Too Far Removed
pros:
-Ability to work remote in most exempt roles
-Jeans, all.the.time.
-Quite a lot of development opportunities
-If on a main campus, tons of discounted food options & doctor & gym
-Lean mindset
-Solid benefits & PTO/sick time
cons:
-Like most businesses, the bottom line is still important.
-Being great at your job skills isn't enough.
--Mgmt wants you to sip the sauce, be the culture, contribute to the community, etc.
-Upper-level managers rarely get in the weeds with you, but make major decisions that impact you.
-A little cult-ish

review_title: Not a place that looks after its people
pros: The people are very smart and very open, which provides a great consensus building environment. This is great for broadening your own knowledge and developing your skills.
cons: The big reason to work at somewhere like Capital One is work life balance. Take the lower salary and avoid all the pain Wall St hours. It's not like that at Capital One. They work you to exhaustion and undercompensate you. That might work OK if they looked after their staff, but they tend to treat you like a possession and pay no mind to your own career preferences.

pros: Capital One takes very good care of their employees. The incredible benefits (stock purchase plan gives you extra 15% free, 7.5% extra towards 401k if you put in 6%, focus on professional development, generous travel expensing, incredible amenities, etc.) alone make Capital One a great company to work for. Plus the business analyst role pays like a Big 3 analyst role, but hours are closer to 45 a week. The people are super nice but also brilliant, and a lot of special attention is put into the business analyst program. You also learn a lot through tons of hands on experience-- not a ton of just sitting around on the job.
cons: The company is constantly changing/developing, which can lead to a lot of reorganization and switching roles unexpectedly

review_title: Careful if you have medical needs
pros: Good Benefits, multiple shifts based on performance
cons: If you have any medical accommodation needs be wary. Also traffic around the region is so unpredictable you must be very careful. You are expected to be not one minute late and also cannot go to your desk or classroom early.

review_title: Feel valued at a credit card company that doesn't behave like a credit card company
job_title: User Experience Designer in Nottingham, England
pros:
Great working environments, designed to encourage collaboration across multi-function teams
Commitment to employees is evident in everything the company does - from the interview process, to the welcome experience, to the support for personal and professional growth. 
Commitment to continuous improvement - processes and working practices at all levels are under constant review and suggestions for improvement are welcomed at all levels.
There's a genuine desire at all levels to build products for people, to help them gain the benefits of credit - not trying to get people into debt they cannot possibly manage.
Talented people from a variety of backgrounds.
Flexibility and work/life balance is excellent. Balancing work with childcare and family commitments is well supported and accommodated easily.
cons: As with many big companies, it can still take a little while to make things happen - but this is always improving.

job_title: Senior Associate, Risk Management in Richmond, VA
pros: Work location can be somewhat flexible when you need it to be. Less is best, just say you have kids or family obligations like everyone else.
cons:
Performance Management - Once they lock you in, they'll promise you the moon and stars and then blame the performance management rating system when they don't deliver. They do not pay you more or incentivize your growing skillset, which is why they cannot retain top talent. Based on the current performance management rating system, the likelihood of you being promoted is 15%. Most are only promoted then they throw temper tantrums and threaten to leave... who wants to work like that? Also, the wage gap is real. That's why it is "frowned upon" to discuss what you make. If you're a female, it's pretty much guaranteed that your less qualified and lower performing male colleagues make 15-25% more than you do. As your skillset grows, leave Capital One. They do rarely offer compensation when moving across LOB's or departments. You lose money by "growing within" Capital One internally.

A lotta talk, no action. Look elsewhere.

review_title: Challenging Job with good work-life balance
pros:
- technically more challenging than other banks in the area
- management acts on at least some of the survey suggestions
- emphasis on moving legacy systems to the cloud(mainly AWS)
- time is given every Friday to pursue learning and other interests
- pcp doctor on campus, nice health benefits
- 3% 401k match even if you don't contribute anything
cons:
- salary for senior engineers could be higher
- most employees have a bad opinion of stack ranking
- every technical decision needs to be vetted by a central team of architects even before one line of code is written. This adds needless delays.
- management tries too hard to make employees feel as if they are part of a noble mission. Though company is better than peers, the constant emphasis on mission
becomes distracting

review_title: A good place to learn but team connections are weak
pros: Good benefits. Opportunities for in-house training and on the job experience. Brand recognition helps on the resume. Very smart and talented coworkers. Well thought out programs, although not always for the associates' best interests.
cons: The frequent reorganizations make it difficult to develop strong working relationship. The performance evaluation system emphasizes weaknesses and stokes internal competition. In addition the different job families are not treated or valued equally. The base salaries are lower and large portion of the compensation is deferred (annual bonuses etc) so if you leave you lose much of what you earned over the preivous year. Some claim that the company takes advantage of the visa status of many of the associates, rewarding them less since it is difficult for them to seek employment elsewhere.

review_title: Limited room for growth, behind the times on project management
job_title: Process Manager in Lake Dallas, TX
pros:
1)  Very employee friendly
2)  Flexible on work-life balance
3)  Good, knowledgable people to work with
4)  Lots of opportunity for improvement
cons:
1)  Behind the times in project management (utilizing Agile style, rather then DMAIC, DFSS, Lean, etc)
2)  Lack of communication, which causes disconnects and risk within and cross project
3)  Resists change, does not want to consider other types of methodologies

pros: Excellent company that invest in their employee development. Numerous development opportunities, in the form of courses and/or on the job growth.  They are on the aggressive in their expansion of the business, as well as nimble in the market place.  They are extremely innovative as well.  The number one pro of working with the company was the growth opportunities and development. Benefits, 401k, and stock purchase is also very strong.
cons: Although the growth opportunities are great, it takes an substantial amount of time to move upward. There is a lot of politics that are played and a lot of red tape in order to get projects or initiatives across the line.  Also, very high demand - in order to be a top performer you must manage a team as well as manage initiatives. The work life balance is not ideal...Merit increases and bonuses are also not that great.

job_title: Principal Product Manager in McLean, VA
pros: Lots of work life flexibility, benefits are amazing, very supportive of volunteering and supporting the community.  Lots of support of moving around within the company.
cons: Performance review process can lead to ineffective measurement of associates.  Associates are ranked against peers on a bell curve, so it's beneficial to a peer to provide negative feedback on others to increase their positivity.  Company prides themselves on hiring the best talent.  However, that means that you have a ton of smart, strong skilled individuals all competing for promotions (average promotion time is 5-6 years per level).

review_title: Good benefits and opportunity advance ments
pros: Over all good atmosphere, the referrals where easy, only 13 per month in my region. I easily doubled that, they provide great hands on training for two weeks and pay for the drive time. I worked with the company for one year, I would have loved to stay with them longer but i moved states and there was no Capital One I could transfer to.
cons: They are trying to expand across the United States but there are still mostly a eastern coast bank so if you move often (military spouse) it will be difficult to transfer. They didn't offer a pay difference even though i was hired as a bilingual teller. A times they will micro manage and get very pushy, they will would actually sit next to you, make sure you push products even when those customers dont need them

review_title: They think their a bank but not so sure that Senior Management agrees.  Focused on return from Credit Cards.
pros: Close to home. Salary was good. Former Chevy Chase employees are dedicated to their customers & customers are mostly loyal to the Bank.   Lots of branches & a great local ATM network.
cons:
For a company that prides itself on Technology the branch systems are antiquated.  Product line is weak.  When you sell a Real Estate secured product it will close in 8 to 12 weeks. Process for processing loans in Plano TX is ridiculous & Senior Management  did nothing to fix it.  I don't think anything happened but the addition of another layer of management. 

Keeps its Internet Bank separate but deceitfully tells customers it's OK for them to use branches. The only that works regularly is the Credit Card company. Very frustrating wasting the acquisition of several good banks.

review_title: Relationship Banker: Just like any other...
pros: Capital One is in the works of being competitive. With so many retail branches out there, and the advancements and changes happening to retail banking, Capital One to me is like the little brother. But they are getting there. Just like any bank, sales goals are there for any role within retail. I have been around the block so I do have to say CapOne is more sensible with goals than other banks.
cons: Sales goals. The trend is getting similar to that of a Wells Fargo, or Santander. I wouldnt be surprised if CapOne started aggressively selling bank products in the near future.
