review_title: Company cukture is going downhill fast
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Good benefits, good devices for employees, can work from home if needed, nice facilities. Employees who worked there many years are very knowledgable and courteous
cons: I've worked here since 2004 and the company isn't what it used to be. Too many levels, too many layers, way too many folks involved you don't know who is who. They're hiring directors and VPs who aren't leaders they're taskmasters. Very hard to get work done given very frequent org changes. Even Rich Fairbanks who I loved has changed his soul and tries to be hip and it isn't working. I loved this company, but it is going downhill culturally. If you're into the hipster scene and you like buzzwords and kissing butt, you'll do fine.

job_title: Senior Data Analysis Manager in Salinas, CA
pros: It's amazing the culture they have created there. Employees are highly professional, intelligent, and interpersonal, along with a passion for excellence and genuinely doing the right things. They have exceptional transparency and I loved their 360 review functionality.
cons: Their performance management process, while rightly highly valued/prioritized in the company, ironically functions largely counter to their culture in prioritizing strict percentages/bell curves over reality. They rightly have created a culture of excellence and truly exceptional employees, but then rank them on a bell curve as if they haven't achieved that objective. It's disappointing that they relocated many to a site with assurances, then all too soon closed that site. It's really so counter to their values.Hopefully just an anomaly.

review_title: All in all a great place to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineering Manager in McLean, VA
pros: Executive leadership is great for the most part, Excellent benefits, generous fringe benefits, flex hours and work from home, excellent technology, high bar for talent, most folks are super smart, but every village has its idiot
cons: Stack ranked performance system, difficult to get promoted, annual raises do not keep up with inflation so you need to negotiate hard up front, middle management is disengaged and often just looking for their next promotion, open office floor plans which can be difficult if you're introverted

review_title: Be prepared to work 24/7 to keep your job, and do not even think about disagreeing with your manager
job_title: Project Manager and Process Manager in Richmond, VA
pros:
Great pay and benefits
Nice campus
cons:
Performance management practices cause competition vs teamwork
HR is useless to help out if you have a horrible manager
If you want to keep your job, plan to work after hours and weekends to be able to do more than your peers
Reorganizations continually rotate managers and associates in and out of roles so they end up with job assignments on a whim that you may never have been interested in doing or be qualified or trained to do

review_title: Overall a good place but a roller coaster ride
pros:
1) Good pay and benefits
2) Good vacation/time off 
3) Good flex time and work/life balance
4) Beautiful campus with basketball, gym, tennis and walking trails
5) Richmond has low cost of living PLUS great schools and very little commute time
cons:
- terrible performance management system - most people leave because of this- 
- high stress and competative environment - got to watch your back 
- tons of bueracracy and unnecessary process especially in IT
- If you lose your job there is nothing else in Richmond and you have to move to DC or other big metros
- Management is cutting pay and benefits - no raises in past 3 years, 401K cut down, training slashed, and hundreds of jobs gone offshore. You make one mistake and you are out, labelled as a "poor performer".

review_title: Doesn't pay to be top performer
pros: I loved my job and the opportunity to grow. Loved the people I worked with and the knowledge I gained. Really believed in the CEO
cons: Jealous spiteful  management that drummed up false accusations against top performers and got them fired. I was on maternity leave when it happened to me,  I never missed a day until my baby was born and was consistently a top performer but management accused me of fraud for an award program that they created with a $25 gift card. Now not able of being rehired as the company does not reverse, even though the manager that made the claims was terminated and another manager has confirmed that the claims against me were not valid. Breaks my heart as I saw myself making Capital One my work home for the long haul.

review_title: Great culture, atmosphere. Fun place to work!
pros: I work for Capital One in Sioux Falls, SD. There are a lot of things to love. Benefits (PTO, 401K match, Stock Purchasing Programs) are awesome. Capital One works really hard to try to be different that "just another call center". Casual environment is a plus. One of the biggest pro's is that it is a customer-centric organization from the top down - and they mean that.
cons: If you get hired in at a good salary, you will do very well. If you get hired at a low rate, you have no chance of getting to where you want to be. Policy is to give a small raise with promotions, but not what you are worth. A lot of middle managers don't care and kick their feet up. Frustrating, but I guess you see that anywhere...

review_title: The Company is okay...not the best
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Laurel, MD
pros:
Pay/Bonus       Promotion
Benefits            Career Growth
Open door policy
cons: The management is horrible.  All the managers care about are there numbers. As soon as you bring there numbers down they will try and find a way to get you fired. There compliance and signed in for a call center is ridiculous. Oh and I hope you never get sick because they do not accept doctors note. The managers fraternize with bankers and gossip...the list goes on. This company's turn around rate is the worst i have ever seen for a company.

review_title: Good opportunity! Overall, enjoyed my time working there!
pros: Good benefits and perks for those that meet individual and branch goal. They give you the tools to succeed as long as you put in the time and effort. Hours of operation is in par with the industry and travel time between home and branch is pretty reasonable.
cons: I believe that Capital One overall is behind in the technology field and needs to focus on catching up to the rest in the market. It would also be beneficial if there were better career opportunities outside of sales and this is with the understanding that the company is in the banking industry.

review_title: Good opportunity! Overall, enjoyed my time working there!
pros: Good benefits and perks for those that meet individual and branch goal. They give you the tools to succeed as long as you put in the time and effort. Hours of operation is in par with the industry and travel time between home and branch is pretty reasonable.
cons: I believe that Capital One overall is behind in the technology field and needs to focus on catching up to the rest in the market. It would also be beneficial if there were better career opportunities outside of sales and this is with the understanding that the company is in the banking industry.

review_title: Stay away, there is no future with this company.
pros: Good vacation time. Average benefits. Nothing special, just the same as most large companies. Good 401k match, but you will leave before you are vested.
cons: Okay, where do I begin? Massive layoffs of all aassistant managers in the entire company. Massive pay cuts in incentives, bonuses and generally all areas. The company claims to want the best and brightest, yet every year associates make less money. The morale at branch offices is at an all time low. So the winning formula is less employees, more work for those who remain, while also paying them much less. How is that for a future? Do yourself a favor and avoid applying. Despite the corporate propaganda, this company does not value their employees.

review_title: Take It For What It Is
pros: Flexibility with scheduling. As long as the request in made in a timely manner vacation is usually approved. Due to cutting back cost and not wanting to pay overtime, it is rare that you are required to work overtime. This is beneficial in establishing the much needed work life balance that all of us desire. The hours of operation are very reasonable. Even though it is open on Saturdays there is normally a rotation that allows employees to get weekends off. If you have to or choose to work on Saturday you will be given a day off during the week.
cons: Advancement opportunites are reserved for those in the "inner loop"

review_title: Great buildings and cafeterias.  Make sure you wear a bullet proof vest to deal with the politics.
pros: Great buildings, grounds and cafeterias.  Good benefits.  Depending upon the department, very good people to work with - especially in the Financial Services department.
cons: Technical departments are run by VPs with absolutely NO technical skills or knowledge.  They continually make poor decisions based on their lack of industry knowledge.  Overall, the company is VERY political.  ALWAYS watch your back, no one is immune.  Also, the 'future of work' environment requires most people to drag suitcases on wheels to and from work.  Unless you're a VP with an office, you do not have a desk - you just occupy a chair at a table with everyone else.

pros: Work is fun, and I am lucky to be in a great team. Campus is great, benefits are good, and Plano is a great city. Depending on the team and the department, the culture and the senior leaders can be very open and understanding.
cons: Too much outsourcing hurts morale. New employees get hired at $20-40k above midpoint, and many people joke that it's better to leave the company for a year and try to get hired back because of the raise. Depending on your department, promotion opportunities can be very limited and attrition can be as high as 100% per year.

review_title: I and many other bankers will be leaving once the economy and job market improve. Holding pattern until then.
pros:
Paid time off is four weeks. That is including sick time.
Benefits are ok. Medical,dental, and vision.
 7.5% total 401k match is nice.
cons:
Recently got rid of most assistant branch managers leaving operational duties to managers that were mostly sales managers not operational managers. Those duties are now being passed down to the sales people even if upper management does not believe that to be the case.
Unclear career path for bankers at this time.
Additional responsibilities and doing things the assistant manager and in the absence of your manager filling in that role too with no additional compensation.
Poor morale.
Salary and commission schedule poor and not comparable to other banks.
I and many other bankers will be leaving once the economy and job market improve. Holding pattern until then.
I would not recommend working for capital one.

review_title: Good organization, but need to move out if not on the right career track quickly
pros:
- Intelligent (mostly), diverse group of work colleagues
- In house gym rocks, twice a week personal training sessions included in monthly fee of just $15
- Associates given a wide range of career options to switch. Not boxed in unless you want to specialize. See below for con on promo path
cons:
- Promotion path not very clear or consistent within groups
- Home Loans business on a churn and burn path for the last 5 years. Superstars and promotees one day and fired the next.

job_title: Phone Agent in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great company  true work life balance. Great benefits and time off. Wish we had more stability. Always wondering whose site will close next  other than that I can’t complain. Nice kiosk for getting snacks. All self serve. The way if the future in all aspects of life and work.
cons: Job stability this is what everyone wants in their life right.  I have been here 18 years and wonder every day if we are the next site to close because there is a cheaper place to send our work. This is always a concern.

pros:
- Smart folks with top-notch educational background
- Learn a lot to survive in a regional banking landscape
- Benefit
- Work schedule - some flexibility depending on the management
cons:
- Lots of meetings to talk about meeting
- People who just happened to be there having a job without any qualifications
- Ego of older employees kills the new fresh breath of air
- Tons of lay-offs
- Things move slow, with lots of change, people are still resistant to change, oddly

review_title: Very smart people and a challenging, continuous-learning environment
pros: I work with very smart people who genuinely want to do the right thing.  I am always learning, always challenged.  I have tremendous worklife flexibility.  Management has been very supportive of career moves and provided opportunities for career development.
cons: The very smart people I work with can tend to be arrogant.  Not arrogant as in rude, but constantly searching for the perfect answer and religiously picking apart every idea that comes their way.

pros: the benefits are the only pro
cons:
No recognition
Promotions to those that are lowest on the floor
Top Producers aren't rewarded, or recognized like they should be
Screw the people who have the highest rank on the floor by letting them go, accusing them of not completeing the role of their job
Constant investigation on people if they actually are able to do their job with out being coached
Management is a joke~ They do not communicate, are not any where to be found when you need help, and are constantly baby sitting you to see if your at your desk

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Competitive salary, willing to invest in order to grow.
cons: There is a huge gulf between what Leadership says and what actually happens in the company.  Leadership messaging is all too often directly contradicted by line managers.  Rewards are based on each manager's individual goals, so leadership vision has no bearing on their priorities.  Conflicts abound, and the people that come out ahead tend to be the ones that have the biggest 'win at all costs' outlook, and are willing to circumvent policies and procedures in order to do it.  Easily the most political environment I have ever worked in.

review_title: Great place to build a career.
job_title: Senior Business Director in Richmond, VA
pros: The company takes care of its people - competitive benefits, takes care of people who roles are eliminated, strong ethical people culture. There is a strong culture with talented people, collaborative atmosphere. The is consistent leadership with founder CEO, an inspiring mission, a progressive agenda and a lot of opportunity for career growth.
cons: The company and its various business units go through frequent reorganizations. This is generally for the right reasons to position the company strategically for the long term, but the frequency of change can be frustrating and inefficient. the company is going through growing pains as the it tries to reinvent itself as a technology company and digital leader. This leads to uncertainty about job function and what skills it will take to be successful here going forward.

review_title: Company with a broken performance management system
pros:
- Overall good work-life balance (though not true in all areas)
- Decent salary and benefits
- Learning opportunities
cons:
- Performance management system that focuses on individual rather than team performance and thus encourages “dog eats dog” culture
- Extremely hierarchical and title-oriented environment where a VP+ is like a demigod
- Senior leadership mostly living in ivory towers disconnected from the real world
- Much stronger in strategy formulation than actually carrying it out properly
- Too frequent reorgs, restructures, and layoffs leaving people confused and scared for their future
- Too many daily meetings leaving little time for the actual work

pros: Good Benefits and Pay.    Work-life balance is ok in some areas -  horrible in most others.
cons: Everything else besides Benefits.  Most leaders are life-long Capital one employees -  who have no outside experience - and therefore, only see things one way.......People get promoted based on WHO THEY KNOW........and senior management has no clue about its workers.   Recruiting will say anything to get you on board - reality is so different once you are an employee.

review_title: Insight from a former Senior Recruiter in Human Resources
job_title: Senior Recruiter (Human Resources) in Plano, TX
pros:
I supported the Human Resources department hiring throughout the entire organization, but primarily the HR dept.  I visited Richmond for a week long training but sat in the Plano office. 

Great Company Brand
Culture is similar to a consulting company
Remote employees are celebrated
Remote working is celebrated
Process-oriented work culture
Intelligent Hires- Rigorous Interview selection process to include case studies
cons:
As someone who directly recruited for the organization, I interacted with hiring managers at the Manager to Director level. 
Bureaucratic Process Oriented work culture- Lots of Red Tape to do simple tasks
Dogmatic Leadership style- Yelling Screaming Berating employees
Unfair hiring practices with regard to discrimination of candidates based on race, nationality/origin widely practiced. 
I would not advise anyone of color to work in the HR department.

pros: Benefits are awesome here with Capital One. It's a great company to work for, with a ton of different options for lateral and upward movement. Work/life balance is real solid and the work environment is pretty cool.
cons: Management is horrendous. Coming from a previous sales job, we had 1 manager for my teem but still managed to push out weekly meetings at set times for months and months straight. Here, you're lucky to get a 1 on 1 maybe once a month. It's pretty sad. We have 3 managers for 20 people and even still I am lucky if one of them is around the entire day. Nobody on the sales floor knows where they go.

review_title: Positive workplace and good starting point
pros: Great place to work, brilliant staff, You can't help but get involved. Working at CapitalOne is a very fulfilling experience, from the minute you start at the company you are engulfed into the companies culture, which is work hard, but play harder. The company aims for a great work life balance. They provide alternative working and meeting areas to help you think outside of the box and look at was of solving issues from your normal perspective
cons:
No Computer training before you go on there system.
long hours
not much of a chance to change hours, overtime paid at normal rate, paid late, threats from managment if you dont hit your targets, bullying environment, show everyone on site how bad your doing, not helpful, threaten to take your bonus off you if you dont hit targets that involve the managers bonus

pros: Capital One offers competitive pay and benefits. They also strive to challenge their employees to push to the next level. If you're looking for a company that will challenge you and that will offer great incentives for your hard work, then Capital One is the place for you.
cons: If someone is not looking for a company that challenges you to push to the next level, then Capital One is not the employer for you. If you don't like the way something is done on the job at Capital One, just wait a week, it will change.

pros: Capital one goes above and beyond to offer its employees great benefits. The health care is low cost, but we are offered multiple different options. We even have a reward program where if we participate we can earn up to 350$ in gift cards extra. starting 4 weeks of PTO and it only gets better. great place, definately concerned with making sure the employees can balance work and life effectively.
cons: Only thing i hate is office politics. I guess you will find that in every office...but i still hate it. i feel we should only be judged basedon the work we produce and depending on your direct manager, it may or may not go that way. i have been blessed with great managers, so this CON is just based on other opinions.

review_title: Excellent place to work. Innovative culture & benefits are second to none.
pros: Live our mission statement & values. Ethical company. Incentive-based programs to promote healthy lifestyle like discounts on healthy food at cafés on campus, doctor/pharmacy onsite, gym onsite with personal trainers at no extra cost, beautiful campus & building facilities,  not bureaucratic at all. Access to senior & executive leaders so even though we're large,  we all feel like we know Rich & our top-of-the-house crew.
cons: Benefit package is so amazing so compensation can feel a bit on the middle to low end of indusrty scale - but where else do you get 3-4 weeks vacation your first year and access to so many on campus amenities?

pros:
Great work/life balance for employees
Awesome benefits
Above average salary and bonus structure
cons:
After two recent large acquisitions senior leaders seemed unsure on how to manage a much larger company
Current senior leadership team are not strong leaders to motivate staff and drive results
Lack of strategic vision is causing dissatisfaction among employees, especially as employees are being dinged in year end reviews for lack of results

job_title: Principal Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Their benefits are competitive. If you're fortunate, you will have a manager who acts as an advocate for you and provides additional resources when needed.
cons:
It is very difficult to get things done due to the structure of the company. Every line of business is partitioned off from the other and it's like pulling teeth to get complete answers to your questions and resolve problems.

Even though overtime isn't required, they make sure you do it by assigning more work than can be done in 40. You can work 10+ OT a week on average, and you will still be reprimanded by taking unexpected time off if you're sick. There are no "sick days", only "unscheduled time off", and you are only allowed 32 hours of that a year.  If you are struck with the flu, experience car problems, kids have a snow day, etc., that can add up fast.

job_title: Fraud Detection Coordinator in Tigard, OR
pros:
1. The Team - The people there genuinely want you to succeed.  they understand this may be a foot in the door job and not your first love.  But they willing to help you find it.
2. communication - I was never in the dark about "how I was doing".  The feedback was relevant and brief. With expansions as needed.
cons:
My job ended. They pulled the trigger a year early because of finances and closed the site. I feel this was a bad move as they had goals of increasing their Net Promoter Score, but now they have all new staff. 
Parking wasn't great but it wasn't the worst either

review_title: Lots of great things about Capital One, and some things to work on
pros:
-Great company vision with an inspiring CEO; well managed strategically
-Offices are generally nice; lots of good food options and amenities
-Work life balance below Director is generally good
-Benefits are much better than average
-Big enough company that I got to tackle some pretty cool problems and build my skillset
cons:
-Approach to promotions and employee recognition needs some work; slow promotions; small pay raises; our team didn't do a good job of rewarding folks until they had one foot out the door
-Work life balance takes a big hit at Director and above; with a little bit better staff continuity I think this problem could be greatly reduced
-Lots of turnover (primarily due to the first bullet on the list)

review_title: Engineering team is led by non-engineers
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Richmond, VA
pros:
Latest technologies
Good benefits
Work culture varies by team but overall good culture
cons:
Recruiters try to hire you at a level where once you join you'll realize that people with lesser skills than you are at higher levels just by virtue of being in the same place for a long time.
Inspite of their shift from being hands-off to vendors to being hands-on engineers, sr. managers and directors are all non-technical folks. This is a challenge in terms of growing as an engineer.
Pay hikes each year are measly. Promotions are not evaluated by an independent group, the people managers get together and decide and a lot of value is given to handling "visible" work and "coordination" rather than "complex" work.

pros:
- OK compensation
- some options to work remotely
- large company and lots of people to meet
cons:
- wants to be like a startup, but is too obstructed by legacy mentality
- poor work-life balance and little autonomy over your day and workflow
- feature factory; not practicing Lean and iterative development. uses SAFE Agile and prioritizes shipping features over solving problems
- little understanding of customer needs
- no culture of mentorship; everyone is too busy

pros: Very talented, analytic people.  Rigorous and thoughtful.  Good work/life balance.  Well compensated.  Generally mission oriented (albeit still primarily a subprime credit card company).  Positioned well to be a digital leader amongst banks and consolidate market position in a few areas (cards, retail banking, auto)
cons: Frequent Reorgs make it difficult to make traction on strategic goals.  Too much emphasis on new ideas and agendas as opposed to solid execution on existing plans.  Roles and responsibilities blurry; highly matrix-ed environment that leads to consensus-based decision making without incremental impact from multiple voices.  Some senior management act as if their main role is "best analyst in the room" as opposed to being effective people managers, team leaders and operators.  Annual strategic planning process led by CEO is ineffective and sucks up resources.   Crowded with limited growth opportunities for talent.

review_title: Not the best but not the worst
pros: No sales goals, pay was good they gave everyone a raise when they took away the sales goals, hours
cons: Micro management, high turn over rate, if you’re a banker it’s hard to get promoted they rather higher from outside (in the 4 years I’ve worked at capital one only 1 banker has been promoted in my district), call nights, there are no clear cut rules each branch manager can set their own policies for lunch ( some branch’s give a 1hr, 45min, or even 30min lunch break) why don’t care about your schedule they only care about what’s “best for the branch” so if you have to pick up your kids they don’t care, if you have school they don’t care, if you have anything else to do they don’t care, changing directions capital one has no clear cut direction they change it every so often managers would complain to each other on the phones but when you as an associate question it they have an issue

pros:
- compared to other companies, culture is laid back and you can dress casually
- the company make you feel appreciated they reward staff with small treats to say thank you, which is a nice touch.
- open plan so senior managers are accessible
cons:
- low salary 16.5k per year for coordinators
- perfomance management could be better. I do not understand how you can compare performance for all people at the same level right across the  department when people do extremely different things? It makes sense if everyone is doing the same thing. It's really not a reflection of someone's perfomance.
-  management have a relaxed approach to bullying. I have seen the victims being pushed out with perpetrators keeping jobs because they are "friends" with managers.
- you have to play the game to get promoted

pros:
- compared to other companies, culture is laid back and you can dress casually
- the company make you feel appreciated they reward staff with small treats to say thank you, which is a nice touch.
- open plan so senior managers are accessible
cons:
- low salary 16.5k per year for coordinators
- perfomance management could be better. I do not understand how you can compare performance for all people at the same level right across the  department when people do extremely different things? It makes sense if everyone is doing the same thing. It's really not a reflection of someone's perfomance.
-  management have a relaxed approach to bullying. I have seen the victims being pushed out with perpetrators keeping jobs because they are "friends" with managers.
- you have to play the game to get promoted

review_title: It's a big company, it's what you make of it.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: The company really seems to care about employees. They offer a lot of perks for families and allow you to be really autonomous. They have a goal of being a tech company first and a bank second.
cons: Middle management is not great. There is a lot of bureaucracy and unhealthy competition between tech teams. There is a culture of siloed work where Product is in one silo, Engineering another, Design another. It generally doesn't work and creates huge disparities in goals. There is constant re-orging in the SF office and it is difficult to hang on to good talent because middle management can't agree on a tragectory.

review_title: Good place to work.  Tough times.  Be prepared to compete for your job.
pros: Great compensation.  Good people.  Generally smart enough.  I also think that living in Richmond is a bonus.  It's a great launching point to go to D.C., the beach, or the mountains.  Great launching point to get away from.  Seems silly to say, but it's a good place to raise kids, just not a great place to enjoy the finer things in life.
cons: Territorial.  Some people have much higher opinions of themselves than they should, especially IT and program managers.

review_title: One of a few good financial institutions
pros: They take care of their employees. Management makes an effort to have a personal relationship with employees rather than handing down dictates from their throne. They are flexible for a big corporation, and will support hard-working employees with time and understanding as needed. It seems like they actually care, offering money towards continuing education, and constantly helping local charities.
cons: It's a corporation. So don't be surprised to find four "VPs" in one office. Banking is like the restaurant business; you have to be prepared to smile for customers even if your girlfriend just left you during your lunch break.

pros: Opportunity to try new things, latest technology, work life balance however that is not as good as it use to be, benefits again not as good as they use to be, medical staff on site, culture and values are changing as well.  All use to be much better and are declining.
cons: POLITICS! Capital One use to be a big company that behaved like a small one.  Now they are a typical corporation with managers who have no business managing people, force distributions when it comes to reviews, pay is mediocre, not all jobs in the same role are the same but are compared to each other at review time.  Company has a bad habit of jumping on bandwagons and forcing huge change before understanding the ramifications, then jumping on the next new thing before the dust settles from the last.

pros: Great for someone who is good at, and likes, sales. The company provides countless resources to help make you a better salesperson and have more success with the company. A competitive yet supportive atmosphere among the bankers, for the most part. In the branches, everyone is incentivised based on team goals.
cons:
Graded in many different areas, but the only ones that hold significant weight for promotions are the sales goals. Only a worthwhile position to take if you are extremely sales-oriented. 

The changing environment in the banking industry makes it so that people are afraid of layoffs as positions are phased out to make room for newer, often lower-paid, positions. The recent removal of all Assistant Branch Managers has made many people in lower positions afraid for their jobs.

pros:
Full of bright, enthusiastic and positive people
Work life balance is not just a phrase thrown around - it means something and managers encourage associates to embrace it
Offices are bright and airy and the facilities are constantly evolving to make Capital One a great place to work (including the amazing restaurant in Nottingham!)
There is an emphasis on fun - from the annual Capital One music festival (held with a tent, bands and fairground rides) to the little things, like market stalls popping up each lunch
cons: There is currently a lot of change throughout the organisation and while that is exciting and  information channels are good, the be better communicated at times

pros: Literally none different than compared to other Software Companies in current market
cons: If change happens too frequently, progress is negative. This was too logical to even be a leadership principle. To save his job and past failures, the CTO has gone crazy implementing things without looking at all terms of risks. Layoffs happen every day and hiring happens everyday since last 3 years.  Like a kid, show anything fancy to Capital One and they will adopt it without a thought.

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Lincoln, NE
pros: Pay is reasonable, nice 401k options, above average benefits
cons: Getting written up for no reason, extremely poor leadership, overall feeling of being on edge of losing job for nearly anything, retaliation.

review_title: Flexible place to work and good people.
pros:
Although everything written here can be different depending on the department, at least they are valid for the risk department.
Flexibility: as long as you get your job done, it does not matter if you want to take half an hour or two hours for lunch or if you want to take a break in the middle of your day to go to the gym. If you need a day off for whatever reason you will have it. In general, there are not very strict rules, so you can ask for whatever you want to your manager. Of course, you will have to be flexible with the company as well (it is a two-way relationship).
cons: Sometimes you have got to work very fast to get things done, and work overtime, which is not paid (and this is the flexibility from the employee to the employer).

review_title: When growth slows all the dirty linen is exposed
pros: Quality of intellectual talent - still among the best and brightest although erosion of average intellect has continued from its peak in 2004-2005.
cons: Its just like any other bank now - no growth anywhere - dog-eat-dog politics.  Political maneouvering trumps meritocracy.   Some of the most unprofessional managerial behaviors have started to creep into the culture.  Executives make noises from time to time but largely adopt a 'Look away and dont tell' position on such happenings.   Some quality does exist at the MVP+ levels but thereafter, its all downhill VP and below.

pros: Good work-life balance, nice people and the Richmond campus is great.
cons:
- Looks like you can only move sideways if you're in certain parts of the organization, which doesn't make sense.  Regardless of what department one is in, everyone should have the opportunity to progress upwards. 
- Additionally, if you're based in DC - you have to go back and forth to the Richmond office frequently.  Sometimes meetings will be scheduled in Richmond without even consulting one's availability to make the 2-hour one way trip.  Going for a day is 4 hours round trip.... If I wanted to travel that often, I'd rather work in Consulting for higher pay.

review_title: Great Company, wrong people in managment
pros: Loads of learning experiences - but related to your role and for your personal development. I have always felt the company has great principles and really looks out of it's employees. There is plenty of room for advancement and the compensation/benefits are amazing.
cons: The wrong people are in management opportunities more often than they should be. While their are opportunities for advancement and promotion - many managers would rather place their "buddies" in new roles, even if they have no experience. Opportunities are also given to the same 4-5 people in a department, but everyone is held to their expectations to produce results when they are not given an opportunity to do so.

pros:
- Embrace digital and innovation journey with user design and innovation labs
- Flexible with work location (many, many work from home)
- Some exciting projects and aspirations
- The CEO Rich Fairbanks is inspirational and seems to be an amazing leader
cons:
- Commercial bank is spread out across the country with no leadership or management to make it operate as a whole
- There is a lack of team work and a competitive environment that had caused a bit of a toxic environment with the vacuum in leadership
- Work/life balance is terrible in that while you can work from home and handle personal issues when they surface, 80 hour weeks and lots of weekend time are the norm
- Promotions are scarce and more on who you know than what you contribute

review_title: Massive change happening, trying too hard to act like a startup.
pros: Salary is good, on the higher end for most roles. Professional roles unlimited sick time and good amount of PTO, just hard to take it all.
cons: Health Benefits are expensive but they are everywhere. Work/life balance used to matter but over the past couple of years expectations to work 24x7 are ruining peoples lives. Seems like a lot of tenured folks who are over 40 seem to be getting "packaged" out and in the process, you are losing some great talented folks. Micro management at Senior Director levels.

job_title: Department Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Community involvement, co-workers, leaders, new building, cafe, gym and health center. Also, making customers a priority and treating them with respect and dignity.
cons: Way to many levels to get promoted. Example: Floor Supervisor > FLM > UM ... "This is where it gets real stupid"... > "Stretch PA (no pay increase)" > PA > "Stretch DM (no pay increase)" > DM > "Stretch Senior DM (no pay increase)" > Senior DM > "Stretch Director (no pay increase)" etc. The company says they are ensuring you are set up for success, what they are really doing is not paying you for more responsibility. Great way to lose good talented people.

pros: Capital One gives an incredible level of exposure to people at the analyst and senior analyst role. It is an exciting company with lots of interesting projects happening across the various lines of business. There is generally a strong development culture, good pay, and a good work life balance. The McLean campus is adding a beautiful new building in summer 2018 which is a great perk.
cons:
Some roles can have a bit of a narrow scope and focus. Many BAs like that focus and singular analytical problem, but I generally preferred the more strategic/multifaceted projects. 
Capital One should work on improving diversity. 
Capital One has a strong preference towards college hires and I would not recommend this to someone coming in as a senior associate as an external hire. I do recommend it if you are applying for manager+ roles.

pros: Decent wages, Awesome benefits love the culture and flexible work from home days depending on your manager. Our office is big time foodies always something to grub on
cons: This place constantly change Leadership in the last year 5 Executives left. It's always constant change with no direction.  They are reactive company. Minimum training depending on your manager you probably want get any direction more figure it out. The calibration performance  process is unfair you might end up with no raise at end of year. Not all managers will provide feedback. This office has limited resources on-site you may have to scramble and find your way.

job_title: Management Rotation Program in McLean, VA
pros: Easy quality of life, GREAT offices, snacks, good benefits, pretty good salary for starting out of college
cons: With as many people as there are at Capital One, there is a lack of deep ownership over anything.  As well, more people are worried about making a name, than solving a problem.  Projects are often rushed to meet Performance Management cycles, rather than because they meet needs.

review_title: The constant talk of low turnover and no time limits are not entirely true
job_title: Fraud Account Supervisor in Tampa, FL
pros:
-The job was relatively easy once you got passed the learning curve.
-Great people to work with.
-Tried having team outings to build up unity.
-Benefits from day 1.
cons:
-The pay is pretty low for the amount of work put in.
-The training is long and extensive, but you don't feel like you know anything until you begin answering the phones.
-A lot of micro-managing.
-Favoritism is huge in the quota ratings.
-They constantly talk about low turnover rates, but there were over a dozen people that quit or were fired in a one month span.
-They don't want you logged off the phones longer than 5 minutes unless you're on break. Anything over that you will have to answer to multiple people one after another about what's going on.

review_title: Great Potential, Great Benefits - High Stress, Ultra Competitive
pros: Solid Company. Genuinely care about their employees.  Provide great benefits, and tons of training opportunities.  Doing cool things to get ahead in technology and banking and staying competitive.  Moving around is more than ok, its welcomed.  You can define your own career path and network across the company to get there.  Awesome to work with Smart People, and overall genuinely good people.
cons: Performance management is ultra-competitive, and corrupts even the most decent individuals - creates a lot of overhead in politics, a super competitive culture and inches stress levels to unmanageable heights impacting overall health of many individuals.

job_title: Principal Data Analyst in McLean, VA
pros: This is a great place to start your career since, at the early levels, they have defined criteria with which you can progress your career quickly. It's an incredibly understanding and flexible place as well - many employees work from home when they need to. They were very understanding of my needs when I moved to New York and allowed me to continue working from there. I still have nothing but love for Capital One.
cons: Some of the Data Analyst roles are ~100% BAU work, but I feel that every job needs at least 20% of innovative or interesting work for self-growth. I'm very fortunate that my role allowed me to do that.

pros: Generous paid time off, Incentives can be good when things are busy, a decent work culture, and a genuine desire to encourage career path.  Overall, not a bad a place to work.  Love the people!
cons: It is common for premature rollout of new technology or software changes before the systems are tested and proven.  This is particularly troublesome when it pertains to incentive point tracking.  There is a constant change in the tracking system for no particular reason.  At times, it appears they are making it harder to track incentive points.  An additional negative is the load of paperwork required to maintain while expected to primarily focus on sales.

review_title: Talks the "talk" but doesn't necessarily walk the "walk"
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Plano, TX
pros:
- Benefits (3 weeks PTO, sick days don't count, health, dental, vision, FSA matching...)
- Work / Life Balance
- Employee appreciation (Fun days, spring flings, etc...)
- Training
- Vision
cons: The company puts a lot of effort into hiring the "best" and "brightest"... until there is a shortage of employees at which point many of the elements designed to screen the "less desirable" people are often thrown out the window. This is a non issue most of the time, but the company's year end review process is such that people above, below, and at your level have a say and can impact your year end rating. So if politics isn't your game then this may not be the company for you.

review_title: Very erratic corporation. Too many reorgs.
job_title: Back Office in New Orleans, LA
pros: Size is big. Uniformity across the footprint. Technologically advanced.
cons: Too much bureaucracy. High-sounding nonsense. Those who can BS, make it big. The quite ones, not a chance! Very little diversity beyond mid-level management. Jargonism rules. No career pathing. One has to blow one's own horn. One comes across people of color often complaining that they are kept behind since those at the helm would not work for their advancement and not allow them to move forward. The management often boosts about diversity - yes, there's plenty to be found at the lower level but not much when it comes to management.

pros: Good benefits, flexible work schedule, ability to work from home depending on department, lots of energy in the company, CEO seems open and honest
cons: Constant re-orgs so people get hired then laid off.  Very difficult to move around to other areas or to get promoted.  Growing too big, too fast.  No respect for legacy talent or "older" employees.  There is a sense of age-ism.  Raises are terrible.  Not even keeping up with cost of living.  Different departments operate very differently than others as far as the culture and values.  Very inconsistent treatment

job_title: Business Analyst Intern in Plano, TX
pros: There is an incredible culture at Capital One. There is a sense of really banking for good. I was blown away by how much a large company would do for their customer. Additionally, there is great work-life balance. People come in at around 9 and leave at 5. Sometimes people will work from home a little later at night, but there is no expectation to stay in the office late into the evening. Finally, the people there are great. People are very open and willing to talk to you and there is a pretty flat structure.
cons: There isn't always overlap with lines of business. It can be easy to be relatively siloed into your own line of business, but there are definitely opportunities to get to know people if you are active about it. There isn't always great integration between BAs and non BAs.

pros: I am a 15 year IT associate at Capital One in Richmond.  The Pros of working for this company include decent pay, good benefits and, recently, exposure to current technologies.  The best benefit of working at Capital One is the fairly generous vacation package; I receive 4 weeks of vacation with the option to buy an additional week for a small price.
cons:
My recent experiences (last 3 years) in Capital One IT have been very unpleasant.  Firstly, the culture at Capital One is competitive, nervous and fearful.  The primary reason for the horrible atmosphere is the Forced Distribution performance management practice.  Capita One shoe horns associates into performance ratings with 15-20% receiving bad rating.  As you might imagine in a corporate setting as this the decisions on who receives what rating is highly political.  While I have never received a bad rating in 15 years I rarely am acknowledged for the excellent work I produce and have only received above average ratings in years where I expressed displeasure in previous ratings.

So courtesy of the horrible performance management practices, what you end up with is a group of nervous, scared associates who are afraid of receiving bad ratings or perhaps even losing their jobs.  The response to that by many associates is to work over 60 hour work weeks and rarely take vacation out of fear.  Most associates fall into this category.  I'm always saddened to see fellow associates needlessly work long hours and send emails around midnight out of fear.  It's really sad and super commonplace.
 
The culture is horrible.  Plus, the fear of layoffs is never far away.

Management at Capital One is horrendous.  The typical Capital One middle manager is compromised, scared and a sellout.  These poor folks sit together in conference rooms two times a year "cross calibrating" their associates in an effort to determine who gets screwed with a bad rating.  It is awful.  Capital One has a ton of strong associates; only about 5% in IT are truly bad so these managers try to convince each other and their associates (keeping in mind the 15-20% bad rating forced distribution) that somehow Associate A who is a great worker and nice person should be told they suck for the year.

There is NO work life balance in Capital One IT.  It is not because there is so much work; it is because there is so much fear.  A truly horrendous place to work.

review_title: Capital One FRAUD DEPARTMENT, Tigard Oregon.
pros: Average insurance plan, dental plan is poor. Typical benefits of a large company. Possible future growth at Capital One, just not here in Oregon.
cons:
Pay that is below par. $12.25 for "professionals", people with experience,  people with college degrees, and people with years at the company. High turn-over due to this unbelievably low pay. Many leave for better jobs, and see Capital One only as a temporary job.
Capital One still uses cheap out sourcing of employees in Costa Rica and the Phillipines. Employees who have trained the Cap One employees there say the conditions are horrible (Manila). This company make BILLIONS AND BILLIONS of dollars in annual profits, sponsor high paid actors, NCAA tourney, have constant ads, etc.,...but can't pay wages that keep employees above Oregon's poverty level. They still mainly profit off of high interest credit cards.

review_title: Good Training for New Analysts - Plenty of Big Corporation Problems
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros:
-Work with extremely smart team members
-Great on the job training and early responsibilities
-Analytic rigor that is second to none
cons:
-A lot of politics, as is true of many large corporations
-Can be a grind at times, especially in parts of the business that aren't innovating anything
-Need to get lucky with the team you get placed on initially if you are a new college grad, or it won't work out. With all team members meeting a high bar after getting through the recruiting screens, upward mobility is largely dependent on getting put on good projects
-Lots of re-orgs and a bloated middle management tier that is tough to break through

review_title: Work/Life Great, Management Not So Much
pros: The Company overall is great. The Plano site does quite a bit to show appreciation to their employees from twice yearly activities for Associates (contractors not invited) to once yearly meetings with the CEO. On-site cafe's.
cons: Favoritism within Management. Employee relations not helpful. No true advocates for employees who bring up concerns. Lack of appreciation within teams outside of Customer Service. They treat contractors like they are less than, even though they do the work of an Associate. Tenure means nothing.

job_title: Senior Learning Associate in Richmond, VA
pros: Salary is good as are the benefits. Travel opportunities especially abroad.
cons: Awful culture. Stacked rankings pits associates against one another. Lots of back stabbing and lots of throwing others under the bus. Leadership is awful. Most move up from being an agent with no business education or skills. You have to be in someone’s pocket to rank strong or higher. They have a tendency to weed out people of a certain age yet they claim they are so diverse. Another laugh is that they’re a technology company. You have to wait forever for websites to load. Everything crashes on a regular basis. If you’re thinking of applying here, seriously think again.

pros: Great Benefits and opportunities to increase your education and development
cons: The stack ranking performance management is out dated and a great way to weed out people who work hard and have great potential because of a lottery system they have no control over. Not only must you work hard but you also have to make a name for yourself to grow.  Lots of great talent leave the doors because of the culture. Everything appears great and fun but lack of accountability of leaders, no checks and balances, and little to no help with associate development from leadership hurts the morale and growth.

pros: Great company overall, alot of team events. Company recognizes the hard working individual. Great 401k, paid time off,great co workers. My only mistake was not taking advantage tuition reimbursement while working here
cons: Started as a great company then came the changes over the five years I've capital one five different managers,four different district managers, laid off financial advisors, got rid of mortgage. Branch closures, Closed my branch and relocated. Eliminated my position and now everybody is branch ambassador. No room for advancement only one position Branch ambassador or unless a manager leaves and you get promoted to branch manager. Cut bonuses no more bonuses for employees instead you made a new headquarters building next to the existing one. My suggestion is call for corporate retail side will be gone soon corporate takes care of their people. Low pay

review_title: Too much red tape in evaluations
pros: Capital One has a pretty good vacation benefit.  The work from home is specially a good reason to work at Capital One.  The company also allows flexible work hours.   This is specially beneficial for those of us who have a lot of other responsibilities.  As the company continues to expand into other financial areas, it makes the job more stabilizing.  The pay package for a small town like Richmond is better than the average salary.  Opportunity to learn new things exist  for those who can play the politics.  An average severance package, should  you be unlucky to get retrenched.  Big player in a small town.
cons: Too much politics in the workplace

review_title: Great place to work from a culture standpoint.  Industry is #1 on the most hated by the public
pros:
- Great company culture
- Fantastic quality of people (no bozos)
- Meritocracy that rewards people for results not political prowess
- good compensation and benefits
- analytical approach balanced with sound judgment
cons:
- Industry is in a bad spot and government regulation / legislation will not make life easy for Capital One or anyone else 
- Bank acquisitions are sucking lots of bandwidth while the company gets the three banks to act as one
- Growth of the company is slowing so opportunities are not what they once were for advancement
- Focus is on very specific skillsets and general management skills are less appreciated than great quantitative skills and gaps in other disciplines

pros: Pay is decent and the hours are easy to work with.
cons: Was hired as part time but because of how understaffed (because of firing and quitting they were ) I ended up working overtime many weeks.  The training was extensive and unneeded as the policies and best practices were polar opposites when actually in branches and they vary from branch to branch also (I know this because I was sent to different branches to cover from my first week at the job).  Many of the systems and programs we used in branch were also unavailable during the two weeks training so we had to just wing it when we got to our home branch.

pros: Great work/life balance. The benefits are really amazing. They seem to value their employees as a whole, though certain departments are consistently overlooked. There are some really great people with a wealth of industry knowledge.
cons: Poor senior management. Certain departments are undervalued and used as a dumping ground for displaced employees. Since the acquisition of HSBC, there seemed to be a sense of entitlement from the legacy Capital One employees with a reluctance to accept and work with the acquired employees. Now that two more of the large sites acquired are being closed and work is being moved to the main corporate location, it's a bit of a moot point.

review_title: Great company with equally good benefits
pros: This place has a tech-company vibe. I appreciate the energy and the enthusiasm my coworkers bring to the table. Above all else, teamwork is paramount at Capital One. The lone rangers and credit-takers don't last here. As far as the benefits, they are very competitive within the banking industry - probably the best of all the big retail banks.
cons: While I feel fairly compensated, others (especially) in more junior roles, may not feel the same. Work hard and move up or negotiate on the way in to manage your compensation appropriately. That should go without saying, but you will find many employees sharing the same disheartening sentiment.

job_title: Principal Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Work life balance was good. Gym was really wonderful and healthy food options were available. There were some interesting, intelligent people working in the company.
cons: Capitalone does not care for career growth. Does not matter how much money I made for Capitalone, I did not get promoted. Sometime I felt racial bias. You would see highly qualified people with MBA, consulting experience doing poorly in the year end calibration process whereas no nothing white undergrad is treated as the master of the universe. Then your manager gets changed every 3-6 months. Capitalone is good as a starting place but one should not stay there more than two years. I made the mistake of staying there close to 4 years and I could not get back those years..

review_title: Not all its cracked up to be
job_title: Process Coordinator II in Richmond, VA
pros: Benefits & pay if you can get a promotion over someone who knows everyone. Once you get to a certain point at Capital One its not what you know its who you know. Also if your an attractive woman you will have more chances to move up.
cons: People, most managers are not properly trained people instead promoted from who they know. Not consistent, some people get away with doing nothing while others struggle and either leave do to stress or get fired. Capital One says if the job don't fit they will help you find the one internally that does, however if your not good at your current role you can't move to a new role so your stuck.

review_title: Mislead Position ,Unsettled  Rules, Not so balanced Friendly
pros:
Work @ Home
Benefits Start in 1st day 
Decent Pay
cons:
Can only Work @ Home in 3 states ( FL, Nevada, Virginia)
No Noise what so ever ( doorbell,pets,baby,lawn care , ringer etc)

Should pay All shifts  more money

If not good call ,possible fire 
Rules change daily

Work Holidays and weekends

review_title: A company built on “rank and yank”
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Competitive salaries.  Benefits.  Mostly great people.  Generous perks.
cons:
Performance management system is the center of work life.  The system is subjective and essentially rewards “suck ups”. Many people in leadership positions who are not qualified to lead or manage. Executives have different rules than the rest of the company.  Think what banking would be like if consultants ran the show. 

You are also fighting others to get the last 10 to 20 percent of your salary. 

In general a the performance management system does not foster cooperation or innovation because everyone is trying to beat out their peers.

review_title: Capital One - Great Place to Work
pros: Compensation, Benefits. Capital One is probably one of the leading financial service companies in terms of pay. I've seen VPs and above at other institutions come to Capital One, receive a lower 'title', yet make significantly more than they were making at their prior employer.  Work is interesting as well, particularly as we attempt to integrate 2 regional banks that we brought within the last couple of years.
cons: Bureacracy.  Capital One got in trouble with Regulators a few years back for the lack of a formalized compliance program, so of course the company did what any institution does in those situations, which is to over-engineer their remediation efforts. This has caused the company to become less nimble and innovative as it used to be.

review_title: I was dissatisfied with my overall experience with Capital One.
pros: Capital One has really good benefits and excellent work life balance. The holidays are a plus because you receive time off for just about all federal holidays, President's Day, Columbus Day, etc., including the national holidays. The yearly bonus is great plus.
cons: The performance evaluation process is not entirely fair. It's highly subjective and promotions are few and far between. Compensation is not below average in the industry (low base pay), however a bonus is given yearly but not guaranteed and it's solely based on your performance evaluation. Re-orgs are constant and at times you could have 2-3 managers in one year, which I think hinders career growth.

pros: The pay was ok, tuition reimbursement, they were very generous with vacation - if you are not a manager, you are started off with 4 weeks and after your 5th year, you get 5 weeks,  the hours in a branch were not bad, the training was the only thing fun about the company, they are involved in the community.
cons: They hire the most incompetent managers , Capital One does not back their lower level employees against management. Capital One is all about sales. Management declines vacation time, there was not room to grow, Capital One is constantly restructuring, eliminating positons. Everything is "management discretion" the guide lines and policies are not followed

job_title: Relationship Banker in Falls Church, VA
pros:
-Bonuses and incentives
-employee benefits, (health insurance was pretty good, PTO was awesome, 5+ yrs get 25 days, tuition reimbursement $5k/yr for two classes for full time employees)
-Policy and procedure guide and call center for employees to help answer questions
cons:
-if you're not into sales, this job is not for you.  This is a very sales oriented position.  
-A lot of steps to take to open accounts, (time consuming), under staff during critical hours, sometimes you have to handle the vault in the lead teller's absence.  
-Hard to take time off bc again, this is a sales position.  
-Can become very stressful
-if you don't make your sales goals or exceed the first tier for certain number of months, you may lose your job.
-Sales points get restructured to make goals harder to reach

review_title: It's high school all over again.
pros: People are great, salary & benefits good. Telecommute/flex time a big plus. Great campus, lots of freedom.
cons:
Performance Management is a disgrace. Promotions based on popularity and how good your manager is at presenting you in discussions. Decisions already made in advance of "360 feedback".

Very political. Pretty young college girls do well and move up, but veterans suffer. Lots of cliques.I did upper-level work for 3 years and never got the offical promotion (or pay).

Much talk about "open culture" and diversity of thought -- but be vocally opposed to something and you're banished from the kingdom.

pros: the actual people that work in the branches are nice and the hours of the branch are not that bad. Tons of training to learn something new. Health plan and dental are great.
cons: Upper management really doesn't know how to succeed. There is no room for advancement because all the hiring for Branch Managers are always from other banks. With the Assistant branch managers being laid off last year, there is no place to go after you are a banker or a lead teller but to move to another bank for a higher position.

pros: 401k match, stock options, full medical and dental, great culture, supportive enviornment. First time working at a call center and one month in Im loving it. I have never had a job where I felt like I've worked their for years in such a short amount of time. Lots of areas around the center to relax and keep our minds relaxed while dealing with the high stess enviornment. People are always ready to help when you dont know something and team building abounds! Opportunities for advancement not only in the center you work but in other states. I enjoy coming to work and so far so good!
cons: High call volume, many layers of management, short breaks, stressful enviornment not for someone who breaks easily with rude customers and non-stop calls. Must be able to mutli-task and bring enegry to every call!

job_title: Manager, Process Management in Toronto, ON
pros:
Very smart associates
Fun and casual culture
Many opportunities to learn many aspects of the business
Many opportunities to take lead on projects if one is proactive and demonstrates initiative
Associates can drive real change in the organization which is  quite different from other financial institutions which prescribe to more traditional top down management culture
cons:
Organization is in constantly changing from re-orgs to back to back major business/tech transformation initiatives. Very hard to get to a well-managed state when the organization is always in flux

We are almost too reliant on our smart associates to problem solve as we are more inclined to be in fire fighting mode in stead of building stable well managed processes

pros: Great campus, mostly nice people on the surface, challenging work, work-life balance. Decent severance package
cons: I (along with many others) was hired a year ago only to be laid off due yet another  restructure/re-org which already happened shortly after I joined.  Capital One should have clear goals when hiring new people who left a former job for a new opportunity.

pros:
- Good work/life balance.
- Great office and equipment.
- Regular fully-expensed trips to Nottingham.
cons:
Upon joining you quickly become mired in endless planning and scrum ceremonies, bookended by talks on numerous corporate initiatives.

Unworkable requirements are simply passed to teams from stakeholders in Nottingham who have remarkably little understanding of the teams in London. Inexperienced managers must then wrestle with these to try and eke out deliverables for stakeholders wedded to unrealistic deadlines.

The graduate scheme is large and there are a limited number of developers able to support them in their development, adding additional pressure on teams.

If you’re looking to grow as a developer I would simply avoid working here. Although Capital One does have good initiatives for learning and development, these can’t make up for the total lack of time spent actually building software.

pros: Great in-house training on all subject matter. Intelligent and diverse employees. Solid performance review process. Excellent compensation and benefits package along with corporate perks.  The primary corporate sites are very high end with a plethora of amenities.
cons: Leadership shifts direction quite frequently. When there is a change in direction, the (lengthy) leadership approval process typically causes work efforts to be placed on hold until approved.  My teams tended to be rigid and too serious during team interactions.  A more relaxed working environment would have increased morale. Many colleagues were constantly concerned about their job security.

pros: Very good company to work for!! Great opportunity for growth and good managers to help you grow in the company! Good benefits and pay!
cons: You have to meet a monthly referral goal, it's not to bad or hard but if you don't like talking to people it can be hard. Also hard being face to face with rude customers at times so you have to have thick skin which this is with any customer service job.

review_title: A great Company in change with lots of bureaucracy
job_title: Senior Product Manager in McLean, VA
pros:
Flexible hours
You can work from home
The ability to work independently
Hiring more change-makers
cons: Even though the company is hiring people who can work independently and who are true innovators, there still a lot of people at the Manager and Director level lacking knowledge and fostering a bureaucratic system. These are the same people that are pushing down the change-makers and problem solvers in avoidance of losing their jobs. They lack strategic skills and vision in their respective areas of expertise and are not up-to-date with current trends.

pros:
- The benefits and concern for employees is amazing 
- Best work-life-balance I’ve ever experienced 
- Lots of training opportunities 
- Lots of ways to get involved
cons:
- The recognition process is a little strange. More trivial things get recognized than major things with substantial customer benefits or company benefits 
- The Cross Calibration process  is theoretically great because everyone gets rated based on a common understanding of how to rank your talent, but you’ll see people refrain from helping because it won’t boost their ranking. 
- You have to be a self promoter- take every opportunity to present  and train if you want to stand out 
- Toot your own horn a lot if you don’t report to someone that’s into recognizing their team members

review_title: Good place to work for money and benefits, though not challenging or satisfying
job_title: Business Analyst in Glen Allen, VA
pros: The money was pretty good, and there are some intelligent people to work with. The work was moderately paced, and the company was not driven to get things done quickly. It was possible to transfer out of a department into another, though it was not easy. A lot of competition with other people, and a lot of politics are needed to get things done, though it seems that no one wants to take responsibility to get anything done.
cons: Too warm and fuzzy, too vague on reviews, and inability of management to take care of people or know what is really going on. Management  only seems to look to what senior managers want, or will do what will get them promoted.

pros: very open-minded (e.g., in terms of sexual orientation etc.); great support system in the branch I worked at; great opportunities for advancement; great health insurance
cons: bad pay for tellers ($9/hr in Louisiana); too much focus on upselling for tellers and bankers; terrible evaluation system for hiring at corporate in Richmond (beware of the behavioral interviews!)

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros:
- Good work environment and great people to work with
- Salary at par with most other banks outside of the top 4 or 5
- For new hires out of college, this is a great place to learn the corporate world as you can set your own pace for the learning curve
cons:
- Harder to get promoted past the mid-management level internally, which results in a high turnover rate for people who have been working for more than a few years
- As Cap One has increased in size it has become more like a bureaucracy and its difficult to get things done fast

review_title: Learned a ton, very talented people, unique culture which suits particular personalities
pros:
Extremely intelligent, driven people
Ability to move around from job to job - which can be unrelated to previous experience (moves are based on skill level, but there's a downside because people can take highly specialized positions without prior experience)
In some areas of the company - great flexibility with work schedule, hours, location - 'future of work' modality
cons:
Salaries and benefits decreased over time to accommodate becoming a bank vs. credit card company, 
Performance management process is cumbersome
Success depends on manager who will fight for you
Inconsistencies in 'flexible work' environment - vary from department to department and individual to individual
Some legacy employees who joined Capital One when very young are still young and in very (too) senior positions

review_title: Overworked, underpaid, good people are often pushed out, incredibly low pay
pros: There were a few excellent people that I worked with on the branch and district level, and the research and adjustments department were always amazing to me.
cons: Made 15,000 a year less than the low end of the spectrum for my position on glass door.  Was illegally denied overtime pay due to a combination of company policy and poor management.  Was harassed repeatedly by manager with little actual recourse to HR.  Common course of business was to significantly understaff branches and then fire staff "for cause" for failing to meet sales and audit goals in the time allotted.

review_title: Competitive work culture and controlling cliques bad for software developers
job_title: Software Developer in Tysons Corner, VA
pros: Competitive salary,  decent benefits
cons: The company rewards competition amongst peers which create a hostile and vicious work culture. In fields where collaboration is crucial for success, such as in software development, the competitive process inhibits creativity, risk-taking, and fails to build support and trust amongst teammates. Cliques of managers work together to give less than average ratings to those outside their circles.  The bar is set high to get in the door then they grade on a curve once you get in. If everyone was very good to begin with then who is graded low on the curve? Those outside the cliques or those who failed to make side deals with key people.

review_title: It's a great job but they try to use you and the pay is not worth it if you're having to drive a long way to work
job_title: Bank Teller I in Monroe, LA
pros: I love my customers!!! You meet a lot of people and you start to learn more about them.
cons: The pay is not worth it still with years of experience is under your belt. There are many many changes from day to day so don't get use  to it.

review_title: Only if you are not ambitious
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Competitive compensation and benefits
- Choice of Mac/Windows
- Choice of company paid Iphone/Android
- Excellent health insurance and RRSP
cons:
- Non technical managers. 
- Lots of pointless meetings.
- Lots of dependencies on US Head Office Richmond.
- Highly Political Environment.
- Brutal Performance Management.

Being Agile is just a slogan to recruit good people here, lots of paperwork, lots of restrictions.
Management doesn't really understand software development. Lot of mismanagement in allocation of resources.

You can survive here if you are not too ambitious about your career. Otherwise this place might hurt your software career in long run.

Politics here are very ugly. Something you need to consider carefully before joining.

pros: Almost always voted within top 100 companies to work for.  Great campus in Richmond, expanding and modernizing as well (gym, upgraded cafeterias, Starbucks, bakery, many on-campus events for employees and families) Driving to become industry leader in banking technologies.  Very strong risk management. If you're driven, capable, and curious, there are opportunities for movement and advancement.  Very good benefits.  Leading the industry for diversity and disability inclusion programs.
cons: CapOne has a unique culture, you either love it or you struggle with it (lots of meetings, very collaborative, direct feedback, love our ppt decks!) To be successful, don't expect 40 hrs a week. I just saw an industry stat that CapOne is ranked #1 for revenue per employee. I.E. -  Do more with less....there seems to always be pressure to streamline, this does create some stress.

review_title: GREAT EMPLOYER and BENEFITS but POOR work-life balance!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Richmond, VA
pros: Everything else is excellent. Benefits are endless. The atmosphere is very friendly and helpful. There are always events and things to do with Capital One. The perks are heavy. I haven't gone through them all
cons: The scheduling and training are TERRIBLE. Pick the right schedule the first time because after that changing is almost impossible and very unlikely.  One employee I spoke with has been there for years and is still waiting for a change in schedule. As for training, you will know the job ON THE JOB. The training will teach you nothing.

review_title: I love my job most of the time.
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: The co-workers are great.  I've worked in several departments and almost everyone is very sharp and good to work with. There's a great focus on work-life balance that is relatively new, and we are given tools and policies to take advantage.
cons: Expectations are very high and it's easy to bite off more than you can chew.  At review time it seems the quality (and quantity) of your work is less important than the projects you were part of.

review_title: TOO MUCH STYLE AND NO SUBTENCE
pros: The compenstation is pretty good and the company has flex time.
cons: The company relies way too much on outside vendors to do the day to day work.    So, the regular employess just manage spreadsheets and meetings and the work done by the various vendors and software and IT companies that acutally do the processing.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Capital One is one of the best places to start a career, because they place a lot of value on development and training.  Campus recruiting starts new hires in an Analyst Development Program that trains job specific skills and provides an avenue to network with peers for the first year at the company.
cons: While the job as a package is very attractive to college graduates just starting out, it is sometimes difficult for Capital One to deliver on its description of job role at the company.  Business analysts are supposed to drive in market strategy, but are sometimes used as a "jack-of-all-trades" to do less intelectually stimulating jobs.

pros:

-company tries to create work-life balance,
-company wants you to feel engaged
-work from home-but depends who is your manager
cons:

-some managers are simply crazy and they will have huge turnover and yet nothing is being done

review_title: Most screwed up place I've ever worked
pros: Good pay and benefits - 7.5% contribution to 401k to your 6%.  $1,000 company contribution to your flex spending account for dependent care or health care.  Reasonable rates for medical.  If it weren't for the strong pay and benefits, I wouldn't have stuck around even a year.
cons: Horrible business processes and systems.  Constant reorganization and restructuring.  No one is willing to step up and make a decision on anything - it's impossible to get things done.  Horrible bonus determination methods - lots of favoritism, and lots of times performance ratings are assigned by someone with almost no knowledge of whom they're rating.

pros: Good benefits and environment.   CEO has a strong vision for the company and making it a tech company.
