Cross-cals are brutal and the ones with better political skills or strong mangers succeed while good engineers struggle with strong ratings.    Attrition rates are already rising for tech employees with the strongest leaving and not the poor performers that you would expect with stack ranking and force distribution.    Tech employees stay away unless you enjoy selling yourself over delivery great product.

review_title: Avoid this place if you want to keep your sanity
pros: Great benefits, clean office and work environment, modern look building
cons:
An extremely toxic work environment. Management are unhappy but still put a smile and pretend this organization is the best place to work. Management are incompetent, yet they have expectations for deliverables and expect you to outerperform so they can suck dry the life out of you. The more you show you are smart, the more work you have to do to continue proving yourself to others... even a that stage and you won't even get a promotion because there are zero advancement opportunities. 

This place is not what it portrays itself to be, leaders back each others up and they always start with initiatives that never finishes or sustainable. Head office does not care about the call centres and people in Toronto believe that they understand operations and always do things in their best interest.

review_title: Not as great as it seems
pros:

* Compensation is OK
* Friendly people
cons:
* Work is very dull, not interesting and filled with horrible corporate process and red tape. As a result, you won't be able to learn much as an engineer.

* Engineers in london are not given the same support as the Nottingham counterparts.

* Performance management is completely unfair. You are not rewarded on you're technical ability and delivery but on how well you sell yourself to senior managers.

* HR is very unhelpful, non responsive and their only interest is to protect the company.

* Hiring is also very biased as well. Again people who are all talk but no substance get hired while actual talented engineers are not taken into consideration. This results in many hires having imposter syndrome.

review_title: Cap One used to be a great place to work for.
pros: Great intelligent people- extremely smart and relaxed. Very good pay and benefits. Flexible work schedule. Capital One used to be truly a great place to work for- it was hard to complain and I think most of the collegues agree on that. Lately, the growth slowed impacting career progression. Plus Cap One is struggling to integrate traditional banks acquired. They do not fit in the legacy culture of Cap One.
cons: Limited carreer growth opportunity. Risk of tough regulations. Profitability not certain which may impact bonus for 2010 and beyond. There is a heavy bonus component 40- 60% at Director level which may be at risk with declining profits in tough economic conditions.

review_title: Below Poverty wages for fortune 100 company.
pros:
Nice employees/co-workers. Average  benefits.
There isn't too much positive to say when a company that makes BILLIONS pays below poverty wages, and just above MINIMUM wage. It's CEO's are paid multi-millions.
cons: This company pays in Portland/Tigard area employees 12.25 hourly, which isn't far above Oregon's minimum wage. Most employees receive government aid such as food stamps to get by. The cost of living in Oregon is far above what one can earn here. Many take the bus and share apartments just to get by. We constantly hear how this company make BILLIONS in profit, and how they are a FORTUNE 100 company, yet they pay wages WAY BELOW the average. Fast food workers and dishwasher make more here in Oregon. They try to sell the company as caring, and constantly give the employees their "Kool-aid". Many  employees have college degrees and prior experience, yet are still paid poorly.

review_title: Company success has moved too fast for employee mindset to keep pace
pros:
Easy workloads, so work life balance is very easy to achieve
Good benefits
Nice work environments
You'll meet some really great people
cons: The company has grown fast. But, the traditional and limited real world experience of its large Richmond employee base has not been able to keep pace. Mind sets are slow to evolve and there's a total lack of real experience, but a mindset that they think they are great and better than everyone around.  A company who grew up in Richmond has to grow up and out of its old ways of thinking or it will be taken over by the likes of smarter and better players like The Wall Street banks.

pros: Great Coworkers, pretty good environment,
cons: Terminated without warning for doing something that was not specified in the employee conduct book. This company lives for having humanity and "changing banking for good" Well there's not much humanity when you terminate someone without warning for an honest mistake, especially with Holiday's around the corner. I thought management was great until I realized that everyone is a snake, just living for a paycheck and will terminate you quick, no advocacy for their employee's but we go above and beyond to advocate for their customers. I was fired and the manager asked me "so how long have you worked here"? with a bright smile, as if he didn't fire me. People are so heartless, I would never do that to a person. You reek what you sew...remember that!

review_title: Great People - Get rid of cross-cals and the bad political behavior it creates

review_title: VM Team - Very Hostile work Environment

review_title: Status quo rises -- swim hard or you'll sink

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Richmond, VA

review_title: This is the most forward miving and tech savvy company i have worked for.

review_title: Tech Savvy Company That Lost It's Focus on It's People - It's Great to Talk About It But Another To Deliver
job_title: Sr Manager Technology in Chicago, IL

review_title: Great place to work until you are signaled out

review_title: Great place to work! Great benefits! Great people!
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Plano, TX

job_title: Lead Teller in New York, NY
pros: Work life balance is pretty much great, the company offers great health/401K/tuition reimbursement, etc.  Managers are generally good, the customers are generally good.
cons: The company is changing its direction very rapidly.  It's closing branches every quarter so you don't know if you're going to be out of a job.  The company just restructured again so we lost all of our assistant managers and district operations consultants.  The company seems to be changing so quickly it's leaving the people who worked so hard for them in the dust.  In order to join capital one you should have a degree in computers/info tech, etc.  That's where the bank is going.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Plano, TX
pros: Medical and Dental are great.
cons:
Our Sr. Leader had told us there is no forced distribution. Well there is. The S curve is there and this what Rich wants. 

Here is the basic break down:

Needs Improvement - Inconsistent: 5-15%
Strong: 20-70%
Very Strong: 1-10%
Exceptional: 0-5%

It does not matter what you do as long as you put something into production. If you're not a developer then there is not a lot of upward movement for you.

If you happen to want to work here ask for all the $ you can. The avg raise is 2% - 3% if you're lucky.

pros: Under Brent Owen, an exceptional work environment, individual goal and team oriented. Promoted and lived customer service, while we tried to "WOW the Fraudsters".  Internal "Agent Feedback Loop (AFL), which maintained an open line of communication between the Agents and upper management.  A number of major, positive policy changes came about through the AFL.,  Well though out, and generous severance package.
cons: Call center environment, mind numbing, repetitive work.  The call center in Tigard, OR, and Sioux Falls, SD shut down in 2015. over 1,000 job gone, replaced by contract employees in South Florida.  a quote from the meeting that shut us down- "We need a more flexible work force for the digital age."

pros:
-good compensation
-good benefits
-employee monetary recognition 
-pretty office
cons:
-management, management, management. horrible managers who micromanage, have very little experience managing people, and do not protect their employees. these managers are willing to throw their own direct reports under the bus to save themselves. 
-very little career growth unless you can gain favouritism - and that is not based on your work, but your likability. If they do not like you based on any part of your personality, you will not succeed
-projects change too much, priorities change and often you may like what you're doing but find yourself moved to a different project, with a different manager without much of a say
-again - horrible management. enough to make you leave.

review_title: When Nigel Left, It all Went To Hell
pros: They are pretty much the only game in town if you want decent pay.
cons: The amount of politics and inter-departmental backstabbing is worse than any company I have ever worked.  We hired a bunch of DC (Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac) sharks who thrive on stamping out new ideas and replacing them with bean counters and yes-men.  The women executives organized their own lobbying group to put more of their own into key positions, as did the GLT (Gay, Lesbian, and Transgendered).  It's just gotten ridiculously out of control.  It is 'Dilbert' on a gigantic scale, and no one has the courage to change it.  Those who have tried, mysteriously end up 'redeployed' (code word for fired).

pros: Looks good on a resume.  So far, there has been opportunity for growth and advancement.  Structured pay ranges level the playing field and add to the fairness factor.  Work environment is conducive to collaboration and fellow staffers are very friendly.  Time off allowances are good if exempt, standard for the hourly.  Benefits are affordable with a variety of options.
cons: Some talking heads, honesty and availability of information from management.  Secret project code names can get in the way, and become distracting to getting the job done.  Benifits could be better, some that are offered are never used.  It would be nice to see the resources redirected a little to offer superior health coverage.

review_title: Fantasitic and wonderful place to work!
job_title: Senior Manager, Extended Operations in Richmond, VA
pros: I really enjoy the flexibilty in work schedules and the total benefits package provided.  The work schedules include condensed schedules and even work from home options.  The benefits package includes great medical, dental, and vision insurance.  There are other benefits that you can use as needed such as commuter plans and educational assistance.
cons: The best of the best work at Capital One, and therefore there is a lot of competition all around which can be high stress. The good news is that this competition can also allow for a creative work enviroment.  Management is well aware of the stress levels and also provide a lot of support.

review_title: Learned a lot - couldn't wait to get out
job_title: Senior Business Manager in McLean, VA
pros: Great learning environment - smart culture that values quantitative approach.  Lots of chances to learn, expand your skills and take classes.
cons:
The culture.  NOT team-oriented at all.  All about making yourself look good at the expense of others.  Stab each other in the back.  Need help - nope, you're on your own.  And they really need to re-evaluate the meaning of the phrase "work-life" balance.  If I had stayed there any longer, I would have gotten divorced.

I wound up taking a job working significantly fewer hours for more money and was much happier working for a company that valued servicing the client over advancing ones career.

pros: Nice facilities in Plano.  Nice cafeteria and good benefits.  Mission is amazing.  Good IT help desk.  High community service culture.
cons:
Even though Capital One was honored again as a top 100 company by Working Mothers, the flexible work arrangements are non-existent in the Financial Services Division in Plano.   There is no telecommuting allowed, working parents are expected to attend after hours daily meetings, leadership meetings, recognition events, etc. after 5 pm.

Agile is the new way of life here.  Flexible work arrangements and other family friendly flexible work arrangements are frowned upon or are not allowed.

pros:
1. Great benefits
2. Employee stock purchase  programs 
3. 3 weeks PTO
4. Diverse environment
5. Constant morale boosters
6. Various Capital One locations in the US
cons:
1. Favoritism
2. I've had a manager only inform one employee about overtime availability. Others were not informed.
3. My manager cheated the team out of their bonus potential. The manager ranked many of us as strong because he said that's the new "Very Strong". He also does not know how to use the systems we do. So how is he able to judge my work, when he can't complete the tasks himself.
4. Difficult transferring within the company. I have about 8 apps that have been declined.

pros: Decent company, good benefits & work/life balance but this deteriorates as you climb the corporate ladder.
cons:
Culture and values aren't consistent throughout the company. Some departments are fabulous at appreciating the employees and promoting great people. Others simply don't, they demonstrate promote and recognize only their friends.
Their calibration process pits all the employees against each other resulting in a ranking from top to bottom. They always need to have employees that are inconsistent but don't always require exceptional ratings.

review_title: Credit Card company in sheep's clothing
pros: Maternity leave, decent benefits, tech savvy, cross-training. I don't have any more pros, just trying to reach the twenty word minimum.
cons: They're clearly steering from human contact, they push credit cards relentlessly, they hire managers who are not only ill-equipped but also have lawsuits against them from other financial institutions. AR is a joke. They do not value their employees and flat out told me that if I didn't like the way my manager  treated me, I didnt have to work for Capital One. I worked for a branch that was closed and I was able to take my severance and move to a bank that values their employees.

review_title: Great Until You Realize You Can’t Move Up
pros: Awesome benefits, work environment, work life balance, campus, and depending on the team - the work is really incredible and meaningful
cons: Leadership is so tenure focused that long time capital one employees have learned how to game the system. Get promoted.... then take it easy for 1.5-2 years then be a try hard for 6 more months. If you are a motivated person that refuses to settle and continues to work beyond what’s asked... then this place will frustrate you. Stay for a bit then get out.

job_title: Capital One Developer Academy Associate in McLean, VA
pros:
Hands down the best job on the market if you want a career in tech, but don't have a computer science background. 

You get paid a FULL SALARY TO LEARN to code for 6 months, which really says something about the economy or society as a whole with our attitude towards STEM, but anyway you can't beat this.
cons: Not anything big. You are in a room with the same people for the entire 6-7 months, which can get a bit claustrophobic.

review_title: Great Team, Smart Engineers in NoVA
job_title: Senior Associate, Software Engineer in Tysons Corner, VA
pros: You get to work with smart individuals without worrying about defense contracts in the NOVA area.
cons: rehydrating clusters to stay compliant with financial regulations is a burden when the onus is on a small team across large tech stacks.

review_title: Great place to work but with alot of "politics".
pros: Very competitive pay and benefits. Onsite amenities (cafeterias, fitness center, health clinic, tennis court, ball field, soccer field, walking trails) are fantastic (they have an onsite Chick Fil A and Starbucks). Challenging work and very open to new ideas. Decent access to Sr Management. Very large focus on development. Excellent place to learn and push yourself. Great opportunities to create.
cons: Very political. Thay talk alot about diversity as long as you fit their model of thought. Starting to get more bureacratic as they transform into a major Bank. They still haven't figured out how to manage costs proactively yet (see above).

review_title: System lacks transparency, performance doesn't count
job_title: Master Applications Developer in Plano, TX
pros: Brand name, onsite be-well center
cons: There is a recent review describing nepotism and I fully agree with that. It's so prominent and constantly demotivates people who are deprived of recognition just because of it . Even though there is a term of 360 feedback but it's just on paper. In reality, neither HR nor management bother about the actual performance or real feedback from team and peers but completely rely on the statements of supervisor. System lacks transparency and if supervisor is not honest, only option is to move on instead of dealing with frustration.

pros: Awesome to place to begin your career - Dynamic company that genuinely wants to do the right thing - Challenging and fast paced - Always, always striving to do things better
cons:
Change is a lays afoot, so you will likely have multiple managers each year

While I believe Capital One wants to cares about their associates, ultimately it's all about results

When Capital One decides to move in a direction, it goes all in - without fully thinking through consequences

The Marketing & Analytics team (M&A) team runs Capital One.  If you are not from M&A, your future is limited once you reach middle management.

review_title: Come for the work, stay for the people!
pros: Capital One's culture of "excellence" and "do the right thing" creates such open, autonomous and empowering environments.  It's so refreshing to be surrounded by smart, capable and diverse people who look for better ways to deliver great products for our customers.  The flexibility in schedule and work environment is key to balance.
cons: There is constant organizational change that disrupts both business value, associate morale and customer experience. The communication and change management associated with these types of changes is mediocre and must be improved. Tons of opportunity for improvement here.

pros: Pay and benefits are good for the area.  My coworkers were mostly great.  There's lots of opportunity and resources for self-training.  The campus is really nice, though the open office floorplan leaves much to be desired.
cons: Data documentation is nonexistent.  If you're thinking about joining because of how they want to "transform" the DA role and technologies - don't bother, they're not doing that, all you will do is write SQL.  Go somewhere else where you'll get a better title and better experience for your resume.  Your manager is very important to your career here.  Unfortunately, just because you have a great one doesn't mean you won't get reorged into a worse one.

review_title: Great Place to Work in Info Tech.
pros: Capital One really cares about all of it's associates. There are a ton of incentives and associate intramural activities. You can expect several social events and also community volunteer events. They are flexible on hours which helps with the life work balance. I've never worked for a place with better management. This place is amazing!!
cons: My only Con of Capital One is that it's a far drive for me.... but that's my problem. Capital One is also always in a constant state of change. It's not a con from me, but some people don't sit well with constant change. If you like constant routine, this probably isn't the place for you.

pros:
-Great Benefits
-In Richmond location, nice amenities (cafe, bank, pharmacy)
-Everyone is intelligent - great people
-If you find a good people manager, it will take you far
cons:
-No opportunity for advancement
-No work/life balance - 60-70 hours/week is expected not an exception
-People Managers do not take active part in career growth
-Highly competitive - focus is on cut throat people competition which makes building trust an oxymoron
-Performance management is not based on facts but rather who you know and how well your "liked"

review_title: Great company, but can become a bit suffocating.  And a young company.
pros:
A lot of oppotunities and a young feeling company.  I got to work in France, USA and Madrid in my role.  Some peopel there are very good and there is a collective energy in the office which makes working there a pleasure.

There is a lot of fun in the office with a fun budget where every quarter you get a day out paid for by the company (bowling / meal / day out doing something etc)
cons: Obsessed by soft skills, sometimes forgetting about the core work itelsf.  Also some management were promoted, put in management of people positions who were very poor people skills.

review_title: Great company with a very good people culture but industry is going through massive upheaval
job_title: Director, Marketing and Analysis in Richmond, VA
pros:
- Great culture
- Meritocracy where people are  awarded for what they do not who they know
- Data driven decision making with good judgment applied
- Very good benefits
- Good pay / great pay if you are a high performer
- Great company name to have on your resume - highly respected by other employers
- Work hard play hard culture - good work life balance
cons:
- Industry is going through major challenges and will make banking and credit cards harder than ever
- Capital One brand is limiting from a customer standpoint
- If you are not analytical you will have a hard time succeeding at this company

pros: For the first time in my 20 year career, I am treated as an adult.  The policies in place all support the employee and their ability to get work accomplished.  We are encouraged to structure our work in the manner that makes us most comfortable.  Benefits are generous, and there are ample opportunities to move within the company should one outgrow a role.
cons: I felt the base salary was low, but I was switching gears somewhat, which makes it hard to judge.  Other than that, I haven't found any downsides -- I'm DELIGHTED here.

job_title: Senior Business Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Lots of great things about the company, some of the things I like most are:
- Extremely smart and competent people to work with and learn from
- Complete empowerment to associates at all levels 
- Very young, highly energetic, and collaborative culture
- Culture encourages debating different points points of view 
- Very open top management with a lot of respect for people at all levels
- Very balance work/life balance for their level of compensation
cons:
No place is perfect and Capital One is no exception:
- Main focus is on developing and rewarding analytical skills and less on leadership development
- Growth opportunities are started to become limited 
- Hard to differentiate yourself amongst such a great group of smart people leading

job_title: Fraud Intake Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: the benefits other than health, your getting a paycheck and not standing in the unemployment line
cons: pay, management is horrible especially in HVSD department in Tampa, there is only one good manager in this department that everyone cross the board feels is fair and manager material, the favoritism is ridiculous I have never seen anything like it and yes every company has this but this place and department takes the cake, some people get written warnings others get a pass which keeps the morale very low, mostly everyone is unhappy but pretends to be happy. Upper management could care less what goes on and seem to cater to the bullies and troublemakers, as long as the numbers are good they could care less.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: Work from home. Benefits. If you need something to hold you over while waiting for something better.
cons: Very mismanaged company. Specially with their work at home core dept. Advancement is oportunities are minimal. They will change your schedule without your consent with a weeks notice. Started in a class of 20 and 6 months later 7 were remaining. Every employee is micro managed. Could be there for a couple of years and all of the sudden you can recieve a phone call telling you that you are no longer employed there without an explanation! Managers heve their favorite employees who they favor more than others. Oh and if you leave involuntary or voluntary you will recieve a letter by mail months later asking you to pay your vacation back.Thats not all. If you leave involuntary they will lie about the reason why you were terminated so you dont get unemployment. Hahaha What a joke of a company.

review_title: Great Place to Work, Awesome Benefits
pros: The campus and buildings are beautiful in Richmond. The salary and benefits are among the best in the Richmond market. Most everyone I have worked with is high performing employee, that wants to do what is best/right. Everyone is dedicated to doing excellent work and focusing on constantly improving things. The company provides it's employees with the tools to do any job right.
cons: A very competitive environment. Employees are rated and forced into distribution (a bell curve). The problem is that some areas have such few employees at a particular level that they're forcing a distribution on less than 10 people. Like most large companies there are some politics and it can be hard to get things done. Meetings have overrun this place.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Fast growing in SF. Great office spaces, resources, and culture (in the SF offices). Benefits are amazing. It's not a typical stuffy bank environment and the company is focused on disrupting the bank industry.
cons: HQ based in DC so it can be hard to push things forward quickly if working with colleagues from corporate HQ. The SF culture is vastly different from the corporate culture in DC. DC associates don't seem to understand the growth in SF and what digital teams are trying to accomplish.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros: Good: The benefits are really great (401 K is one of the best in class), Health insurance is OK. flexibility in working from different locations within and outside the company. Very informal and relaxed work culture. People are very talented and are helpful.
cons:
Cons: No work-life balance for some groups (M&A, CM) with too much work and no work in others (ops). Lot of good  work was been scrapped on the whims of middle management.

Middle management: (Directors, sr. directors) are incompetent bunch and are more in numbers than required. Many are very talened but  have no people management skills.

Performance reviews should be more transparent but ends up being a blame game to pass Project lead's and sponsors' incompetence to the team members.

pros:
Love the environment, people, management, resources, and the constant food they provide. 
It is mostly a fun environment where you can develop yourself and listen to your peers, help your peers and management, strive to learn and reach out to management who will help you establish a good career in the company. 
Great benefits.
Good pay... Could be a little bit better.
cons:
Upper management needs to listen to people and don't take others idea and make it their own by tweaking it a little bit. 
Favoritism in few departments.

review_title: Company with no vision for the Capital One Bank
pros: Great Medical, Dental and Vision benefits
cons:
Layoff is the order of the day. There is a regular massive layoff due to what the senior leadership describe as 'restructuring'. Capital One is so convinced they will lay people off regularly that they have a Career Development Center office in their Richmond location and works with a company called LHH to help their laid off employees transition out of the company.

Additionally, the annual  employee performance review is not based necessarily on how well you have performed over the past year but how you compare to others in the same level but who may not be doing anything related or close to what you are doing. Your annual bonus depends on how well your manager can represent you in the presence of other managers and/or how well or badly everybody in your level did over the previous year.

review_title: Flexible work arrangement, but too many re-orgs
pros: Impressive flexible work schedule. People all have different work schedule, people pick up at 2 pm in the afternoon and tells me they have to pick up their kids. Really great place for working moms. Good health benefits, great 401K (up to 7.5% of your salary), average paid time off, great on-site cafeterias with healthy options, on-site gym.
cons: Unwillingness to change or accept new ideas (even for the better), too many re-orgs and layoffs (not based on performance), interesting performance review style, too many meetings, inefficient (takes forever to do something, gazillion ineffective meetings before something is approved), promotions hard to come by unless you're a super star. There are people who have been here for 20 years and is still a principal!

review_title: Easy work, good pay but hard to advance
pros: Good pay, great experience with a Fortune 200 company and a very recognizable Brand.  If you are looking to build your resume as a brand strategist and get great hands on learnings the Brand Department is good.
cons: Too many lifers, too top heavy, narrow thinking and passive aggressive management. No one leaves and Capital One does like firing people so there are very limited spaces at the top of the department.  I have been a 'top performer" for 3 year, getting the highest bonus you can but still not advancing.

review_title: It all depends who is the manager
pros:
If you land with a good Manager, the growth will be high.
Work culture is very good.
cons:
Performance review is a joke. The managers behave like gods. If you have an issue with the manager, then talking with internal HR or Associate relationship is waste of time.

In some departments, like commercial IT, the IT senior leadership is not really capable of interpreting the technology clearly. There is a lot of show off, precedence but really lacks computer science part. Those people who makeup things and bluff the achievements can progress much faster. However, the production and infrastructure teams will end up owning the poor implementations and suffer a lot to maintain it.

pros: Leading edge, cares for customers and employees, great benefits, lots of opportunities to learn and advance, fantastic facilities, lots of very smart people to work with, very professional place.
cons: People are very cordial and don't say what is on their minds. This leads to misinterpretations.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros:
Nice working environment, although has declined 
On the face of it, relatively exciting business, but far too many poor decisions have been made of recent
Good work life balance, 9-5:30
cons:
Leadership team presence has declined and the engagement of associates has fallen
Morale fluctuates and leadership skim over the fact when it's poor
Talks about diversity but there is very little of it in the UK business
Strategy has slowed drastically and is very slow to get anything done
Extremely cliquey, some hard workers go years without promotion, others with a face that fits get promo quickly
There are managers in the business that do not deserve to be there

review_title: Fraud Specialist II in St. Cloud
pros:
I've heard bad things about call centers, but I was actually impressed with the management and the company. The facility is gorgeous and right downtown St. Cloud. They push you into the deep end quick, but honestly, it's the best way to learn.

I learned a ton and the benefits are fantastic. My studies didn't lead me to work in fraud, which is why I left.

Great opportunity for people at SCSU since they cover a large portion of tuition.
cons: It's a call center - Capital One isn't the problem, people calling in are. Not a lot of room for advancement in St. Cloud since headquarters is in VA. Advancement is largely a function of performance measurement, e.g. short call times.

review_title: Local management was very good, Corporate withheld and misleading
pros: Capital One compensated well.  The ability to take needed time off for family situations were extremely flexible. The crash of the mortgage market did not help.
cons: The same downsides as working for any corporate company.  The meetings that resulted in a ton of work, then come to find out all that work was a smoke screen.

review_title: Local management was very good, Corporate withheld and misleading
pros: Capital One compensated well.  The ability to take needed time off for family situations were extremely flexible. The crash of the mortgage market did not help.
cons: The same downsides as working for any corporate company.  The meetings that resulted in a ton of work, then come to find out all that work was a smoke screen.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros:
Exceptional culture, everyone seems to really enjoy working here. Great benefits, work-life balance, and  Inspirational senior management have the company headed in the right direction. Lots of very smart employees that are excited to work there. 

Strong focus on employee learning and development, career growth, and diverse experience to find the right fit for you.
cons:
This company is behind the ball digitally. Old systems and IT infrastructure make data-based decision making difficult to come by, especially in certain departments. 

The culture is not as "open" as they would like you to believe. People don't speak their mind for fear of retribution. 

Strong bureaucratic environment, tons of processes that make accomplishing anything substantial very difficult.

review_title: Capital One has provided a great environment for me to develop professionally and to sharpen my technical skills.
pros:
Associates are encouraged to "Live the values" by volunteering in the community, helping others internally, and giving back to open source projects.

Capital One fosters technical development with ample growth opportunities and encouragement to take ownership of your own development.

The pay is very competitive. The benefits are comprehensive including very generous 401k automatic contribution and matching.
cons: It's challenging to "Live the values" by helping others and being selfless while also endorsing yourself to be competitive in cross-calibration for performance management.

review_title: Capital One knows that they are asking you to do a demanding job.
job_title: Fraud Account Supervisor in Tampa, FL
pros:
They actually try to make you feel welcome when you become employed. They care about your well being and do a lot to make sure that even when you are being screamed at by customers that you have outlets to be okay. 
They feed you all the time.
They make sure that morale is up with all of the competitions and prizes they can give you.
cons: Customers are absolutely terrible and you cannot defend yourself in anyway. They are the worst part of the job.  I do not know how to explain how bad the card holders are, especially as a supervisor in the Fraud Department.

review_title: make the shareholders more than happy!
pros: Large cap and stable company with strong benefits. Not afraid to mix it up with the big banks. Offers self-directed investing platform
cons: One flavor of the month was for us to be "locally devistating". If that doesn't pump you up then try working for 7 branch managers in less than the same number of years. Now that is devastating. Growth only through playing the political game. If you are looking to work here make sure that you polish and hone your political skills to maybe get a shot at a promotion.

pros: Great atmosphere, leadership at the top has great vision and ideas. Tons of very bright peple looking and willing to do the right thing
cons: Failure by senior most leaders to measure the affects of their changes on the people that do the work. There are also a few there who harbor ill will towards any who disagree and take great pains to run them out (even though we are suppossed to Disrupt and challenge). The company also fails to properly budget and forecast which leads to massive layoffs (or what is currently being labeled as a change in focus).

job_title: Senior Business Manager in McLean, VA
pros: Capital One has a fantastic work environment.  Super smart people all around you, in additional to top notch benefits and work space.  Highly recommended for marketing / credit corporate functions.
cons: It can be difficult to get things done at COF.  Multiple rounds of review, multiple senior stakeholders who need to approve (oftentimes unclear who the decision makers really are, if you're Director or below) can delay getting things done.  Be prepared to wait around for executives to make decisions and for the operations team to take months upon months to ship a new strategy.

review_title: Middle management needs a lot of work!
pros:
- Competitive compensation (e.g. Benefits, base, signon bonus, RRSP matching, vacation days and personal days).
- Flexible work from home options and depending on the team, good work life balance.
- Office space is brightly lit and lot's of natural lighting. Plenty of meeting rooms and collaboration spaces. Now there are standing desks and Macbooks available.
- A selection of foosball tables, ping pong table and TVs for watching games with coworkers.
- Free goodies (e.g. Tea, coffee, occasionally food).
- Plenty of committees to join (e.g. Fun Committee, Philanthropy Committee, Asian Committee).
- Casual dress code.
- Various Fun Days or company social events throughout the year.
- Coworkers are generally intelligent and hardworking. Have met some really nice people and even made some friends. People are usually open to helping and connecting with you.
- Senior leaders are friendly and relatively approachable (e.g all hands, office hours, walking around the office).
cons:
- Lot's of bullying in the office by middle management that are not addressed through HR policy or by senior management (e.g. coercion, pranks, humiliation, tolerance of inappropriate behaviour). 
- Rampant favoritism that is counter to its claims of meritocracy. Very obvious in-group and out-group dynamic. 
- 360 degree reviews are now gone so performance review is more of "he said she said" and whether you are on the good side of certain key players. 
- Managers don't know how to coach or develop. Just provides passive aggressive "advice" to keep you in check of your "development plan". 
- Everyone seems nice but will go behind your back to complain to your manager/others. No one really cares about your development like the company claims unless it helps he/she get promoted. 
- Overemphasis on the charming and extroverted personality as a factor to success. 
- Lack of focus and forward momentum in the strategic direction of the company. 
- Things are poorly documented and very poor training in general so good luck with your own onboarding!
- Pressure to spend a lot of time, whether you like it or not, to "socialize" with your peers above and beyond what is reasonable for a professional relationship. 
- Better to keep your mouth shut about issues in the workplace because it will probably get back to you and you will be the one who gets penalized (this includes the many many "employee" surveys that you are asked to fill out).

review_title: High potential ruined by poor management structure and cult-like atmosphere
pros:
-Potentially good culture
-Smart people
-Competitive salary
cons:
- Your progression is highly dependent on the manager you get, people leaders are promoted based on performance instead of ability to actually manage others so you have a lot of managers who have low EQ and can't develop their associates
- Advertised work-life balance only applies to ~40-50% of the company, long hours otherwise
- All the truly good associates and smart people leave
- Zero diversity of thought, and expectations not baked in reality - likes to pride itself on being a strong competitor and a "fintech" company but in reality is severely lagging behind the big 5 banks on market presence and isn't doing anything about it

review_title: Capital One - I enjoy getting up and coming into work each day!
pros:
I am very satisfied with the benefits of the company - matching 401K, discounted stock purchase, and more vacation and personal days than I have ever been able to take in one year!
Management also encourages working remotely, another perk. 
I am also very satisfied with the salary AND bonus structure. 
The other associates are very helpful, friendly and great to work with.
Capital One has plenty of growth opportunities within the organization. It's up to you where you want to take your career! Although I have held the same position for several years now, I feel confident that I could find another position within the company.
cons: There really aren't any downsides to working at Capital One.

pros: Generally a good company, in terms of the big ones.  Has had a history of alienating its people over the past 6 years as it has had to adjust its busienss to slower growth, but you have to regard Capital One as having a fairly good and human approach to these changes.
cons: Financial sector is tough - and credit cards is not growing - so this is an environment where the people you work with really matters, and the person you work for is hugely important.  Cultures within the firm do very widely, so it is best to go and see the different departments for yourself if you can.

pros: Great facility. Great Talent. Excellent teamwork. Awesome opportunity for increasing industry experience.
cons: As a contractor, beware of the potential for abrupt pay cuts under the auspice of AT WILL work laws, BAD ECONOMY budget cuts and employment pools. Senior Managers and work group leads in certain (but not all) groups are extremely belligerent in their disrespect towards contractors. In certain circumstances, mid-level managers provide disingenuous feedback to augment their performance as it relates to problem resolution and personal/group production. The VITALITY CURVE approach to performance management turns this potentially outstanding company into an extremely stressful work environment outfitted with the fear of job losses and reprimands.

review_title: Good balance of stimulating environment, good pay and decent hours
pros: The recruiting process is fairly stringent, so the people you end up working with are of high caliber. A great part of the culture is the 'fun' element and even senior managers do not take themselves too seriously. Makes for a highly enjoyable environment where people focus on delivering results while making sure they are enjoying themselves.
cons: Within certain groups (esp. marketing) there is quite a lot of competition among employees, with plenty type-A people pushing ahead to get promoted as fast as possible and ahead of everyone else.

pros: Great place to work - they treat their employees really well in terms of benefits and flexibility. The culture is definitely one of work life balance. Many areas of the company will allow you to work from home if needed and they are very flexible with allowing you to take time off whenever you want to. In terms of the working environment, you are given a lot of responsibility early on, and your opinion is valued and trusted even if you are at a lower level in the company.
cons: Promotion seems to be slow in comparison to other companies. I have seen multiple people leave Capital One and come back later at a much higher level/pay than they could have achieved by staying at Capital One the whole time.

pros: Benefits are hard to be beat! 401K match, FSA contribution, and PTO rather than vacation/sick time. The values are good, but they are not put in place my management so what is the point in having them?
cons: Management is unprofessional and extremely difficult to work with. I'm sure that's not the case in every dept but it has definitely made me consider going elsewhere. It's almost impossible to be promoted too - even for top performers. Appears to be the only way to move us is to quit and be rehired. Bad business practice.

review_title: Great partners at Capital One Bank.
job_title: Insurance Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Many of the Bankers, Branch Managers, Financial Consultants and TELLERS believed in insurance.  They knew that I was the only knowledgable and competent insurance agent many of their clients would ever have a chance to meet and I got to help many people who needed my services.  The Bankers and other partners uncovered these needs and made the introductions!
cons: I didn't get to meet as great a variety of the Bank clients as I would have liked.  There was no mandate to introduce, I only got to meet the "low hanging" fruit so to speak.  There were many opportunities that were left "un-met".

pros: Flexible work schedules and opportunities to learn and contribute to the overall success of Capital One.
cons:
About 75% of employees are contractors with low wages remaining stagnant for the past 20 years and no benefits.  If there are benefits offered by the 20 to 35 agencies, the deductibles are prohibitively too high and having such benefits will immediately make your salary equivalent to minimum wages.

There is high job turnover as employees have the good fortune to find employment elsewhere that does have competitive living wages rather than subsistence wages.

review_title: Great place to start Software Development career
pros: Capital One stays at the forefront of new technology. In the tech side of the company they are always encouraging associates to implement the newest technologies and they will provide support along the way. The company culture is also phenomenal. They really do care about your growth as a software engineer and associate within the company.
cons: Because there are so many tech teams in Capital One Tech you may find yourself in a role that may not suit your interests. However, management is awesome when it comes to hearing your concerns and placing you somewhere you want to be.

review_title: Software engineering company that happens to be in the Banking industry
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Wilmington, DE
pros: This is not like working for a normal bank.  Capital One sees itself as a software company and it shows in where they are putting their time, effort, money and recruiting into.  You are given the freedom to come up with creative technology solutions.  They encourage  use of open source tools and looking for the best solution.  Pretty relaxed atmosphere.  Lots of room in the organization to try different roles out.
cons: The performance review process creates a very competitive culture.  You are looking for ways to make yourself stand out from the group and it can take away from the Agile team approach.

review_title: Great company in need of strong leaders that will communicate up and down the organization.
job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Wilmington, DE
pros: Growing company, focused on a digital future, 100% green energy consumption. Great benefits and work-life balance. Company genuinely cares about employee engagement in and out of the office. Huge commitment to employee-driven community investment.
cons: For a large financial institution, the salaries could be more competitive. Still going through the pains of expansion and growth. Instability in certain departments. Technology groups in need of consistent leadership that can communicate across different fields.

review_title: The benefits and perks are pretty good.
pros: The Benefits, and perks. Opportunities for growth often available.
cons: Management is a challenge, poor HR. Can be stressful at times.

pros: TDP program is great for college students who don't know what they want to do in the IT field outside of college. Great work / life balance, never expected to work an unreasonable amount, but there are times where you will more than 40 hours.  Awesome benefits
cons: Promotions can be hard to come by, still uses a bell curve and relies heavily on the opinion of higher-ups. Can have the feeling of a big company with a lot of red tape when it comes to trying to get innovative ideas accomplished

review_title: Strictly business, don't take it personally.
pros:
Good people, good management at the middle and associate level. Good place to work, as long as you are in a big center, especially Richmond. 
Management makes everyone feel valued, until it is time to reduce staff or close a site. As long as you remember that no one is irreplaceable and it's nothing personal, you'll be fine.
cons:
Capital One legacy and Richmond-based employees are favored, though many good people have come with acquisitions over the years. 
Cross-training is emphasized and people are shifted around in some departments, regardless of expertise, resulting in damaged trust in support departments.
Communication from top down could be better.

job_title: Technical Product Owner in Arlington, VA
pros:
- Extremely analytical and intelligent work force
- Competitive pay and benefits
- Extremely competitive.
cons:
- Frequent restructuring, leading to elimination of roles.  However, there is time to find a position internally and the severance package is quite generous. 
- Performance management cycle  is dysfunctional 
- Senior Leadership has little vision beyond a couple quarters.  Hence the frequent workforce restructuring.

pros: Benefits and salary are top-notch. Buildings and grounds are beautiful. Incredibly smart people work there. There are some groups that are doing great work and actually live the values that Capital One espouses.
cons: Work/life balance doesn't exist, even though they tout it. It's more that certain people in certain groups are able to have that, but it's not guaranteed. It's a crap-shoot whether or not the area that any one person works in is a good one or not, and that is likely to change at a moment's notice. Obviously the frequent cycle of layoffs.

pros: Great benefits, diversity driven, and AMAZING people to work with! A variety of development opportunities to attain certifications.
cons: There are constant reorganizations of departments within the company which don't give you enough stability with the constant layoff for tenured associates.

review_title: Smart people, competitive pay, good upward mobility
pros:
- Consistently worked with smart and capable people.  
- There's a pretty good amount of openness and transparency in general and leadership tends to include their teams in decisions.  -
 - Offer competitive pay, great benefits (cheap, high quality healthcare, 7.5% 401k match when you put in 6%, 15% discount on stock purchase up to 15% of your salary).  
- It's great to have a gym ($15/month) and primary care facility (for free) right at the headquarters.  
- They do a pretty good job promoting from within, especially at the junior and mid-senior levels (good upward mobility)
- Really nice facilities in general (bright, open, colorful, fun, good food)
- Focus on doing the right thing for customers instead of squeezing every dollar of profit out of the company
- Founder-led approach results in a focus on long term investment vs. just trying to hit investor goals
cons:
- Can be political (both corporate politics and insertion of national politics into the workplace).  From a corporate politics perspective, advancement can be highly dependent on who you work for and what projects you end up working on.  From a national politics perspective, with the HQ being just outside of DC, employees tend to lean pretty far to the left and are not shy about it.  Politics are discussed often and it's not uncommon to be asked questions like "who did you vote for?"  I've seen this result in favoritism based on whether or not you have the same beliefs.  Big no-no.
- Promotion of good do-ers into management positions.  There are way too many cases of people in management positions because they were good producers.  A good analyst rarely translates into a good manager.  
- Death by meeting - seriously - I would guess that at least 50% of meetings I was invited to were either completely unnecessary or very minimally applicable to me.
- Pains from rapid growth still exist.  Tons of separate systems.  External example: just look at the consumer product logins on the website.  It's been 5 years since the ING acquisition was completed and customers with a traditional Capital One checking or savings account still aren't integrated with the Capital One 360 products/services (formerly ING Direct)
- Major locations are generally in the suburbs so there aren't a lot of options if you want to walk to grab food, do a happy hour, etc.  Most things involve driving.  This is mitigated by them providing just about everything you need on campus but it sometimes you just want a change of scenery.
- Not many options for work locations unless you want to be in either Richmond, VA or McLean, VA.  Richmond is small and isolated and McLean has an insanely high cost of living and terrible traffic.
- Hard push for diversity recruitment sometimes results in great candidates being passed up to meet a quota 
- Performance management system is based much more on time at a certain level than actual performance.  For example, you pretty much have to move a mountain to get anything higher than a "strong" rating in the cycle following a promotion.  They do performance management on a bell curve, which means that for every person with a high rating there has to be a person with a low rating.  Isn't the goal to have every employee perform as highly as possible?

pros:
-Really nice training!
-Chance to work with the new technologies
cons:
-The politics! A lot of back stabbers there so watch yourself and get everything in writing
-Performance review process is archaic and causes a lot of incentive problems!
-Everyone is afraid while working here so be careful what you say to who.
-Retaliation is a major concern  at COF

review_title: HR will run this company into the ground
pros:
- CapitalOne US is great, Canada - not really!
- $$$. Clueless Hiring Managers + Recruiters end up offering most salaries (as long as we're in line with the higher US salaries!) at around 80 p - that is 30% above market. If you get an offer as an experienced hire, go high and they will likely give it to you because they dont know what theyre doing. Youll need it too, because unless youre willing to join the long human centipede of people s**king each other off, you wont really get promoted and will quickly fall behind 
- Young workforce: can be a fun environment, One word of warning: everyone is sleeping with everyone else at this place.
- Great place to get your feet wet for a year and a half and bounce, because unless you're part of the special club, you are unlikely to advance at the company.
cons:
- Shady HR practices: this HR department is incomparable. I have always had great disdain for HR people - but the group here takes the cake. Recruitment is the worst, but then it continues on through to Leadership, who are typically doing nothing more than spewing sound bites from articles they read on Linkedin about the latest "trend" - all without any actual knowledge behind any of what they're saying
- Lord of the Flies culture: someone doesnt like you or perceives you as a threat? Get ready to be manipulated and lied about behind your back so that the backstabber can get ahead
- Delegate delegate delegate. The minions sitting at the top keep distributing work down to the ones underneath, and they all work mindlessly towards arbitrary goals that go nowhere - because there is really no accountability save for when people are souping up their performance assessments for promotion calibration - the best blow(out) gets the biggest promotion!
- In a nutshell - pretty toxic a workplace. Do yourself a favor and go to a real tech firm

job_title: Senior Development Manager in McLean, VA

pros: I work were I am for two reasons. The location is good for my daughter and how close I am to her school and the family work/life balance. I am able to get my daughter from school and bring her to work or take off when either of my children are sick with no questions asked.

People are friendly when they want soemthing either personal or professional. No one likes to help out. pros: Excellent benefits, salary is decent for most positions, flexible work from home arrangements, generous paid time off, great tuition reimbursement plans.

job_title: Senior Fraud Account Supervisor in Tampa, FL

And free coffee, not French Vanilla, but free!
cons: I can only say great things about this great company!

review_title: Great place to work, but some issues
job_title: Technical Program Manager in Nottingham, England

pros:

So apply directly to Capital One

review_title: An eye-opening experiencing to how a different company operates
job_title: Senior Associate, Digital in Richmond, VA
pros: Amazing employee benefits and resources. Well-communicated agenda and ambitious outlook that is infectious.
cons:
A very process-bloated organization.  An elaborate network of people/processes/initiatives that they think 'ensures' high quality results (speaking from the Digital side).  Being a (primarily) credit-card oriented company, the work pipeline is looked at from a capacity/operational perspective and cannot be tied directly to revenue.  I come from an IT/Software vendor where work was done right the first time, and FAST - because it was tied directly to revenue.

The meeting culture here is bizarre.  My previous company had a high ratio of remote workers, so we EFFECTIVELY used email and stuck to conference calls to get decisions moving.  Here, half the people in my meetings aren't paying attention and busy instant messaging about something else.  The meetings end up with little to no headway and always include the words, "it sounds like we need to have more conversations about...".  I'm not exaggerating.  The worst part is that these people can't be in my meetings because they're double booked in someone else's.  All the while, mine was TRULY more important to the organization than the one they attended.  So, two meetings are shot while one of them could've been dealt with via email in a smart manner.  Every time I craft comprehensive well-written emails, people want to set up a meeting to discuss because they don't want to take the time to read it and think it through.  These are all smart people working here.  They are all brainwashed into this ADD pace of perpetual confusion.

review_title: Lots of promise, some positive intent, poor execution
pros: Work life balance. Innovative and industry-leading work in some areas (but not outside of the core front line businesses)
cons:
I have never seen a company offer so much promise based on its reputation, and then succeed in beating the potential and enthusiasm out of highly capable people. I have worked at several companies during my career and see the specific problems at Capital One as:
1) "Tell me what I want to hear" - the senior-most leaders are so sure that "what got them here will get them there" that they only want to listen to people who use the exact same kind of language, communication style, and ideas. 

2) The emperor has no clothes - This follows from #1 above. Leaders don't want to  listen to ideas from people who have gained expertise in other banks. They are rewarded for being generalists and lack depth of expertise - yet they do not want to leverage the people who do have that expertise, for fear they'll be overshadowed.

3) Lack of maturity in people leadership  -  Little weight is placed on the maturity of  people leadership skills and talent development, even at the executive levels. This leads to short-sighted org decisions, lack of investment in talent hired from the outside, and external hires at all levels feeling like they're not fully utilized or challenged.

4) Performance management - claims to be objective and transparent but is very susceptible to favoritism and disproportionately rewards loyalty above other factors. Old timers at the company heavily favor other old timers.

5) Cultural hubris - Only Capital One experience counts. Only Capital One has a "high bar for talent". Skills built at other institutions aren't recognized and made use of.

They don't care about work/life balance.  Forget about having a free Saturday!  All they care about is having more numbers, numbers & more numbers.  I saw a lot of people put into uncompromising positions.  They made doing what's right for customers more difficult everyday.  Glad to no longer work there!!!
