review_title: Great Culture, still getting established as a bank, technology sucks
pros: The environment is great, they treat employees right, company events, competitive products.
cons: The technology is very outdated, everyday tasks are very tedious and lots of paper work, no imaging system, lots of paperwork to print out and have to keep track of, system is antiquated, have to use 3 separate systems to figure out a simple request. Online banking is also outdated cannot have the same login for credit cards and deposit accounts, don't have actual partners in branch such as mortgage and business, one financial advisor in Houston, Book of business is new to company and  is hard to navigate compared to other institutions.

review_title: Overall a good place to work.
job_title: Risk Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: The benefits are great. Health benefits are available upon your hire instead of making you wait 90 days. PTO is available after 90 days. Lots of opportunity to advance within your department and also to move to other departments. Classes and computer based training made available to learn or improve skills. Managers work well with employees to move onto new positions or to obtain promotions.
cons: I have noticed that some managers will not provide employees with feedback concerning their performance and will either penalize or terminate that employee. Bonus pay out for some call center jobs means despite having a great month, your bonus may be small if your department is set up on a tiered/competitive system.

job_title: Multi Branch Senior Relationship Banker in Woodbridge, VA
pros: Capital One cares about it's employees and it shows with the amazing benefits and perks. They also care about their customers which is evident in the execution of their mission statement, customer service, and product offerings. Innovative in every shape and form. An absolute fantastic organization to be affiliated with. One of the few large companies that doesn't lose sight of what is most important.
cons:
Constantly evolving and changing...could be a con, could be a pro. Sometimes it can be difficult to keep up with the integration of new acquisitions and constant changes as they drive forward at lightning speed to be the innovator of finance, credit, and technology.
The pay structure seems to be evolving into one that is more complacent and less competitive.

review_title: Great Company - Poor District Level Leadership
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great benefits for all company divisions, plenty of opportunities to grow with company, dedicated to associate development, the card division and corporate setting is where the company earns all its high marks for associate satisfaction
cons: retail banking in the northeast lacks positive, consistent and effective leadership, low pay for mid level bank associates - example bankers paid approximately $5000-$10,000 less than the competitors. retail banking does not have the staff to effectively give the net promoter service expected by management.

pros: Capital One has a great culture, where people actually do live the corporate values.  They have a flexible work environment which allows remote computing .  They have good work life balance.
cons: Their technology infrastructure is immature.  Up until last year you had to fax expense reports.  They have a big workforce in Richmond.  When I dial into conference calls there is poor audio and edicate making it hard to participate in the meetings, especially if you are the minority on the phone.

pros: Great work-life balance, great work, great people. I may have been lucky, but was on a team with managers that put their employers as priority and focused on our growth. The culture was quite laid back; you can complete your work at any time and did not have to get to office on time. The work was great as well; I got to work on a lot of innovative business ideas that I really cared about.
cons: It's a big company and of course comes with some bureaucracy, but that is to be expected. I was taking on work to reduce the process time so I believe there are some motivation to change the long process to get stuff done.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow
pros: The structure of how work is done, coupled with a culture of moving associates through different teams and experiences contributes to a great learning environment. During my tenure, I have worked on expansion strategies, marketing, underwriting, new product development and associate-facing development programs. My managers have been supportive of learning new skills through trainings, projects, and conferences. I have learned a lot in five years!
cons: Banking is a highly regulated industry, which means that getting something to market can take quite a while. And, like many public companies I see leaders falling into the trap of focusing on short-term results over long-term strategy.

pros:
Good pay (not great)
Great work/life balance
Great technology
Great flexibility (work from home option)
cons: I have  noticed that most of the leadership started as colleg hires or are from India (brought over by friends) and have only worked at COF. This makes it very difficult for them to understand how things are done outside of Capital One in the U.S. I believe this is a definitive weakness, as diversity is not only ethnicity, but based on work experiences as well...

pros: Perks, benefits. Great place to work if you're fake and pretend to be satisfied with your current position and salary for the rest of your employment with them. Also, a great place to work if upper management is a family member since you're most likely to be promoted faster than anyone else that works harder.
cons: Promotions, personal growth, company values, ethics, employee morale. Management is directed as a bureaucracy. If you use FMLA you will be looked as lazy, and management will attempt to find patterns (using FMLA during the weekends) to insinuate that you're not being truthful. Salary increase. I received a 2.5% after being one of the top performers during 2012.

pros:
New software studio in Toronto with, and I'll admit to be amazed by this, real agile development models where the teams are actually empowered to figure out how to they want to organize themselves and tackle problems whether mobbing, paired, or solo. Choices on gear such as iPhone 6 vs Galaxy S6 (and 64 GB models too) and Mac vs PC. Even better, techies get administrative permissions on their computers and access to the latest software tools, patches, etc. That was seriously shocking.

Very good location, near Mel Lastman Square, so close to subways, shops, and lots of good restaurants (especially if you like Asian cuisine). Facilities have really nice spots for more casual relaxation or comfy work with a cafe, foosball, pingpong, x-box, and more. 

Work-life balance is more than expression, it actually exists and encouraged. There are fun days, opportunities to engage in charitable efforts, and more. It's refreshing to work in company that actually encourages you to get out and involved on company time.

The company sees itself as being a digital technology leader that happens to be in the financial world. From the CEO on down, the plan is lean, agile, tech savvy, and future focussed with a willingness to spend to make it happen. You can't ask for much better as a techie, but even for non-techies this is good. Bringing in agile coaches and scrum masters to help their business teams become agile is well-nigh unheard of and is great news because, in my experience, many attempts at agile software development die on the vine because the business doesn't go along with them.
cons:
It's not all sunshine and roses, obviously, but the cons are not that bad and many are starting to get knocked down.

Capital One is in a very regulated industry, banking, and so there are some rather onerous processes and gates to get through much of the time. The company does want to fix this, but that's a slow moving change and much of that is related to risk mitigation.

The company is still very meeting oriented and many of them don't actually resolve anything. It is improving, but I've never had 6 concurrent bookings in my life until Capital One! Mind you, nobody seems terribly offended if you skip their meeting.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Richmond, VA
pros: Great benefits, fun days to boost employee morale, preferred employer perks, corporate perks
cons: QAs based on perception, hard to transfer to another department, eliminated departments to "streamline" heavy emphasis to build rapport with customers even if the customer didn't want to, despite them telling you in orientation that there are no favorites believe me there are. If a manager likes you they will cover for you. They wanted us to go above and beyond for customers to the point they were giving away the bank

pros: Love working with the people at Capital One.  There's a lot to learn from everyone.  Company does not skimp on expenses or training.  Big emphasis on the customer and innovation.  Everyone is ambitious, hard working, enthusiastic on my teams.  Card, Small Business, Digital and the Labs are exciting places to be.
cons: Lots of regulation because it's a bank.  Some digital innovation takes much longer than it should.  Have heard some horror stories out of Operations and Card Partnerships.  Promotion/development is not clear and, on many teams, not talked about.

review_title: Great work culture. People are great and helpful. However, not easy to get work done.
pros: Work culture is great! People are extremely helpful! People move across teams a lot and it is encouraged, hence you wont really get bored because you can find another team as soon as you start getting bored.
cons: Its not that easy to get work done and sometimes people just want to take it easy, which can be a problem if you want to drive things fast. Pay is lesser than market.

review_title: Don't take a Finance job at Capital One unless you're 22 years old
pros: Capital One is a huge company so I'm really only reviewing the Global Finance organization, where I had the misfortune of working for four years.  For the right person, it can be a great opportunity.  It's a big, well-run company and it doesn't expect you to work more than 40-50 hours per week (granted, strenuous hours in a Finance role).  If you work in Richmond, the West Creek facilities are fantastic.  I saw plenty of not terribly talented people in the their late 20's making (low) six figures without really knowing all that much or working that hard.  Especially in the undergrad program (FRP) the kids are treated really well with tons of training and networking opportunities.
cons: Capital One has a brutal performance management system and they really do fire people, even good people, and lots of them.  In the area I worked, pretty much anyone over the age of 40 was toast if they weren't a Senior Director or above.  The Senior Manager and Director levels ( for those age 40+) were constantly targeted in re-orgs and downsizings.  And it's not like you get great experience in Capital One Finance.  What you learn there is very internally focused and not valued outside of the company.  The people I saw getting caught up in re-orgs were not finding comparable jobs in other organizations.  For anyone over the age of 30, joining Capital One Global Finance is a horrible career move.

pros: I went through recruitment process which included; initial application, online assessments, online video assessment, phone interview, and appointment for personal interview. I decline the personal interview and withdrew from process. Overall, the process to this point was easy to follow, and took approx 2 wks from initial application online. To be fair, I'm not rating in the "stars" ratings below since I withdrew from the recruitment process.
cons: WHY? The pay started at 13.88/hr and is low, even for the FL market in my opinion. Raises do progress, but you must wait and qualify with performance.This was the number given to me by the H.R. department when scheduling a personal interview.

review_title: Positive and motivating company culture while still being a sensible business
pros: The company has a great culture, where people collaborate and motivate each other,  where being a good person is celebrated and where learning is encouraged. There is also a drive to keep growing in the ever-changing technology environment. This is all while still being sensible as a business, with a strong focus on sound analytics and decision making, something that's really important at a lending institution.
cons: The UK business sometimes don't have as much resource as we probably need to achieve our lofty goals the way we would like to. Also, I don't think everyone's recruitment experience in the UK is a good reflection of what a great place this is to work.

job_title: Director, Software Engineering in Richmond, VA
pros: The company has fully embraced a leading edge technology, open source, cloud, and software engineering culture.  The company makes bold, strategic decisions and initiatives powered by a technology first strategy.  Great facilities and better than average benefits.
cons: The performance management forced distribution system is archaic for a company that advertises being a high tech company.  It is the number one dis-satisfier year over year in the annual employee survey but the CIO and other tech executives keep burying their head in the sand and blaming managers for the survey results.  They have recently implemented a system where a pretty high percentage of technology staff have to be ranked in the bottom,  which is a death knell for anyone that lands in it.  They have also just raised their attrition targets significantly and are requiring their Managers to aggressively work people out to meet it.  The current tech employee morale is low and one of fear because of this and ongoing layoffs over the last few years in various parts of the business.  When added to the incredibly aggressive project goals leadership has declared, it is currently a very tough technology environment to be in.  Especially in technology management.  I know this flies in the face of the "Best Companies to Work For" awards Capital One gets but if you talk to most Tech managers you will hear what I have stated here.

pros:
- Excellent opportunities to develop professional skills, both within the department and under own initiative.
- Management really support and encourage training with some financial support available. 
- Highly professional blue-chip environment, but with a modern and forward-thinking approach to supporting a good work-life balance. 
- Great office space, great restaurant for lunch.
- Overseas travel is an opportunity, but not a requirement.
- Good culture. Ambitious, but not overly-competitive working environment.
cons:
- As a (relatively) small subsidiary of a large US business, policies, procedures and systems are often US focused and awkward to work around. 
- Cross departmental networking and socialising is encouraged, but not actively supported.

review_title: Capital One used to be a good place to work when it was Hibernia.
pros:
I really can't think of any pros to working here.  Once in a while there were good incentives.
Nothing else I can say about this place.
cons: When Capital One was Hibernia, it was an awesome place to work.  They really cared about their employees, then Capital One took over and jacked everything up.  They stopped caring about the "little people" who put in the hard work and started caring only about the bottom line. The opportunities went away and laid off began to happen.  They would outsource the work to the home office and use temp services instead of hiring within to build morale.  They treated people like crap and because of that , after the 2nd time I was laid off, I left the company.

pros: Great management support across all towers, good work life balance, since insourcing has begun it is getting better and better as more resources are brought internally.
cons: High expectations, if that can be a con but I guess the largest challenge has been learning the internal flow if things but not too rough if you take good notes of your resources you will be just fine.

job_title: Fraud Intake Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: depends on what supervisor you get as to your success. always hiring because there is high  turnover (aka fire people).  last summer was all over the news and web that are firing 200+ people.
cons: They will dangle the bonus of $1100 per month in front of you, but you must get 100% on your monitors to get it--and they try hard to find fault with every little thing you say so that you do not earn it. always hiring bc always firing. 4 weeks training not enough.  you get dinged on your monitors for stuff that was NEVER covered in training.  This company makes tons of $ and none of it is going to you.

pros:
Great benefits
Good brand
Fast paced environment
cons:
Bad calibration. People with wrong behavior get promoted
Too much change with no proper planning
Bad behavior is celebrated. You may not be appreciated for good work for any goof up will be used against u. Don't end up in legacy hsbc departments which has bad management and people with huge egos. Don't expect capital one culture there. HR is non existent and I seriously don't understand why they are paid.

job_title: Work At Home Customer Service Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: The starting pay is incredible and full time agents can bonus up to $1000.00 per month on top of that. Some positions allow you to work from home which really helps with the work/life balance. They offer a lot of optional overtime. The benefits are the best I've ever had and they give you a lot of vacation/sick time. You are not required to work holidays but you can if you want and they pay triple time if you do. I could go on and on! If you get the chance to work for this company, take it!!!
cons: Sometimes the customers can be over the top rude but that says nothing about the company itself.

job_title: Process Manager (Associate Level) in Chicago, IL
pros:
Flexible work environment, decent pay (I make $69k, started at $50k six years ago), opportunities for advancement. 
Inspiring, technology driven strategy that makes Capital One a forward thinking bank and unique among competitors.
cons:
Health benefits are not great for employees with large families (multiple dependents) or ongoing health issues.  Capital one is self insured, which means higher premiums (think 800+ per month for a family of 4), high co-pays, deductibles AND co-insurance.  Other benefits are on par with industry standards (bonus, time off, retirement, etc).
Lots of change (re-organization, layoffs, site closures, etc), but this is perpetual here.  
Overly complex change management procedures that could use simplification.

pros: Hours, meeting new people, holidays off, direct customer interaction, for me, it was my first banking experience. I learned a lot.
cons: Management plays favorites, promotions not based on most qualified, get sick used unsceduled time off you risk getting terminated. Even when you have PTO to use! This is a policy they don't tell you!  Watch your back, other employees are very dishonest. First banking experience, and I will never work in banking again. I have numerous years of customer service and management experience and was excited to transition into banking, after 2 years (2 long), I am left feeling like I just left an abusive relationship!

pros:
Clear mission based business. Customer focussed.  Senior leaders give regular updates on how the business is doing.
Nice office with restaurant, free tea, coffee and hot chocolate, pool table, gym, music room, etc.
cons:
Employee performance reviews are done by ranking all employees of the same pay grade. As a result, colleagues are very unhelpful towards each other as they consider them as competition.

High staff turnover.

Whilst from the outside it looks like a very flat organisation, with VP’s and Directors sitting in an open plan office with everyone else, people are very status oriented and regularly say “X is a Principle Associate” or “Y is only a Coordinator. He shouldn’t be talking to someone of our level like that”.

pros: Capital One, as a company, is a great one to work for. They have a great corporate structure and amazing benefits. Lots of opportunities for growth and advancement. They've transitioned from a sales-based banking approach to a customer-based banking approach so it's a lot less stressful than other banks who run on numbers.
cons: If you are working at a branch level, it's really the luck of the draw who your direct manager is and how good or bad of a team you will have. This can either make Capital One a great place or a horrible place to work. Also, surveys! Every interaction you have with a customer can generate a survey and heaven forbid you get anything less than a 5....

review_title: Worked there 8 years, loved everyday until the day I lost my job due to  re-org.
pros: The company really does care for the employees and has great work life balance.
cons: The company recently went through a massive internal business operation change model that  wasn't handled very well and caused confusion with ripple effects.  In some instances it opened up opportunity, in some instances it shut the door for others and great associates were lost in the shuffle.

pros: Progressive company for the financial services industry.  Encourages a diverse workforce, and pays competitively.  Great overall environment
cons: Advancement within the company is difficult and not always a product of performance or results, but can depend on your direct manager and his/her reputation within the department.  Performance management in general is a huge pain point at this company, and is not likely to change.

review_title: A great place to work if it doesn't bother you that you job could be eliminated any day.
pros: An ever changing environment that constantly provides interaction with very bright and capable people.
cons: They don't care who they get rid of when times get tough.  Some of the people they have let go have made huge contributions to the company while some of the ones that are kept can hardly find their way to the office.

review_title: Much more relax setting than most corporate financial institutions.
pros: It is a very familial atmosphere, and everyone is very supportive.  It is also a place where feedback is important and recognition is abundant.  It is sometimes a fun place to work.
cons: It has changed in the past few years with the acquisition of banks.  It has become more professional, and less fun.  It also can be very time demanding.  And there is a lot of politics in play at times.

job_title: Technical Project Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Everything is fast and there are always a lot of changes.  The management is forward looking and try new ideas all of the time that keep things exciting.
cons: The change process is not always smooth.  There can be a lot of craziness during transitional periods and even though there is a lot of communication from management it is not always complete.

review_title: Capital One is the Worst Company I ever worked for
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in McLean, VA
pros:
The benefits are very good.     The heath insurance and 401k options are better than average.
In many departments, they allow people to work from home when needed.
cons:
1.  There is no job security and no stability in management,
2.  There is always a large amount of staff turnover.
3.   They encourage people to move around from one position to another almost every year.
4.   If you stay in one position more than 2 years, you will be considered stale and a candidate for their redeployment process which really is another term for layoff.
5.   In the banking side of the company, they rely 100% on vendors to do all of the IT processing and changes.   They even hire contractors to do the unit and system testing.
6.  There is very little in depth knowledge at Capital One about how the  IT system that is used for their retail banking operations works   
7.  Every new hire must pass a 'personality test'.    This leads to an environment where everyone is alike and very boring.
8.  Since all of the day to day operations work is outsourced to vendors, the Capital One employees really just work on meaningless task to please the directors.    Nobody below 
executive management does any 'real' work.
9.  The review process is an example of HR gone to the extreme - it takes up a ton of time for both the employees and managers .
10. If you have any morals and try to treat others as you would have them treat you, you won't survive at Capital One.

11.  The environment for the day to day non executive management staff is a model of survival
of the fittest, but since most of the work is outsourced to VENDORS, it is more like game of
survival.

12.  You job becomes navigating the review process and changing positions quick enough to keep on keeping on.

13.  The executive management team makes very good decisions on what banks and credit card companies to purchase.   But they have no idea on how to run the internals of daily business.

14.  Everyone who worked with me at Capital One had the same point of view as I did.

15.  If you want a career at Capital One, you should be prepared to step on people and basically your main task will be to navigate through the yearly performance review process so that you survive another year.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Saint Cloud, MN
pros:
*Flexible work options
*Good compensation and benefit packages
*Aggressive long term strategies
cons:
*Very little transparency in decision making
*Authoritative and bureaucratic organizational structure
*Unstable, constantly reorganizing with layoffs and poor job stability
*Poor performance management system
*Very sensitive org culture and feelings often trump logic in priority
*High level goals/plans are not broke down to realistic implementation timelines
*Organizational units are too separated and the global direction is often overlooked for individuals trying to attain recognition

review_title: Nice place to work, limited advancement
pros: Capital one has good benefits, competitive pay, flexible hours and nice campuses. Employees are generally given the required authority and resources to to their jobs and I would say senior management is fairly decent overall. It's a nice place to work..but...
cons: Advancement opportunities are extremely limited in most business units and promotions can take a very very long time to go through. Most of the guys I worked with ended up having to leave for other employers to advanced even after years in the same job and getting stellar annual reviews.

review_title: Nice place to work, limited advancement
pros: Capital one has good benefits, competitive pay, flexible hours and nice campuses. Employees are generally given the required authority and resources to to their jobs and I would say senior management is fairly decent overall. It's a nice place to work..but...
cons: Advancement opportunities are extremely limited in most business units and promotions can take a very very long time to go through. Most of the guys I worked with ended up having to leave for other employers to advanced even after years in the same job and getting stellar annual reviews.

pros: Environment is very team-oriented / collaborative; most people love their jobs and go out of their way to help you; usually there is a big-hairy goal for the year and the organization goes all in to achieve it - which creates a lot of alignment
cons: Management tends to turnover and go through a heavy reorg every 12-18 months; many people managers are great / many are not - don't like yours?  wait 12 months and you'll have a new manager

pros: Wonderful culture and diversity. Always an opportunity to expand your career. Very rewarding environment and a lot of help and resources in place to make every associate feel sincerely cared about. The company is transparent and holds town halls to discuss with associates where the company stands and where the future is going.
cons: Sometimes depending on your manager, it may be harder to move out of a role into a higher role. Typical people problems, though.

review_title: Couldn't ask for a better company to work for!
job_title: Principal Data Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Freedom and flexibility to balance work and life, as well as to take ownership of your career. My leadership is incredibly passionate about making sure each of our associates are doing work that is truly fulfilling and inspiring. Never have I felt limited by hierarchy, role, team, etc. My opinion feels valued and I have many ways to voice it. I love that I can take an idea and run with it, without needing layers upon layers of approval.  The pay and benefits are fantastic.
cons: We've made improvements (and continue to make improvements), by leaps and bounds, but sometimes process slows down delivery of work.

pros: Great benefits that start immediately
cons: Poor management. Most don’t know the employees jobs they manage but concentrate on how to make their spread sheets look good for their managers to promote themselves. Very cliche. High school type environment . Gossip, bullying and if your over 40 plan on never getting promoted unless your part of managers cliche . Promotions and rankings, metrics are adjusted inconsistently to prmote managers favorites. If you have a disability you might be told just to leave without pay or give up your vacation for fmla, informed they want you to leave and will force you to sacrifice your job or your health.

pros: Love the engaged talent and strategic mission of Capital One.  Very forward-leaning.  Great people to be around.  Very good salary and benefits.
cons: Biggest dissatisfier is performance management system and the ratings distribution.  Made famous by GE, but abandoned by GE, Capital One still adheres to it -- big dissatisfier.

pros: Great permanent and contract coworkers who willingly share information about  policies and procedures or may ask you for assistance just to be sure.
cons:
Low Wage Company with Mostly Contractors.

Excessive micromanagement that creates a peculiar type of "hostile" work environment where everyone senses that they are walking on eggshells.

There is the common practice of "Wage Downgrading" where there are job postings on various websites and, when applicants accept a considerable lower wage job offer, the permanent or contract employees are soon "let go" after they have trained the new contractors.  This is evidenced by a very high workforce turnover.

review_title: Great Company. B2B Calls. NPS rating hideous. Salary below par. Upper Management choaos
pros:
Work from home.
Team/Colleagues are nice.
4 weeks of pto plus option to buy 1 extra week.
401k and health care plan are good
cons:
Non-stop back to back calls
NPS grading is insane 
Customers can be quiet nasty
The long scripted informs you are made to read is insane.
Managers will reduce your lunch break when busy, instead of jumping on phones to help lower call volume.
Lots of system issues and glitches

review_title: Great benefits, terrible turn over rate.
pros: Health care benefits, 401k and stocks, work life balance, upward mobility potential after 9 months in department.
cons: If you have a health condition and need to apply for FMLA, you have to work a full year before doing so. PTOU time on a rolling calendar year and guidelines for it make it almost impossible to be a worker with a health condition to feel comfortable knowing they can successfully hold a job. Even if your stats are perfect, if you mess up with time it completely negates everything you have done and can be fired on the spot even if you had just received praise for assisting customers effectively.

pros:
Ive worked here for 4 years and still enjoy going in every day. The work is challenging if you make it out to be. As a developer you have the opportunity to work in a wide variety of areas.

Benefits/ Stock Purchase Plan ++
cons: At times things can be a bit slow. Like I mentioned above, you make your experience there as great or as poor as possible. Ive waited over two weeks for a translation to be finished.

pros: Flexible schedule, benefits, onsite conveniences
cons: Working to reach a goal is not enough.  When you've reached your personal goal or position and would like to enjoy the moment - it is not enough.  Doesn't show you're a "go-getter". Job descriptions don't mean much.  Management is only impressed if you do your job but also know IT to fix your own stuff, basic coding and creating reports.  That's the only way to advance from an entry level position.  Also, being a Conservative can be uncomfortable in this environment sometimes.

pros: Above average pay, certain groups (in Richmond) are given very flexible schedules -- I've heard the majority of employees work 9AM to 5PM.  I enjoy my immediate team and people are quite friendly here (I'm not certain how sincere it is, but I have lots of professional friends from the company)
cons: Very political internally, advancement track is unclear / no "career maps", benefits average;  I am expected to come to work in Mclean from 8AM to 7PM most days -- I think the firm talks about "work/life balance" but I'm some times not convinced it is a value of the firm. (<- it could be a Mclean thing).

pros: I enjoy working at Capital One because of the culture and values. The culture is progressive, inclusive where open and honest conversations are encouraged. The support in my role and development are also key.  The values -- Excellence and Do the right thing are not only spoken but embedded.
cons: Downsides include the busy work schedules. Capital One is growing, not only from a products perspective, but also organizationally. Work schedules are hetic and sometimes overwhelming. But, as stated above, there is flexibility from a work/life balance persepctive.

review_title: Working at Capital One has been rewarding, flexible & free-spirited..
pros: My manager and team has allowed me to work autonomously while continuing to foster a collaborative work environment. The worklife balance at this company is amazing - working from home is more of a norm than any other employer I've worked for. There are 2 values at Capital One - Excellence & Do the Right Thing. It's doesn't get much better than that, wouldn't you say?!
cons: So far, I haven't experienced many cons with working at Capital One. So far, things have been extremely accommodating for me. Maybe I can report back on this later during my 1 year anniversary :)

pros: Benefits start on the first day, good benefits,401k. Nice employees, managers are mostly friendly. Some extra perks.
cons:
The pay is very low for quality workers with experience and degrees. Pay is just above Oregon's minimum wage. With incentives, most make mid 20s to low 30s. My coworkers need government assistance to get by. These are not livable wages in the Portland market.
There is no growth in the first year, and there are few chances of advancement at the Tigard location.

review_title: Always changing, one day that change is going to be you being pushed out the door.
pros: Market leading, exciting to be part of an entity with a clear obsession with being the best, pay seemed above average for the specific location
cons: Never satisfied, competitive to the point of it being a negative because folks are more interested in how they are perceived than with getting work done, becoming impossible to get work done because Management is so afraid of making a mistake that nearly everyone in the department must sign off on every document before it goes out, not a place to be if you are the "I just want to come in, do my job well, and go home" type.

job_title: Part-time Teller in Glen Cove, NY
pros:
My colleagues were fun and really friendly.

review_title: Capital One is a "Monet" - pretty from a distance, a big mess up close
pros:
Work/life balance - associates are allowed to work from home when needed (at "manager's discretion" of course; if your manager's a jerk, good luck).  Capital One also pays fairly well and encourages associates to volunteer regularly.

I think your experience at this company really depends on your role and the organization you report into.  It only takes one senior leader to make your department miserable.  I switched departments a few years ago and was relatively happy before.  But not now!
cons:
The company is unstable, quietly laying off over 700 associates last October; this is the third round of layoffs since I began work there in 2010.  Attrition has been extremely high at the Sr. Leadership level; over half of the CEO's direct reports are new to the company within the last few years.  Of course any turnover is always followed by the "everything's fine" email or meeting.  

The health benefits are also horrible.  Extremely high (over $1k a month for a family) monthly premiums, PLUS a deductible, PLUS 20% coinsurance.  And that's their best plan!  Anyone with ongoing medical problems knows that's completely unaffordable.  

The performance management system is garbage too, forcing associates into "distribution buckets" (you could be an awesome worker, but if they need someone to go into the "inconsistent" bucket, it could be you!).  

Capital One preaches diversity of thought and it's always about "the associates" in the annual strategy meetings, but it's all a bunch of b.s.  The dumb ones just eat it up, though!  For the record, I'm super low on the totem pole.  I've always been rated a v. strong or strong and have no issues with my manager.  I'm just not stupid, I see the writing between the lines and I don't feed into the crap that others do.  

If you don't work in Richmond (their biggest campus) you miss out on 90% of the "perks" that make this company one of "Fortune 100's Best Companies to Work For".

review_title: Innovative, congenial culture - definitely not your traditional bank!
job_title: Principal Associate, Scrum Master in Chicago, IL
pros: I've been there 5 years, working mostly in Card Technology, and the company feels more like a vibrant academic laboratory than a stuffy corporate office. It's a real dynamic, open, collaborative and modern environment. There's a huge corporate focus on innovation, and my colleagues are extremely intelligent and hardworking. Company is a great place if you are personally open to change and dynamic (and I mean constant change every 6 months in terms of organizational structure and strategic priorities); on the other hand, it's not a great place if you are a old time 'good ole boys' kind of banker. Another positive is the organization is structured around cross-functional teams and so usually decisions are driven by consensus and not by a single authority - so the decision making process on almost any task requires continuous collaboration among associates at all levels and roles. GREAT company if you are right out of college and looking for meaningful work. College hires are given meaningful work and given a wide latitude of ownership. Also the benefits packages are great: 7.5% 401(k) matching, medical / dental / vision plans, and (while definitely on the lower end) there's modest educational assistance although some star middle-manger performers are given full-funded MBA tuition. WORK/LIFE balance is awesome! You get 3 weeks vacation plus 10 paid holidays and unlimited sick time (within reason). Overall, associates are super friendly, congenial and excited to come to work. It's really this entrepreneurial, hardworking and amiable culture that's kept me here.
cons: Given the company's 'start up' feel there's no real career pathing. This can either excite you or distress you - and it's not uncommon in some areas for an associate to have sometimes 4-5 people managers in 1 year. Capital One really requires you to 'own your career,' meaning it's up to you to manage your manager, write your objectives, and move your career at the company in the direction you want it to go. I find this exciting but others get burned out by what they feel is lack of support and direction. But on the plus side I've never had a manager who didn't encourage me to explore new opportunities. Another downside is performance management can overly focus on softer items like communication, etc. which can seem at times nit picky and trivial, ignoring meatier results and hard skills.

review_title: Capital One - A great place to work (generally)
pros: Overall Capital One is a great place to work.  At least in the Richmond tri-cities area, they are near the top of the list in compensation and benefits (including a very generous bonus each year based on performance, training/certifications, and health options - free health consultants and discounted gym memberships).  Furthermore, because there is constant change  (which I've also listed as a con), if you don't like what you're doing, you don't have to worry about doing it very long!  Finally, Capital One allows, and even encourages, lateral movement across the organization.  Many people move from technology roles to business/operations roles and vice versa in order to gain a holistic view of the company and to find their niche.
cons:
Like many fast paced companies, there are constant reorgs at Capital One,  and you should expect to be shifted around a couple of times a year.  While this allows for growth to those who embrace it, it can be a bit unsettling at times and keeps many on edge around the security of their job.   If you can accept that change is inevitable and that job security is a myth in the 21st century, then you will be fine.

Because of the competitive salary and benefits, Capital One has a stringent and somewhat difficult performance management process that consumes about a month of the year each year (at least for people managers).  This involves calibrating associates (often in different role types) - often an apples and oranges comparison that can seem somewhat unfair.  As such, there is little room for "individual performers" who do not display strong leadership qualities.   Again, once you understand and accept the process, this is not an issue.

pros: Fun and talented people do the work. Lots of learning opportunities for less experienced people.
cons: Managment is riddled in politics and a lot of leadership lacks experience with people management. It's also extremely difficult to advance your career the way their reviews are set up. review_title: A great company with heart, but definitely room for improvement
pros:
Founder-led and market-back strategies: Fairbank still is at the helm and sets truly market-based strategic priorities 
Data-centric decision making: Analytics run this company.  Data trumps tenure.  
Amazing opportunities to grow and learn:  The organization generally values a breadth of experience and frequent rotation/movement is supported and encouraged.  Development programs available for high performing associates that come with HUGE benefits such as special training curriculums and full MBA sponsorship 
Fair compensation:  always better for newer associates, but, keeping an eye on the labor market is something Capital One takes seriously.
Benefits: To say the benefits are generous would be a incredible understatement.  Great standard benefits packages (e.g. retirement, health insurance, disability, tuition reimbursement) with ton of thoughtful extras (e.g. $35k in adoption or surrogacy assistance per child) plus some location-specific perks (e.g. fitness and health centers, walgreens locations, snacks, Tesla charging)
cons:
- Getting a raise and promotion: I think we most leaders do their best to administer the performance management process in a fair way, however, because people are involved, there are many imperfections.  There continues to be a relatively homogeneous group of associates (namely white business analysts who started as college hires) that are recognized and promoted more quickly than others.  
- Poor strategic execution: While the company excels at setting a high-level strategy, the one-level-down decisions are often poor.  The direct reports to the CEO seem willing to invest enormous sums of money, but $$ needs to be managed/directed much more closely. 
 Examples like the Capital One Labs, technology transformation, and obsession with "Design" and "Product" illustrate the idea that you can't just "buy it" --- you need to "grow it" to make a healthy organization.
- Org issues : The siloed accountable executive model doesn't deliver results as it is supposed to... still very much a matrixed organization (e.g. enterprise, technology) . The result is that the ability to navigate politics and effectively influence others is the only way to be truly effective

This includes everything from internal approvals, documentation being wrong, a tool/API you're trying to use to not having an owner anymore, to your team all losing access to github randomly (again not joking).
- Organizations are very territorial. If someone thinks you're not the right person to talk to about something, they'll ignore you. They won't go out of their way to stop you, but they will certainly not be helpful.
- Expect anything you want to do is already being done by at least 3 other teams but you have no way to find out who they are.
- Everything needs a business justification so work on your business-speak.
- Ultimately the bottom line still comes first, not customer experience. 

Compared to other banks, Capital One is forward-thinking and ahead of the game. Compared to technology companies in the Bay Area they have a long way to go.

review_title: Overall, a fantastic company, though not without some of the pitfalls that are typical of a F500
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros:
Disclaimer: My feedback is specific to the analyst development rotational program and general corporate strategy functions - cannot comment on the experiences of cross-functional staff (HR, IT, etc) and field employees (branch, call center, etc).

It's a truly impressive company that built itself out of nothing in the early 90's and is now a top-10 bank and respected brand in the corporate world. That stems from the leadership of the founder, Rich Fairbank, an ex-consultant who,  nearly 30 years later, remains closely involved in the company's direction.

I think there are three principles that characterize the company's core values, and each one accounts for both pros (outlined below) and cons (next section):

The first is its Information-based strategy - Capital One takes a fiercely-empirical approach to decision-making. This focus on data and powerful analytics is what enabled them to disrupt the credit card industry (a business where decisions are nearly all quantifiable) in the 90's and it is deeply ingrained in the culture. The company places a premium on analytical ability and conducts its interviews much like a consulting interview (cases, looks for quant skills on resumes, etc). As a result, the analyst ranks are filled with exceptionally intelligent graduates from the finest schools in the nation, and they typically go on to do impressive things in business. I think nearly every person in my analyst class who went on to business school ended up at a top-7 MBA program.

The second is the attitude towards people management, which is effectively to hire the best people you can and truly value them - provide them with all of the tools they need to be successful. Capital One really treats its employees well - respect for work-life balance, provides them with all the latest gadgets on the company dime, offers robust perks like an amazing gym/free personal training, on-site doctor care, subsidized meals cooked by professional chefs, etc. Capital One's corporate culture has way more in common with Google than it does with a Wells Fargo or B of A, its peers in the banking world.


They typically match MBB comp packages for the business analyst program, and you'll work wayyyy less than someone who takes a job with an MBB. 


The third is its sense of corporate responsibility and customer focus. Capital One used to have an unwarranted reputation as a predatory lender that made money off of lower-income customers' interest fees, but in retrospect I truly believe that a sense of accountability and loyalty to the customer permeates the majority of decision-making.
cons:
As with any large corporation, there is a heavy dose of politics. There are often people at the senior management level (think SVP and up) who seemed to have schmoozed their way up the ladder and wound up in over their head. However, most of the executives are indeed quite smart and worthy of their titles, so not a huge knock.

The analyst program pitches itself as primarily strategy-focused - essentially in-house consulting - but depending on where you are assigned to work in the company/who you are working for, the job responsibilities can be far less sexy (lots of coding).

The raw analytical horsepower that exists throughout the analyst job family (including management levels) does present a double-edged sword in that decisions can tend to be OVER-analyzed. Big data analysis lends itself well to the credit side of the house, but the banking business is way more brand- and relationship-driven, and applying heavy analytics to decisions on the banking side can occasionally feel like you are killing a mouse with an elephant gun.

The social events are pretty lame (probably due to both the nerdy culture as well as the crimped budgets of a huge corporation with public shareholders).  I remember one year, instead of a holiday party where most companies rent out a cool venue and everyone gets drunk, we had a holiday luncheon, in our office, with no booze, and just lame White Elephant gifts.

There's a ton of middle-management which means it's hard to make a big impact until you have climbed the corporate ladder significantly, which is why I left for a smaller consulting firm.

job_title: Product Management Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: In most cases, some interesting work - most of the org really does try to 'Change Banking for Good'. Both the Richmond and McLean (the new one, M2) are amazing places to work with countless amenities, think kombucha on tap, medical centers, gym, collegiate-like campus with bikes to ride from bldg to bldg for your meetings. Shuttle buses are available between the campuses so when you do need to get to Richmond for a meeting, just hop on the shuttle in the morning and catch it in the afternoon to get back. Compensation and benefits are exceptional. Even in comparison to large tech firms (Apple, Google, etc.) Capital One offers similar or in most scenarios, more benefits. Work life balance is pretty great depending on your team, general start time is 9am and employees are encouraged to take the time they need to tend to family business. Hours and wfh can be flexible, but again depends on the team. Adoption assistance is up to $35k and they offer fertility benefits with up to 3 IVF rounds with meds included (no PGT testing unless you meet specific conditions, you need to utilize all embryos before doing a second IVF round, and all FETs are covered until the last round of IVF in which case they will only cover 1 more FET).
cons: Not necessarily a con, but need to be aware of the environment - it is a very matrixed organization. So most teams don't have full ownership over what they are building and will need to collaborate very heavily with multiple other teams because another product owner will have accountability over the vertical while you own the horizontal. This causes projects to take much longer than they might otherwise. This also means that if your Sr. Dir. isn't very strong, you likely won't be able to your projects to move forward if discussions have to move up the chain. The YE rating system is cut-throat. You need to prep and stay prepped all year. Make sure you are socializing your work to every single person you can. It will come down to stack ranking with a required 5-15% needing to be rated lower than 'meets expectations'. If you keep upping your game every year, you'll be fine but that may mean taking on external public speaking engagements, leading projects that will have massive business impact that can be 100% accounted to you alone (you'll get docked if someone else can share credit, which is in a matrix is hard to not share credit). I've seen people with $100MM in project value get average ratings so know that you aren't coming here to go with the flow....if you do, you won't last more than a year.

pros: Compensation, education (internal and external) and team building.

When I resigned and did my exit interview I was shocked to be told this boss marked me ineligible for rehire... without any reason. pros:
1. The agile methodology is a breath of fresh air compared to the waterfall they used to operate under.  

2. Their software is using some pretty old technology, but they have meetings to practice and discuss newer technology and they occasionally bring them into operation if management likes it.  

3. They seem generally interested in hearing employees concerns and addressing them.

4. Annual bonus is nice if you get a good review.
cons:
Working late is expected if your team needs to meet a sprint commitment.  

The 70/20/10 rule is used for performance reviews.  I usually land in the 70%, and once or twice in the 20% high ranks, but each time the reviews come around, there is a lot of anxiety and self doubt.  

The way it works is your manager has to advocate on your behalf in a big meeting and convince everyone else of your value.  You are compared against all other employees with the same rank as you.  If your manager isn't very persuasive, even if you are one of the best employees, you could end up in the bottom 10%.  Also, a manager who is a great salesman could sell a bad employee into the 70% pretty easily.  So rather than measuring employees to get rid of the worst 10%, they are really just punishing employees who work under a bad manager.  This model seems to really highlight the old saying, "A team is only as good as their manager".  

Also, the system also seems to encourage leaving coworkers out to fail publicly so that you can get a leg up on them in the next review session.  I've never done it, but I can see the strategy working for some.  Because its agile, you have an incentive to keep your team mates on track, but there is no incentive to help Joe from the other team.

review_title: Excellent place to develop skills early in your career
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Plano, TX
pros:
Joined Capital One as a member of the Analyst Development Program. The program is world-class in terms of developing employees analytical, quantitative, and technical skills, and gives new hires fresh out of college the chance to own high-impact ($MMs) projects right out of the gate, with lots of exposure to senior management. Analysts operate under an 'internal consulting' model, with internal clients or customers for whom they are responsible for providing analytical support for various projects. Culture is very similar to that of a consulting firm, as many of the firm's senior leadership initially came from consulting.

Skill development in the program is phenomenal, and analysts leave the program with a very robust skillset that is applicable not just in financial services, but a wide variety of industries which value analytical talent. Expect to receive numerous inquires on LinkedIn etc, if you have Capital One on your resume. 

Company also promotes a strong work-life balance and a collaborative work environment, where learning and development is highly encouraged.
cons:
Simply put, managers at Capital One are, for the most part, a total clown show. Traditionally promotes employees to management roles following strong work as an analyst, but unfortunately, the company puts in very little effort at developing actual human people management skills. As a result, managers tend to be very strong analytically and at problem solving, but horrendously poor at communication and influencing, motivating, and developing their own employees. This is compounded by the fact that the company has very vague and subjective criteria for evaluating employee performance, and puts too much weight on things that are not important in the grand scheme of things when it comes to performance. As a result, the performance review and promotion process tends to be a nightmare. 

Company is also very inefficient with regards to their decision-making process, due in part to being overly reliant on PowerPoint presentations, and in part due to the many levels of hierarchy that must be cleared before any decisions are implemented. Even policy decisions with the smallest level of customer impact require a 10-page PowerPoint presentation to at least 3 levels of management + a third-party office responsible for evaluating credit policy decisions. As a result, the pace of change and progress tends to be rather slow.

Compensation and benefits are good enough, but pay levels could be better - especially with respect to other Financial Services firms.

Typical large company issues:  Micro management of how developers do their estimating; vague reporting requirements that no one truly understands but are required none the less;  Business and Product teams can't decide on a direction until the last minute, so features are not well thought out and half baked deliverables are given to the development teams to deliver against with predetermined time lines, etc

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Plano, TX
pros:
* Focus on employees' personal development
* Information based company so tons of room for analysis
* Work life balance
cons: Calibrations and forced distribution. This can be a demoralizing process and make talent leave the company. Someone who is doing great but moved teams or is trying something new might be forced into the bottom if others in the same group have been in the team for a long time. Therefore, forced distribution is anti-diversity and anti-learning and trying something new.

pros:
Most departments support a flexible work schedule, enabling you to work-from-home if necessary, and leave for appointments or family scheduling conflicts.  Most departments support and encourage a health family/life balance, recognizing the importance of family commitments and interests.

The benefits are impressive - company matching 401K contribution percentage, enables you to buy a week's worth of vacation time, most departments encourage team outings and volunteer events.  

Most people are of good intention and have good attitudes on a daily basis, making it a friendly environment.
cons:
Their performance management process is severely flawed.  Much of management abhors the twice-a-year process, admitting it is extremely stressful and upsetting.  Forced performance rating distribution mandates that your department has 'poor performers'.  Meaning, even if everyone is doing a great job, exactly what they are asked to do and they do it almost flawlessly, they still need to decide who isn't performing as good as the rest, so they can be in the lower performance bucket.  Managers either get in arguments in which one person ultimately loses because a manager isn't as an effective communicator or advocate as the others, or because a manager steamrolls the discussion and is so stubborn the opposing manager just gives up out of frustration, hence making their associate become the poor performer.  Associates rated as poor performers often have an extremely difficult time invalidating this label and perception, and are often used as the automatic scapegoat for future calibrations' low performers.  Additionally, once given this low performance rating, you are unable to move to a different role, even in cases where the manager agrees there is a job fit issue and the associate finds a more suitable role to go to.  Based on this, associates who stay in this category for too long inevitably are pushed out of the department and by default, the company (aka are fired).  This is frustrating, disappointing, stressful, usually unnecessary, and in many cases heartbreakingly unfair to the "poor performer" who is only labeled as such because someone has to be.

*note* For those wondering, no, I am not a disgruntled employee writing a review, I have been rated as Strong, Very Strong, and even Exceptional during my career in the company.  I have witness and be involved in these discussions first-hand.

pros:
Great work environment, where associates have a voice; personable leadership and management that recognize what the employees do everyday matters. review_title: Loved the job, but got laid off
job_title: Senior Content Writer in Plano, TX
pros: I really loved working at Capital One. The campus in Plano is great, and I liked getting plugged into a network of talented people from around the country. I was given a lot of authority and autonomy to shape content strategy for my line of business, and it helped me experiment and grow into new areas of that role.
cons:
There's a weird culture thing between full-time employees (FTEs) and contractors. Many people start as contractors and get moved to FTE after a while. While I was a contractor, though, I had many meetings where someone would say "this next part only applies to FTEs", and then we'd sit around as people talked around us.

For the most part, it isn't a big deal, but after a long time I started to feel like a second-class citizen. There's a two-year limit on contractors - if you don't get moved to FTE after two years, you have to leave for 90 days and re-apply for your job. After I'd been in my position for 18 months, I had to start job searching because no one would commit to bringing me on permanently.

I got laid off in November, and it was really a bummer. Eliminating 950 jobs and cutting an entire line of business after only two years in operation doesn't say good things about the company's long-term strategy and planning.

Also: applying directly to an FTE job or moving from one part of the company to another to become an FTE sometimes involves a weird, unnecessary standardized test full of personality, logic, and advanced math questions. I'm a writer, and I flunked the math portion pretty hard and got turned down by two FTE positions exactly similar to the job I'd already been doing for 18 months. Three months later, those positions are still listed as unfilled online. This unfortunate testing policy kept that role vacant and turned away a qualified applicant, and I heard the same thing from many of my co-workers.

review_title: Great Innovator, Poor Performance Management and Huge Deadline Pressure
pros: There is always a new challenge, if you're on the right project or have a high-profile director. Lots of in-house learning and collaboration opportunities. Mostly very nice people to work with, and a pretty diverse workforce.
cons:
It can be hard to take advantage of some learning opportunities or participate in innovations because so many projects are under high-pressure deadlines set be senior management. The company uses Agile methods but does not really buy into the real Agile approach of giving teams a prioritized backlog and letting them define release scope and dates. Instead, whole systems have to be built, migrated, etc., by hard deadlines and the teams have to figure it out. Teams or trains can't easily grow and get people up to speed, so instead directors crack the whip, requiring lots of extra hours and weekend work. Teams are rewarded, but they can't really complain; many teams are mostly contractors and have no feedback power.  Directors say they are empowering their people, but then won't negotiate scope or deadlines. 
The forced distribution performance management process is still in place and creates a negative atmosphere among peers who are in a team environment but are also in an un-acknowledged competition for their jobs against each other. Who will come out on the bottom each year is a matter of constant concern, and relief when it's not you. 
The CEO is a wonderful person who sets inspiring visions, but I am told he is a big proponent of forced distribution. Also, when he sets an audacious goal, this is what sends the rest of senior management into overdrive on crazy deadlines.

review_title: Can't think of a better place to work!
pros:
- Family leave for mothers and fathers, including adoptive mothers and fathers
- Benefit plans to choose from, so you can pick what works best for you
- The Plano, TX campus has a free on-site health clinic (if I remember correctly, my spouse was able to go there as well)
- Fun Day once every quarter (your team takes a paid half day off work to do a team building event that your team voted on and that the company pays for)
- Cafes with a wide variety of rotating food to choose from (the Plano, TX location had at least 3 cafes with each serving breakfast and lunch)
- On-site gyms with personal trainers, and classes. The Plano, TX location also has a basketball court and a softball field where they hold intramural sports for associates to participate in
- At the Plano, TX campus,  from time to time they have little carnivals for associates and their immediate families. These carnivals would have games, contests, carnival food (cotton candy, popcorn, corn dogs, etc...)
- Mid-year and end-year reviews so you always know where you stand and what you can improve on
- Technological leaders in the banking industry
- In my experience, management was always willing to help me achieve my career goals
cons: Not sure if this is company-wide, but in the department I worked in raises and bonuses were based on the year-end rating. The year-end rating was determined by a calibration system. A calibration system is when the managers get together to determine which of the employees in the department are middle of the road, and they are given a Meets Expectations rating (or whatever the middle rating is). All other employees are then compared to the ones who received Meets Expectations to determine if they get a better or worse rating. The downside to this is if you have a manager who does not argue your case well, then you may not get as high of a rating as another person who has a manager that can make a good case. And as stated above, this rating will determine your raise and bonus, if applicable.

review_title: Join the company, benefit from training but don't stay too long
pros:
Capital One is a good employer, the pay and benefits are good, the business training is solid and executive communications are beneficial. The people are young and smart and I have made wonderful friendships during my 12 1/2 year tenure.  I have worked in diverse areas such as the functional areas of HR and Finance and US Card and the Bank in various positions.  It was easy to move around until the past few years when the company became flatter (limited promotions) and horizontal mobility was determined to be a business risk requiring at least 12 months tenure in a position.  Potential candidates should consider their postings, as they may be enjoying the role for a long time. 

Flexibility is a big benefit as it is the culture to work wherever you are, from home, from the office, from the cafeteria, from Panera.  Hours can be flexed as well to suit a work/life balance.  Get to work early, as sometimes it is difficult to get a seat near business partners, as work tables fill up fast in the morning unless your department has assigned seating.
cons:
This is a company that recruits the same type of people - young, smart, analytical, results driven and integrated thinkers, managed by the tests that candidates must pass to get to the interview.  Sometimes diversity of opinion is not valued and there is pressure to succumb to popular opinion.  

The burnout factor is high, as the annual performance management process is highly competitive. It's hard to have a family with after hours activities and remain competitive from a performance standpoint with those that are young and career-focused 24/7.  (I'm not saying that there is age discrimination but my situation was curious.  A few months before I turned 50 I was redeployed and my role was given to a younger male with less experience, even though my end of year rating was in the top 10%.  My attorney commented that this is a common practice for the company but the way that Capital One redeploys in small batches and since that statute of limitations is short, it's difficult to prove illegal practices.)

The company reorganizes frequently and I have been redeployed three times, two of which I stuck around and found an internal role but the third time I took a package. There is a glass ceiling and career progression can be limited to the selection of assignments received.

review_title: Potential to be great if they can get past the many little fiefdoms
job_title: Vice President Treasury Management in New Orleans, LA
pros:
Very innovative.  For most of my 9 years with Cap One, it felt more like being part of a large tech company than a bank.  I enjoyed having the flexibility to switch roles on my terms.  The IT teams work almost exclusively in agile pods, so new projects are always right around the corner.  And they are starting to see the benefit of bringing big data and AI into finance.  
The benefits and salary are on par with other industry players.
Severance package was well done and helped my family during my transition to a direct competitor.
cons:
Commercial Banking is a mess.  Mike Slocum is a strong and supportive leader, but his upper and middle management team are sharks.  Moving  to the Treasury product team from the commercial IT dept felt like going from a great big supportive family to a Colosseum full of gladiators.  Within a year, the newly hired head of Product fired almost the entire department (many with over 25 yrs of experience)  before leaving himself.
Reviews and ratings are a cruel joke.  You can pour yourself out working 18 hour days to keep systems up and running, to minimize client impact, to develop new processes--but in the end you'll still end up with a 'meets expectations' rating unless you are working on one of the super shiny new pet projects of the day.  The whole cross-calibration process is ridiculously subjective and supports those managers who can "make the most noise".
Also, the reorgs are comical.  I had 4 different managers in 2 years.  None of them managed me long enough to advocate effectively for me in my cross-cals.  And that has a dramatic impact on your bonus.

review_title: A neutered, toothless house pet posing as a predator
job_title: Senior Technology Manager in Tysons Corner, VA
pros: Great benefits. Most locations have a beautiful campus. Fantastic subsidized cafeterias with amazing food. Some very talented people (who will leave).
cons:
Your experience will vary greatly based upon for what part of the company you work, and then even more so by your leadership team.

The company repeats ad nauseam that it is "a tech company that just happens to operate in the financial services space" -- saying it does not make it so. I've worked for many companies in my career; this is more like a Soviet-era, government-owned manufacturing company than anything else.

Organizationally, it is highly fragmented and lacks both vision and leadership. The various LOBs are so very siloed, and driven by their own goals and politics that serve the sole purpose of getting leaders fat bonused, that is nearly impossible to get anything meaningful done. Unless it is a Cyber remediation activity, then all of a sudden everyone is aligned -- and that's what a takes to get alignment.

The vetting/hiring process for Directors and above is a) do you have a friend here? and b) do you have a pulse? This means that the excruciatingly painful and laborious hoops of tests and interviews through which Senior Managers and below must go through are not equally applied; as such, you will undoubtedly encounter some absolutely terrible people in senior leadership roles that have no business being in such positions of authority.

Despite what the Capital One PR machine claims, it is ridiculously far from being an Agile organization. Small, sporadic pockets of something slightly resembling Agile exist within the company. I was very disappointed by encountering people (in leadership roles) who have only been with Capital insisting "we're doing Agile" [flag!] and who, when you thoughtfully challenge that inaccuracy, you're persona non grata for telling the Emporer that s/he has no clothes.

review_title: Great people/team members; not so much management
pros: People are some of the brightest, smartest and most motivated and creative that you'll ever encounter. True team and partnership mentality. Associates encouraged to build skills, knowledge (if they're associates) if they can find the time (and that's always the issue). Teams across company are dedicated and hard working. Teams trying hard to really find best ways to be more digital. Customer service and the customer are truly at heart across the organization - not just lip service; associates and leaders really mean it. Great benefits, buildings/facilities are awesome.  Some flexibility in work schedule - most people work from home on Fridays or school holidays, etc.
cons:
So many layoffs and reorgs in US Card that leaders down through associates are leaving rapidly. They're sick of all the changes. With the mass migration, all associates are overworked. Although US Card is focused on being more of a digital leader, they don't get it and aren't hiring or training people to get the right skills. I learned more in 1 year way from COF in a digital role than I learned in 4 years there. They're still too slow to change.  

Mid level management (Sr Mgr - Sr Director) is overworked; need more training and time to be effective mentors and managers. Pressure is so high that leaders are micromanaging and expecting perfection when associates are working 50 hrs a week. The whole work-life balance that COF touted for years is a joke. It doesn't exist anymore. 

Work and roles are too siloed and sub categorized. Too many people doing just one role when they could combine (for example, brand, corporate communications, PR - you don't need one role who just publishes articles intranet or creates templates, presentations, sends emails. Combine that into each PR/Brand/Comms role and give person opportunity to  more than just be an email/article publishing jockey). 

Too  many clunky and limiting processes, although that's slowly improving with Agile and process management methodologies being implemented across the company. 

Hard to get promoted unless you're a superstar because of the performance management program. If you accept a job there, expect to be in it at least 4-5 years. You can always move to another team in a lateral move. If you're a contractor, expect that you won't be treated that well. You'll need to just do whatever junk work is left over at the end of the day that the lowest level associates don't want to do.

review_title: All that glitters... is not necessarily gold
pros:
1. A very lax culture with a startup feel for being such a large company. Hours vary per team/manager, but it's usually around 9:30-4:30-- you never get the stink eye for coming late/leaving early.
2. Working remotely is heavily encouraged in situations that warrant it, such as being sick/house work/doctor's appointment/etc.
3. (Sort of a pro, sort of a con) Some managers are amazing-- and some are very lack luster. Thankfully, Capital One encourages movement around the company, so you don't have to be stuck in a position that you hate.
cons:
1. Capital One is growing far too fast for comfort. The parking situation is absolutely horrendous. If you're not in the office by 9:15, you're kind of screwed. It's sort of like a college campus-- lots of growth and 0 parking. The thing is, colleges have subsidies for/free public transit; Capital One has no such thing. The employees have been making a buzz about this issue for years with no response from the company.
2. Employees (specifically those brought in through the college grad program) are hired in flocks. This is okay on the surface, but the overcrowding situation is at a tipping point (some people don't even have desks!!) and it's looking more and more like Capital One hires these college grads as cheap labor. In general, the vetting process isn't the best-- it does a pretty good job most of the time, but every now and then you meet a person and think, "who in the world interviewed you?"
3. As you've probably guessed, politics are major here. Playing the right cards, not necessarily doing great work, gets you promoted. Your manager alone is the one who pitches your competencies during review season. You can have 10 great things on your brag sheet, but if your manager has a vendetta against you/a favoritism for another employee, you're going to be torn down.

- Extremely high turnover (at least 50% of the people you started with will be gone within 2 years) yet leadership refuses to acknowledge the problem and make changes that results in higher morale and happiness.

review_title: Good company for undergrads looking to develop skills, bad for long term career
job_title: Principal Project Manager in Richmond, VA
pros:
-Smart people
-Good training
-Good industry exposure
-Good company name brand (for getting into MBA school)
-Work life balance (Normal hours are 9-5, 1 hour lunch break, work from home Fridays)
-Really good pay for undergrads

-Resort like facilities (private in door basketball court, walking trails, gym, tennis court, baseball field)
cons:
-Way too many reorgs (I had 3 managers 1 year)
-Promotion system a joke, its a seniority based pecking order, meaning those people who had a higher rating than you the year before will stay above and managers will look for reasons to keep you in that order regardless of your performance (I literally had one of my managers tell me that the only reason she gave me a "strong" rating on an attribute instead of a "very strong" is because if she gave me a very strong, it would've looked like I had more very strongs than strongs and that I then should've gotten a very strong rating overall ... umm... isn't that the point??)
-The company had a promotion freeze and then fired all the low performance. Since the promotion system is based on a forced distribution, it meant that it became that much harder to get a good rating and the bar is always moving. A common phrase you'll hear from managers during performance review is: "You did an awesome job this year, but unfortunately the bar has been raised again [so even though I've been telling you how great of a job you've been doing throughout the year, in reality its only average]" - in other words, its a moving target and you never really have a good idea of how close you are to it
