- So many courses that you can take through Capital One university. Honestly the best training programs I've ever heard of and they're all free. Taking a half day to take a course is totally cool.
- Strong moat, good company overall. We didn't lose our hat in the financial crisis by any means so we'll be around for the future.
- Awesome analyst development program. Capital One wants to bring in and train people for the future.
- Great work/life balance. Flexible work arrangements. Work from home if you want or need to, but people tend to lean towards coming in every day
cons:
- Finance company parading around as a "tech" company. Big push to hire tons of software engineers and go "digital," but I have my doubts that this will ever affect the bottom line.
- I have a great team, but it's such a large company that everyone's experience is different. For a company that claims to be a "tech" company at heart, we're really slow to adapt new technologies. It took awhile just to get one Tableau license. 
- Rich Fairbank might be ADD. He demo'd Tableau one day (This was before my time so it's a second-hand story) and it was all the rage, now I hear they're pushing SAP Lumira as the BI tool of choice.
- Base pay is definitely below market for Data Analysts and Data Scientists despite a lot of these people having very valuable skills. (some combination of Python, SAS, Shell, SQL, HBase/Hadoop and R)  Richmond, VA or Plano, TX pay is alright when adjusted for Cost of Living, though.

review_title: Not The Company It Used to Be
job_title: Senior Systems Integrator in Richmond, VA

cons: Morale is low following recent layoffs and constant changes in leadership and direction. Change can be good, but forcing people in roles with no consideration of their competencies or career goals makes for an stressful environment and sets people up for failure. People can embrace change if it is well presented and implemented as a smooth transition as opposed to the shot gun approach used currently. Many of the current senior leaders are relatively new to the company (less than 5 years)and have made drastic changes to the culture of the company with less and less focus on people over processes and tools. Associates are not respected and receive important communications via pre-recorded messages or email with no ability to ask questions. The recent exodus of key leaders is concerning and politics is king as the remaining leaders try to keep their jobs and newer leaders attempt to make their mark.

review_title: Top 100 Best Company to Work for 10 Times!
pros:
Capital One is in a class of it's own. They are a Fortune 200 Company that has been awarded the prestigious Fortune Top 100 Best Companies to Work for 10 times. In addition, Capital One is a top 25 best companies to work for in the Dallas/Ft. Worth market. Amazing things are happening here from driving cutting edge technology to providing a superior service to our customers. This is no longer a bank- It's a tech company and thought leader.  

The internal culture is phenomenal. Work life balance is a core company value for it's associates and we have it. This is the first job I have had in my career that really offers a work life balance. They don't just say it, they live it. I came from the technology industry and think what is going on at Capital One is like a hidden secret that is getting ready to explode. Capital One takes great care of their associates through carer progression and benefits offered to employees and their families. The 401k match is awesome. The system where you go to look up all your benefits is super easy to navigate and user friendly. Internal mobility and job security is remarkable. 

Diversity is another big focus for Capital One. The company is committed to hiring, promoting and retaining their talent, which includes a diverse workforce. Capital One is a mecca for all races, ages, ethnicity and sexual orientation. They value hiring top talent  and only want to hire the best. There is uber smart people everywhere. We have a diverse customer population so, Capital One wants to mirror the same diversity inside the company and it shows when waking down the halls.

pros: Fast paced, challenging work environment with intelligent coworkers. Flexible schedules; pay and benefits are slightly above average.
cons:
Rapid change can be an interesting challenge but when change seems to occur every second of the day, it creates massive inefficiencies and frustrations at work. Work has become even more bureaucratic over the years and there are way too many cooks in the kitchen, trying to take ownership of everything. Capital One is a meeting culture, again, leading to many hours each day that are completely wasted. The collaborative environment is only good if you are an extreme extrovert, otherwise this is not the place for you as you will find yourself on the road with coworkers for hours on end, commuting from Richmond to Mclean, to the airport, business trips, etc all together. 
At the very top, Capital One is mismanaged. It can take several months or longer to roll out a new process while employees struggle to follow whatever the 'current' process may be on any given day. I have worked in the headquarters for 2 years now and have only seen execs roaming the halls a handful of times. You never hear direction come from the horses mouth, instead it comes from 5 levels below senior management at which point the message has more than likely become misconstrued and miscommunicated. 

Many wasted hours are spent on performance management which, as in most places, is a joke and unfortunately comes down to who you know/ who likes you. The "diverse" and "open" culture that Capital One raves about on daily basis don't seem to apply to the average person. Joe Schmo will never fit in at Capital One. You must come to work each day with a crazy frat boy-like story in order to fit in with the culture here. Good luck to those who don't!

pros: Analytical work culture, Data oriented decision making, Flexible work hours

review_title: Mixed Bag - Great if you are LGBT

pros: The staff did have some problems at first but once you have a great team that understands each other, you can achieve anything. review_title: Don't let the back-office employees with the plush jobs fool you about what working Capital One is really like...
job_title: Relationship Banker I, Then Mortgage Loan Officer in Metairie, LA
pros:
Benefits are solid. I was a little disappointed when I left and lost my contributions, due to a vesting schedule that was NOT well communicated. Auto enroll me into the 401(k) without my consent, but not let me know how long until it's vested? Pretty lame

I took advantage of the tuition reimbursement and wasn't disappointed. 

Pay and bonus potential were good, but depending on your branch location, traffic, demographic, you'd either be doubling your salary with incentives or making your base salary ONLY, no matter how hard you worked.
cons:
Incentive program changed rapidly - sometimes 2-3 times a year, based on the direction of the company and how they felt if too many bankers did "too well." It's their game - they make and change the rules whenever they want.

Being a branch employee is like prison - while there may be work-life balance, there's no leaving outside of branch hours for life/family/adult responsibilities. 

I moved onto a Loan Officer role after they began to remove the Assistant Branch Manager and Sales and Service Coach positions that I was promised and working so hard towards. 

As I moved to mortgage origination, Capital One destroyed the majority of my book of business. 
1) deceptive advertising - how much money did they spend on a No Closing Fee loan that almost NO ONE met the underwriting criteria, leaving inquirers upset and disappointed?
2) ridiculous lack of communication and flow through the mortgage department. There's a reason they abandoned mortgages all-together for quite some time. People often left the process and moved onto other institutions. 
3) forcing people into products they didn't want. No one wants your high interest rate, low closing cost fee "first lien" home equity loan.

And many other issues. 

I finally went back to school and left banking for much more lucrative pursuits. You should all consider the same.

review_title: Great company to work for.  Excellent benefits!
pros: There is company is very diverse and has a lot of opportunity. The company is strong about promoting within. Everyone in leadership is very friendly and down to earth Great work-life balance and awesome benefits.
cons: The biggest challenge is getting promoted to another department. You have to sell your self daily in order to be noticed. Also the pay is okay but not as good as other competitors.

review_title: They want to be a software company, but they aren
job_title: Master Applications Developer in Richmond, VA
pros: Excellent work/life balance. Ability to work from home frequently. Opportunities to travel if you want. Good salary and benefits for the Richmond area.
cons: Digital team leadership is lacking in people skills. Projects do not follow standard software development practices resulting in last minute "dashes" that can go on for months. I don't think half of the people in charge have ever shipped an app before and it shows.

job_title: Chief of Staff in Mc Lean, VA
pros: Great people and challenging work are some of the best parts of Capital One.  There are plenty of opportunities to rotate jobs and get development.  Strong mission and senior leadership.  It is unique to be able to work for a large company that is still founder led.
cons: It is a big company and at times things move slowly.  There is a lack of diversity in the most senior ranks of the company.

pros: Fairly dynamic, very smart people, often very likeable, they tend to be 'good people' with solid ethics and values. If you like the culture it's great (though it can be a little cliquey with the folks who've been around since the '90's being a tight knit group who seem to take care of each other). Very high quality work facilities, great benefits, competitive compensation packages. Emphasis on strong people management can be a good thing - the Card division is especially good at people management, they grow good people leaders there from the bottom up. Not so good at growing people managers/leaders in the functions like HR, finance, legal, etc (not sure about the Bank division).
cons:
Relentless focus on performance management and constant assessment of everyone at all times, and never ending giving of feedback can have a dark side (though it can definitely help everyone grow too). Specifically it can and does sometimes lead to a culture of nastiness, judgement, and a rigid heirarchy (because semi-annual performance appraisals are heavily influenced by committee discussions where every people manager at the next level up has the opportunity to give input both positive and negative - so there's a lot of striving to impress and never offend/disappoint anyone a step up in heirarchy). Also, people can spend their time indulging in judging others as an intellectual pastime (past the point of usefulness), rather than actually doing something meaningful - it can be an excuse for people who don't know how to get results in their own work (or who want to avoid confronting their own issues).

In fairness around the time I left that the company was starting to discuss finding ways to overcome some of these problems, and may have succeeded in the meantime. However, if you are gentle soul, who has any trouble at all taking criticism, or doesn't like being in a pretty fiercely internally competitive (although the competitiion is below the surface) environment then you may want to think carefully before moving here.

One other negative - historically Capital One has been very unplanned in having massive hiring sprees in good times, with insufficient internal controls. Then at some point they realize they've added too much overhead (either if there's an external shock in the market, or they just wake up and smell the coffee one day) and then go through heavy rounds of layoffs. As a result, especially in Richmond, Capital One has a reputation for these major reductions in force - and unfortunately this reputation has been earned. So this isn't as secure a place to work as some others.

review_title: It really depends on your manager/location...
pros: great company values, benefits, and work/life balance
cons:
forced distribution for performance management... more often than not your performance is based on how strong of an advocate your manager is for you 

Capital One is a different work environment based on what location you work at and where your department is primarily located 

Associates move around often internally... mostly because it is the only way to advance or not be managed out 

Capital One is a great place to work for a certain type of person.

review_title: Fun place to work, but if you want to be challenged you need to enforce that yourself
job_title: Associate Software Engineer in Wilmington, DE
pros:
Incredible work life balance within this company.

Working from home is never an issue, but you'll want to go into the office because it's fun.

Lots of opportunity to pickup work outside of your main job.
cons:
Most of the work isn't challenging, if you want to be challenged you'll need to pick up side of desk work.

I've heard mixed reviews about people in the TDP program. I was fortunate enough to be put on a good team, but others weren't so lucky.

pros:
Work from home
Some scheduling flexibility but this could be better improved.  People brag and overrate the schedule flexibility when in actuality it is super rigid.
cons:
The management team and dated Performance management process tries their best to find faults.  Good performance is rarely celebrated.  For example, you can have 30 good  calls and you have 5 customers who compliment you through a survey and give you a 5 star rating but then if out of the 30, one customer may have a so so rating and give you a 2 out of 5 star and not recommend Capital One, the one bad rating will negatively impact your overall score in a huge way. The worst part is that the detractor may not even be your fault and  they may give a  bad rating primarily because the company does not meet the customer's needs e.g. lower interest rate or bonus rewards for long time customers.    
Management also tries their best to find fault with your calls as much as they can.  Every time I see customer surveys I get 5 star rating, and even got Celebrations from Promoters and yet one or two calls that didn't go so well you get bad errors that count against you getting any future promotions, raises or even job transfer to a different dept.
Vision care benefits aren't that great.  I spent 150 on contacts and only got $75 back and I buy the premium vision care.  
OT is NEVER available even though people like to brag saying it is.

review_title: Steep learning curve at first but quickly flattens after
pros:
- Great work life balance, unless you're in the team that manages credit card approvals
- Heavy emphasis on analytics and SQL, skills that are very valuable and highly transferable
- In general you'll work with good people at the individual contributor level who're well intentioned
- Competitive pay for the amount of work you do
- Good RRSP program and pretty standard stock plan
-  A  strengthening "tech" brand due to the strong exit placements of alumni
cons:
- You'll be working in the credit card industry, which isn't for everyone,. Capital One also isn't very forthcoming about this during recruiting. 
- Analysis paralysis, the flip side of the heavy emphasis on analytics is that there is a general sense of false precision, and you'll be asked to do the same analysis a hundred different ways  for very little incremental insight.
- Because the work is concentrated on a single industry, the learning curve will be steep at first, and you'll quickly become knowledgable in credit cards, but it'll flatten out thereafter unless you want to build extremely niche knowledge in  one particular aspect of credit card (e.g. over-limit fees).
-  Management is a mixed bag, while there are a few truly inspirational leaders, there are also managers who are very "cliquey" and will only promote associates who're close to them, there are also a lot of first-time managers who were promoted to people management position based on their individual contribution and they're not well equipped to lead teams.

pros: Good company to work for, treat employees well with lots of opportunities for training, learning, etc, good benefits and salary. Gives the chance to do interesting work in the financial services sector while being in a more laid-back environment with good work-life balance

review_title: It has been a good journey with Capital One

review_title: Capital One is a great company to work for.
pros: Flexible and collaborative environment. Easy to manage work/life balance. Amazing benefits and competitive pay.
cons: The company is focused on bringing technology to the customer by improving their remote banking and reaching customers that are not near a branch site, however internally they struggle with having teams or departments at different sites and don't focus on applying the same technology or remote team management to their employees.

job_title: Senior Risk Project Manager in McLean, VA
pros:
Great work-life balance on most teams, ability to work from home
High-tech innovative workplace with desks that allow you to stand, break rooms, free food.
Salary is performance based and competitive. Promotions and raises occur often.
cons:
Locations are limited to VA, CA, DE, IL, and some occasional presence elsewhere.
Change is a part of the culture here, most people move roles every one or two years, so be ready for that.

pros: The benefits are fabulous at Capital One and the free coffee was great. The office I have worked at was also conveniently placed, close to public transportations.
cons:
For my couple of years with Capital One, we were promised a better salary as it was much lower than the competitor. This promise was only keep for the least paid employees, many of the employees slightly higher were completely ignored. Promotions were also very iffy. Very often promised to be open internally first but many of the new promotions are often announced late or hidden from internal employees. Many of the new promotions are also "reserved" to preselected candidates and employees are often discouraged or prevented from applying to new position. Job security is also a big issue there, employees were laid-off even if they had decades of tenure with the company and as someone who had access to their performance numbers, I can attest that the reason was not their performance.

I also did get laid off so it may seem that my opinion may be biased but consider this. I worked very long hours off the clock (overtime was discouraged), including Christmas eve and Christmas day. My position involved very specific work and against impossible odds, I did manage to keep myself on time with everything. I was laid off under the pretext that I did not perform well in certain areas that was not the main focus of my position. Evaluations from peers also went against my superiors' opinion on those performance points. 

My goal here is show you that I never felt that it was a great place to work. Surveys were forced to us and the worry of a prying eye often forced people to give a positive score no matter what.

review_title: Relaxed environment but very old school

pros: The people were amazing. Great benefits. Had a bunch of classes and ways for you to learn new things. Gave you the ability to learn and develop. As an intern I was treated as top priority

review_title: "A" for a tech company, "A++" for a bank

job_title: Senior Process Manager in Mc Lean, VA

There were many times that it felt like pulling teeth trying to get the different areas to work together or help out with what they knew.

review_title: Great work life balance and great company!

pros: Good place to work. Good benefits. Lots of different departments to work in. Variety of schedules to work. Pay can be good to great depending on your willingness to work. Have some great managers who care about their employees.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Toronto, ON

review_title: CapitalOne a Bank that functions more  like a FinTech
job_title: Chief Data Architect in McLean, VA

There is a premium on solution engineering, as open source and internally developed solutions are the preferred methods for creating new products.
cons: With the desire to be innovative, quite often the same solutions are developed independently.

pros:
The number one reason to work in any company, I think, is your colleagues. It's one of those things that you don't have any influence over unless you're the one hiring, and actually contributes the most to how you feel about your work. I feel really lucky to have some of the smartest and warmest colleagues I've ever worked with. The culture, particularly in the Design team, is really nice; everyone is incredibly supportive of one another, and my colleagues are all experienced and enthusiastic about producing brilliant work every day. This makes me want to come to work more than anything else.

There is a lot of support from Senior Leadership in getting us the right training and learning opportunities. I feel like they invest in their team, and work to grow us to our maximum potential.

I also really love the culture, the flexibility with where and how I work. When I choose to come to the office, the spaces I can work in are varied depending on the type of work I'm doing. The expectation is that you're trusted to get the job done, so whether that's achieved in one of the cosier corners of the office or sitting/standing at your desk, it's fine.

The benefits are really nice; the pension is the best I've ever had, and health/dental care are all options you can take. I really appreciate the Mission Days and team days they organise for us, too.
cons: Some benefits are not equally distributed across locations, so the staff in the headquarters get very subsidised meals & an onsite gym, in London we have free cereal and fruit for breakfast and free fizzy drinks fridges, and a running track on the roof with a very small discount for gyms. The pay is less than it would be at other companies in this industry.

review_title: Becoming a big corporation and all that entails
pros: Great hiring process and tends to land well above-average people, especially in M&A. Depending on the role you land, work-life balance can be very attractive, and benefits and pay are competitive. Problems tend to be interesting to solve, and very cooperative and helpful culture compared to other large organizations. Excellent place for either college student looking to work at a great company for a few years before their next step, or a middle management type with family priorities who can accept a good work-life balance and great culture in return for marginal career growth. Roles and org structures tend to shuffle every 12-18 months - this can be an up or a down depending on the situation. Credit roles are overvalued to a fault, but if you can land one its an excellent way to accelerate career growth.
cons: The last five years have brought a few changes: First, a number of extremely competent senior leaders have left the company. In addition, career advancement at all levels has slowed significantly and, as at many large companies, become more based on executive favor than competencies or results. Depending on your role and your management chain, you can have either a favorable work life balance or find yourself working I-Banker hours but without any commiserate recompense. Promotions lately tend to be based more and more on political positioning and executive favor; as a result senior and middle management tend to lack fundamental management skills, leading to low morale and turnover in middle and junior buckets. If you're ready to play the game you can do well, but don't expect much career mileage out of the quality or quantity of your work.

review_title: Take advantage of the benefits, always be prepared for a layoff, beware of structured office politics.
pros: Capital One is a great place to work if you take advantage of the opportunities.  They paid for me to complete my degree. And they offered a lot of free programs at work that could help you advance your computer skills and marketing skills.  Most of the programs they offer are certified so you could add it to your resume and let it work for you at another employer.  I have had more managers than I can count in my 8 years at Cap One but most were really good.  The benefits packages were the best that I have seen compared with my friends.  I enjoyed the flex time it created a good balance for me to tend to my family and go to school almost full time.  I can't say that people who are on the phones get this kinda flexibility.  Company sponsored team fun days were great!
cons: I would agree with one of the other posters that when Nigel left it seemed the Spirit of the company left with him.  At one point I was really excelling in promotions at the company and around 2005 I hit a brick wall.  There were a lot of changes being made in how people could get promoted.  I could watch certain associates come into a department and know that they were set aside for a promotion.  It was weird like the management was waiting for the right moment to push someone who didn't know the work right into manager position ahead of people who posted for the job and had worked it for years.  Then they came up with this new idea of how to promote and give bonuses based off of these manager round table discussions. Managers who you never worked for had a say in how much of a raise you would get.  So if you were an introvert, you could forget about it. I watched many take on new projects and work hard only to be passed over by those who were "in" with management socially and not "in" on the work. Heartbreaking.

review_title: Excellent place to start your career
pros: Capital One is full of very smart people from around the world. The recruitment process is quite intense and that insures a good pool of analysts that run the business i.e. business, data, operations and statistical analysts. The positions demand fairly high competency in math, programming, statistics and the mix depends on the job family. The work place is very relaxed and casual. However that does not mean that work is taken casually. No decision is made without grounding it in data and a lot of analysis. Taking time off for vacation/personal/family stuff is not a problem at all. You can work from home on days that you don't have meetings with senior leadership. I generally like to go to the office since that allows me to interact with people, but I stay home when I don't feel like getting out of bed. Work attire is casual (most people wear jeans). As long as you get you work done well you will be fine. You need to go above and beyond your present level to get promoted.
cons:
In my opinion, the legacy business (credit card) is still very dynamic, challenging and full of very bright and talented people. That business has always been very enterprising, almost like a start up, full of youth and vigor. Since capital one acquired 3 banks over the last 4 years, the bank side of the business came with a lot traditional banking type people. The two cultures are quite different but luckily if you are in card then you dont interact with bank at all. Capital One has tried to move some card folks into the bank to instill some of our traditional data driven strategies and ways of doing work into the old-school bank. That has been full of challenges and I've heard a lot of horror stories from people who moved there. Basically you add 20 odd years to the average of a card employee and you get the average age of bank employee and you can imagine the problems the generation gap can bring.
Capital One doesn't pay as well as other financial services companies. I guess one reason it did so well in this past recession is that it gives moderate bonuses. however money can only do so much for you. The work life balance you get working for Capital One negates the lower pay. I think I've been spoiled working for them...can't imagine to leave. Wait, this was supposed to be "Cons" part. Oh well!

review_title: So much to do in so little time
pros:
-I was with Chevy Chase Bank when it merged with Capital One and they kept the length of time I was with the company, allowing me to have 20+ days of PTO.  
-You are compensated when you reach your goals.  You can earn anywhere from $120 to 3000+ plus per month based on your sales.  
-Health benefits are pretty good, you can choose from three different levels, depending on your situation.  
-Tuition reimbursement for PT who reg works 20 hrs/week (up to $2500) and for Full timers (up to $5k).
-If you are unsure of a procedure, need guidelines, or have legal issues, they have a customer service number for employees to call and get directed to the right department.  You can also obtain policy and procedure guide on the intranet.  The intranet is very resourceful.

The company itself offers many opportunities and a lot of aid for their employees.  As a Relationship Banker, if sales is not your passion, then don't apply.  Any sales job can be stressful and time consuming, but if you're into sales, Capital One would be a great place to work.
cons:
-If you're not sales oriented, this is not for you
-Some procedure takes a while to do, sometimes you would have customers sign things and then you later organize everything after hours.  Notes are helpful so you can remember what happened between you and a customer, potentially to obtain sales later, but if you don't have it, you will be frowned upon or cause your branch to fail an inspection from the sales and service coach.  Bc of this, you could also be staying after hours to add volume to your notes.
-Follow ups schedules, possible an hour to open an account and add a checkcard, coin machine bags needing to be changed, and there's only two of you while there's 5 people waiting.
-If you're not doing good or just doing ok...prepare to be micro-managed.  Logs and trackers on how many people you've talked to, how many you've helped, any sales from any conversations.
-If you're not meeting your goals, or just meeting the bare minimum, you are indirectly hinted to find new jobs.  So the implications could be "Sales is not your thing, find another passion/position" or "We're going to let you go if you don't start producing the numbers."
-Working at a branch means work-life balance can be difficult.

review_title: Open culture mentality is a farce, political
pros: Decent benefits, insurance plan is through Aetna, 401k with matching, paid federal/bank holidays 20-25 vacation days and sick time is at your will (meaning it is paid and unlimited for exempt). Ability to work remotely HOWEVER it is at the discretion of your supervisor and many do not allow or encourage it.  Most departments have a good work/life balance. Pay is ok, merit increases and bonus potential
cons:
The culture is very political and all about how well you play the game.  If played exceptionally well you will go far.  Your work does not speak for itself, your ability to play does.  This is evident in the performance review process. The fact that you've successfully done your job well can still lead to an "inconstant" (below expectations) or "strong" (which is average and most common) rating.  The rating is determined in management calibration sessions which rate your performance against everyone else at your same level (not job title). So if someone at your level has gone above and beyond (which always occurs), this then creates the standard for which you should've followed.  This makes it impossible to set goals and be confident that if you've met them you've performed well, since you are ranked against your peers not against goals set by you and your manager. And these are peers in various states and locations so you more than likely will not even be aware of what others are doing. This process leads to less teamwork and knowledge sharing and more individualism.

As with most companies, your direct manager can make or break your experience.  There are good managers, however, there are a lot of managers who are self serving and not supportive.

With the numerous mergers and acquisitions, the company looks at the acquired employees as inferior and their opinions and recommendations based on experience is not welcomed. Conform or else.

The "Best Company to Work For" ranking is questionable.  I've never met an employee who felt that strongly.


Advancement is contingent on the above and can be limited or non-existent.

Job security is non-existent constant acquisitions and reorganization creates rolling lay-offs.

New to the banking industry, but not willing to learn.  Lots of federal compliance violations exist (but not widely discussed). 

Technology is lacking and in some ways is less than the industry standard.

review_title: Be aware of what you're getting into
pros: Excellent pay for my field
cons:
Good old boy network is in full force at Cap 1. I am in a technical role and expected for the stellar pay that everyone hired would have commensurate technical abilities. 80% of my team had NO TECHNICAL EXPERIENCE at all and were hired to run a data center. Out of those 80%, ALL of them were "buddy" hires. Cap 1 works on antiquated tech policies that are barriers to getting anything resolved quickly. It's as if all Cap 1 full time employees came from the government sector. The brilliant idea to hire offshore technical support is just asinine. In my 2 years here I have only met one offshore counterpart that knew anything that could be remotely construed as actual technical knowledge. The money they lose in downtime of systems alone is mind-boggling.  

Now for the bad news. Ready? If you're a contractor you have a 2 year life span. That wouldn't be so bad if you went into the gig knowing that, but most likely your recruiter fails to mention that. In fact no one on my team knew that until almost their 2 yr mark. Several people only had a 2 week notice their contract was ending. This was 4 days after Management came in to address that we would be there for several more years despite technical changes to their model. Apparently no one, including Cap 1 Mgmt or the Recruiters "knew" it was a 2 yr contract, as if it was a surprise to them. Ironically, my entire team reported to and was directly managed by Cap 1 mgmt. And with that announcement came the real face of Cap 1.  After stringing us on with becoming full time employees for two years, we suddenly became anathema--- just disposable contractors. I couldn't even get management to return my emails on anything, including their plan to supposedly bring us back on after a 90 day hiatus. Neither could my co workers. They did bring two people over as full time associates prior to the announcement. And ironically, they were two members of the good ol' boy network. 

That aside, management is clueless. They are all "yes men" marching in lockstep to edicts from above that are devoid of reality in the trenches. The pay was great, there was little politics I had to deal with at my level, but the reality is you;re a second class citizen and no amount of hard work, loyalty, or dedication is going to change that. If you go into it knowing it's at MOST a 2 yr contract and can plan accordingly with that, you should be fine. Don't buy into the hype though, mostly they are looking for warm bodies to fill positions as a numbers game because their inefficiency and productivity isn't one of their concerns apparently.

pros:

Work/life balance exists but it depends on  which department you work in.

Benefits are great if you are a FT employee, but non existent if you are a PT.
cons:
To get promoted, you must be the best brown noser around ESPECIALLY if you work at the branch level. As the company is changing the structure as far as positions at the branch level i.e. branch ambassador & market manager or cafe coach - you will be required to multitask. The training that a banker will get in a period of 3 months, is given to a teller in a span of 3 weeks and they are expected to learn this quick.

Since at the branch level employees are forced to present the most up to date product i.e. the infamous 360 accounts customers are left frustrated because the company is losing its personal touch. 

Company moved away from mortgage lending, but today (due to the complains) they have come up with a bandaid to tackle that issue called lend one 

There were a few massive layoffs that affected hundreds of people and they did it over the span of a weekend .. and these employees were let go regardless of tenure or performance there was the case where an employee was months away from retirement and they let her go. Another that was promised that she wont be affected by the changes and she was part of the group of managers impacted.

So your job isnt secured at capital one even if you were a stellar employee.

pros:

-Technically Innovative 
-Training
- Good benefits

cons:
-Hyper political environment, favoritism is rampant. 
-Telugu vs others politics. Chances to succeed in the company depends on which group you land into. If you don't speak their regional language, doesn't matter how good you perform or deliver, your contribution won't be acknowledged, someone else will take credit of your work and you will be given a bad rating.
Because of this, you can see some very talented people leaving or made to leave but also some zero talent, no in-demand skills people holding their position for years.
- All big talks but very low on action HR, whic is mostly absent, unless it is recruitment or firing. One of the SM's openly in a forum said: " I don't care about diversity". A number of times he displayed racist behavior and used to yell, humiliate team members in front of others but have been in the company for decades. It is not just one case, there are others like him.
- Senior Managers have too much power and there is no way to provide feedback about them to HR or anyone else. So, if you end up with a bad or a biased SM especially if he has the backing of the director, they can make your life hell.
- Performance evaluation system is the worst in the industry. It is not based on what you delivered, or as value to the company. It encourages animosity between teams and associates. If a particular group has any kind of feelings or grudge towards you based on some politics or bias, you are a toast. It's a shouting game or better an open fist fight where all the SM's in a room have to fight amongst each other to get a rating for their resources and declare the other team resources as bad and incompetent. Obviously, the loudest voice with blessings from a powerful director wins here. Imagine the case where your SM doesn't have a director? you will be beaten up from all the directions because there is not one above the chain to cover you up. It has happened to me.
- Technically confused. CapOne is going through a phase where it is confused if it is a bank or a technology company, it is thinking of itself as an IT service company, trying a number of things with no clear vision. 
- The company in the past couple of years have adopted the strategy to get rid of experienced resources and have been recruiting cheaper out of the college interns. It also stopped offering any kind of immigration visa sponsorship 2 years back.

pros:
Let me clarify that I worked for Capital One BANK, or the New Orleans-based bank Hibernia, which was one of the first banks purchased by Capital One, N.A. in 2005. It was very friendly, open, and very, very efficient. Local communication within the company was clear, everyone knew to whom to report or whom to call if there were a problem. Advancement opportunities and salary compensation were often fair as the Bank took care of its employees and often treated them like family. Capital One Bank was very generous about paid time off, holidays, sick leave. To summarize:
- Pleasant  Environment
- Fair advancement opportunities
- Good local communication
cons:
Over time, communication broke down within the company and the Corporate Red Tape took over. Bank employees were treated as if they were ignorant. Changes in policy slowed, eventually nullifying, the efficiency that the original bank once had. Managers became distant figureheads and employees were prevented from actually doing their jobs by red tape. There was a lot of wasteful spending, money which could have been put back into the company. I would not be led to believe that one's job is secure due to layoffs in favor of foreign outsourcing. To summarize:
- Very poor distance communication
- Corporate "Red Tape"
- Wasteful spending
- "Us" versus "Them" mentality between the Bank/Corporate sides
- Job security

review_title: Good for post grads, but don't get stuck there
pros: Cap One has a lot of experience to offer post college graduates, especially in analyst roles.  The company generally has multiple levels of great management which will get said entry-level employees quickly up to speed on corporate analytics.  There's also a plethora of systems for the analysts to work on and the learned fundamentals are highly valuable for future careers.  It's a great environment, if used for a stepping stone to other careers.
cons:
Being a large company and having a fairly "locked" management structure, it is very difficult for newer employees to advance to management levels.  Some friends of mine interviewed there recently, and said they had spoke to analyst managers who had been there for 10-15 years, each of whom never worked a different job since college!  If you're looking for the be-all-end-all employer and are happy with 3-5% salary bumps every year, then by all means head over to Cap One.  

However, if you think you're good at what you do and are expecting to double your salary in 5 years, then do not go to Cap One.  It doesn't matter how smart you are, you will not move up quickly.  If you find yourself in this category, you may want to consider a smaller business (<1,000 employees) - that's where you will find some serious career growth and career advancement opportunities.

review_title: Fraud Intake Coordinator / Fraud Account Supervisor
job_title: Fraud Account Supervisor in Tampa, FL
pros: PTO, available after 3 months, health benefits, and 401K matching are great. You probably won't find any place better for a call center job. Some managers are really nice and do legitimately care about you. I loved my manager and that's what led me to stick it out as long as I did before quitting for a job with less stress.
cons: Don't let the title fool you, you're customer service, just in the fraud department. There was a time that the job wasn't so bad, before the Home Depot compromise. After that, the department got slammed. Back to back to back calls, no time in between, from angry customers because Capital One's oversly sensitive fraud detection software rejected their purchase and having people fax documents (fax...it's 2015, come on) to clear up ID concerns. It's interesting for a while, but then you just wear down and begin hating the phone. You cannot really take a breather in between the back to back calls because you're graded on time in between calls, it's one of the stats that goes into your ranking which impacts your bonus and chance of moving to a better shift. QA scores are completely random. You could do the right thing, say the right script 99.9% of the time but if the manager so happens to pick that on call where a customer threw you off and you missed saying something, there goes 12 points and your chance of bonus that month. The stress of QA scores ultimately drove me away..and that was even with me getting a top bonus over 50% of the time in my year+ there. There are no advancement opportunities in this position. You can move to a different department, but about 1 out of every 200 hired employees might have a chance to get promoted to the CAAT team and from there about 1 out of 10 may make manager...eventually. But it will take a while. Pay was poor. I started at $13.01 an hour and got like a .05 or 1% raise after the first year.

Make yourself known, be outgoing, talk to everyone you meet in the lobby during your breaks. When it's not busy, there will be between  8 to 10 minutes between calls.  Another positive is that you get to learn a lot about fraud in general and how it affects card holders.   You primarily get calls from people with high credit limits (meaning they're pretty rich), so it's always nice striking up a conversation with them about their job or business.  You may even get to speak to a famous person too..  I recently got an incoming call from the co-producer of "Resident Evil: Extinction"  in regard to his declined transaction.  Pretty cool.

The potential bonuses are good, but even if you make top bonus every month, the overall yearly pay still isn't great.   Like the other reviews say, the room for advancement is very slim. review_title: Capital One is a great place to work for people that love what they do!
job_title: Senior Project Manager in West McLean, VA
pros: If you are a Finance professional, Capital One offers a chance to work on really exciting and cutting edge projects, enabling quite a bit of professional growth.  This is a great place to work for someone who is passionate about what they do and wants to make a difference. COF's benefits are also another great reason to work here.  COF offers 3-4 weeks of vacation, depending upon tenure (5 yrs is 4 weeks) and offers the ability to purchase an extra week.  COF offers Domestic Partner benefits, 401k matchings, Health & Dependent Care savings accounts (w/ matching).  COF offers a free health clinic in it's building for associates and their families, too.
cons: This is not a company where one can rest on his laurels.  The bonus and merit increases are based on performance rating, and performance ratings are determined in a bell-curve distribution.  It's possible to work really hard, but not get an "Exceptional" rating because others have produced even greater results.  Also, "influencing" is a highly-valued skill-set here, so one must constantly network and build consensus in order to push their ideas.  This is great for someone that has the natural ability, but if not, then it takes a lot of work to get good at this.  And it's important to get good at this because COF pays for performance. Lastly, career advancement in the form of promotions has slowed down at COF, so make sure that you're happy at the level you come in at as you cannot bank on getting promoted within the first year or two.

review_title: Capital One is a great company to work for, with some challenges to work through
pros:
Capital One has a robust hiring process and hires very smart people. The culture is collaborative and is supportive - although there are politics everywhere, my closest friends at Capital One were my peers, who genuinely wanted me to succeed. 

Because of the investment they make in the hiring process, Capital One encourages continued leadership and professional development. They also believe in the "individuals" they hire, which means they give them the support they need. This also means great buildings to work in and a comprehensive campus in Richmond, VA.

Capital One is more supportive than any other company I've seen when they have layoffs.

Capital One is positioned to survive the economic crisis and will likely continue to grow, albeit at a slower pace than before.
cons:
Capital One has the "legacy" culture (from the credit card business) which is very entrepreneurial and prizes intelligence over functional experience (i.e. they're smart & can figure it out) as well as a Bank culture, which is traditional bank (i.e. prioritizing banking experience over raw intelligence). As Capital One acquires more banks, it is unclear which culture will dominate in the long term.

The downside to the entreprenerial culture is that it encourages people across the organization to focus on the next "great" idea, rather than on the execution of the idea (one of the reasons customer experience continues to be a problem). Also, they believe in "reinventing" themselves, which can be good, but can also lead to abrupt eliminations of multi-year projects. 

They've had rolling layoffs across the company over the past few years and this appears to have become a habit.

pros: COF endured the economic downturn, paid back TARP, and is positioned for growth through acquisitions and organically through existing businesses.
cons: Culture can be passive aggressive at times.  Everyone is exceedingly smart, but in many cases experience is lacking, particularly in Marketing & Analysis.  This leads to amateurish mistakes that repeat themselves.  It's getting better as the company matures.

job_title: Customer Service Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Amazing benefits, some departments actually care about their employees, 401k match is outstanding, solid company that really tries to help their employees, gives room for out of the box solutions and most teams want to hear what their employees value, dress code is very relaxed. There are genuinely some smart and talented individuals that work there.
cons: Unfortunately Capital One has a high turnover rate for a reason -- some departments are strict in micromanaging their employees on an absurd level. You're given PTO and flex time and some managers are more lenient than others. There's definitely a lack of communication between different departments and even managers in the same department. There's too many higher ups to have one focused idea and some hardly know what to relay to their employees because it's all "he said, she said" in the office. You have to be careful who you speak about because the company is tightly knit and word travels fast. One particular manager in the High Value Servicing department only cares about herself and not her employees and unfortunately you'll find other managers like that in different departments. This manager, though, wants you to believe she cares about you but when you have a real and pressing issue, her so-called empathy disappears. Particularly, the High Value department hires upper management typically from other departments. These individuals have had little to no idea what happens in High Value and will base most decisions by the book when the department boasts transparency and reaching "outside the box." I think Capital One needs to look at how they structure their management teams and find ones that truly care about their employees. It's such a high turnover rate in that department because employees are being fed misleading information about policy and procedure regarding their work ethic and a customer's account.

pros:
Let me begin by stating that Capital One is in fact one of the best companies to work for in this area. The emphasis on moral is great, and I'll always remember the good times they allowed us to have through employee appreciation events. The atmosphere allowed me to go into work everyday with a positive attitude, and I never dreaded going in unless I had my own personal issues. The job itself is not one you would necessarily dream of but it was not as bad as other collection jobs, according to coworkers. The customers generally understood we had a job to do, and there were only a handful of those who were difficult.  The incentives are good, but as I was leaving the management was making it a little more difficult to achieve eligibility.

Mobility within the company is also great. Although I wasn't given the opportunity to leave the department, many of my peers did (depending on the manager). The whole company was good at working internally. Great, great company in itself to work for.
cons:
Management... If you are looking into joining Capital One collections in Plano, TX...BEWARE. The department managers' methods are extremely questionable and possibly unethical. As far as they're concerned, you will be another pawn on the chessboard. If for whatever reason they found you unfavorable, it seemed to me as any formal policy went out the window and became arbitrary to them, and used to only their advantage to get what they wanted. The pressure became extremely unbearable, even for top performers. A specific example would be that one of the top performers of the past 6 months was unable to leave the department after a year due to the department managers preventing it for their benefit. This agent was able to leave the department after HR intervention.

Now, to say all of management was like this would be unfair, but definitely enough to make me leave voluntarily and go through the effort of writing this warning to you. You may assume that it was entirely my fault and perspective that I see things this way, however unfortunately I am one of many who also left due to the new management. I hope that one day the senior level is able to identify this issue and resolve it for future retention purposes. 

My best advice to those looking into joining the department would be to do as your told, and try your best to succeed while for lack of a better expression, kiss their a**. 

Other than that, the pay could be more competitive especially with the new pressures.

job_title: Senior Associate in New York, NY
pros:
It's a great company to be at. Overall, there's an amazing culture going on, especially in the DC/Richmond/Chicago offices. 

Ample snack, good selection of drinks, video games in the office, and most of what you can ask for at a tech company. 

Company is very well funded – if you work under their customer facing lines of businesses. 

Great pay to stay and collect a paycheck.
cons:
Too much bureaucracy for anything to get done.  

The culture is dying. The quality of new hires coming in are very low. Capital One  can't attract good talent and beginning to "settle" on the remaining applicants. You're not going to attract talent if you under pay your new hires. People are leaving / talking about leaving. Value your design and engineering talent. They're the ones who will bring Capital One to become the tech company it so desires to be. 

Work culture is very dependent on your team / manager. The NYC 114 culture is dead. Long hours plague many teams. It feels like a marketing agency.

If I come back into the office at 8pm because I forgot my keys, and there is an entire team of designers/engineers still in the office on a Friday night, there is a problem. 

If someone is in the office on a holiday, and I'm there to notice that person, there is a problem. 

Too much legacy code. Too many old guys trying to hold onto their jobs. 

It's a dead end for those just starting their careers.

review_title: Previously great company to work for, unfortunately no longer the case.
job_title: Assistant Branch Manager in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Capital One's benefits are terrific. Their PTO/Vacation plans are also great. Insurance provided is well above industry average. Company also provides 5k/year for Full Time Employee Tuition Reimbursement. Dental, Vision, Term Life, AD&D, Disability insurance offered as well. 401(k) match 3% dollar for dollar, and the next 3% .50/dollar. Employee accounts also include free checks, cashier's checks, and no service charges. Training is also very well done, and their internal policy database is very helpful.
cons:
Recently there has been a change in upper management. As a result of that change, and the Dodd-Frank Financial "Reform" bill, there have been severe cuts in staffing and costs industry wide. Now management is micro-managed excessively and needlessly. This is a from Top-to-Bottom problem. From Tellers up to Senior Management there is more coaching taking place thank actual work.

 Emphasis on customer service seems to be lip service. Employees are not empowered to make meaningful decisions at any level, and redundancy is rampant. 

 Sales and service incentive tracking is archaic at best, and in-accurate on a good day. Sales tracking systems often crash several times, causing people to be paid incentives incorrectly or not at all is not uncommon. Incentive program payments have being reduced approximately  25% annually for the past three years. 

Oftentimes new product or business lines are rolled-in or rolled-out in unrealistic time-frames, with no real support.

Examples:
-Mortgage products presently can have up to a 60 days lag time before they get to underwriting, causing duplicate credit applications to be required to proceed with the loan.
-Unsecured loan products were completely canceled with three days notice to branches. 
-Mortgage leads can oftentimes go 30-60 days without being called due to lack of staffing, or lack of accountability. 
-Underwriting is excessive, unrealistic, and completely without accountability.
-Branches have previously been told to stop proactively selling credit-cards completely with short notice.

The computer systems are not integrated, and are a patchwork of programs which make accomplishing simple tasks tiresome and difficult. Branches are staffed at a bare-minimum, and customer service suffers as a result. 

Promotion from within has also suffered as of late, and a large percentage of the senior management comes from outside the bank with little or no experience with the company. Promotion and talent development internally has fallen off a cliff in recent years.

First of all, I'm not sure how Capital One has so many positive reviews on Glassdoor. There has to be many fake reviews here. In my six years working there I didn't know anyone (at least in Retail Bank IT) who was really happy about working there. Most were absolutely miserable. On one hand, Capital One gave me a lot of experience and exposure to things I wouldn't have encountered otherwise. On the other hand, Capital One caused incredible stress to my life because of their morally bankrupt performance management, politics, dishonest and cowardly management, and constant turnover.

If you are considering working there, understand one thing....you are a number on paper. That is it. If management feels that you are not helping their agenda (if anyone even knows what it is), they will push you out by ignoring you and your work, lying about your performance, and finally firing you (they call this "redeployment" to make it sound less serious).  In my last year there, I worked extremely hard to go above and beyond every objective assigned to me, only to have my current manager do a pathetic job at presenting me to the performance management calibrations, which by the way, are based on the opinions of other managers who don't necessarily know anything about what you are working on. It was then I knew it was time for me to go. The whole system is not just ridiculous and absurd, it's immoral.  It is a system designed for upper management to empower "yes men" managers to control hiring/firing.

Capital One is extremely political. I even had a co-worker tell me that to be successful there I should focus more on being visible than my actual work. Believe it or not he was right. Thankfully I found a much smaller company where I don't have to put up with all the nonsense and be rewarded for my actual work. It's absolutely wonderful. If that's what you are looking for, stay far away from Capital One. However, if you are an outgoing person with above average job skills who is good at politics, you'll probably excel.

Make no mistake, Capital One is one of the best companies I've ever seen at marketing a spotless image to the outside public, but on the inside, it is toxic, although it will take new hires a while to pick up on this.
